4497913/4345006/4497954.title: A Prayer
4497913/4345006/4497954.text:
Adorable Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ dying on the gallows for our lives. Oh Holy Cross of Christ see me in thought. Oh Holy Cross of Christ ward off from me all sharp repeating words. Of holy cross ward off from me all weapons of danger. Oh holy cross ward off from me all things that are evil. Oh holy Cross of Christ protect me from my enemies. Of holy cross of Christ protect me in the right way of happines. Oh Crucified Jesus of Nazareth have mercy on me now and for everAmen. In honour of Our Lord Jesus Christ. In honour of his Sacred passion. In honour of his holy resurrection. God -
(continues on next page)

4497975/4345210/4497990.title: An Phaidir Chéanna, Paidir don Aingeal

4498277/4383715/4498303.title: A Collection of Prayers
4498277/4383715/4498303.text:
I have heard many nice prayers and here are some of them.Here is a little prayer to say when dressing. - Dear Lord, thanks for giving me clothing."  Here is a prayer when starting work. - "O my Lord help me to do my work right, and not to be idle and to do all I can to please you.  You who is so good.When lighting the lamp say. - "God grant us the light of heaven."When you awake say. - Lord I thank thee for bringing me safe through the night.  When going (go) on a journey say. - God make the road short in fornt of me.  When going to bed at night say. - Jesus Dear the day is over, and I leave my labour light, and before I seek to slumber I've come to say a sweet Good Night.When you are at work say. - All for the O' Lord, O My Jesus All for Thee.  When going into the church dip your hand in the holy water font and sprinkle it saying. -
(continues on next page)

4498277/4383717/4498304.title: A Collection of Prayers
4498277/4383717/4498304.text:
Here are some prayers I learnt at home. My mother told me these prayers. When I sneeze I always say, "God bless me".  At night when I am going to bed I always say, "Jesus Mary and Joseph send me over the night as you did over the day.  When I get up in the morning I say "Jesus Mary and Joseph send me over this day as you did over the night".  And, thank you dear Lord for bringing me over the night".  This is a prayer I say going to bed. O Mary my Mother in you do I confide and show yourself a Mother to me.  I also say this prayer going to bed. -"As I lay my body down to sleepI give my soul to God to keepAnd if I should die before I wakeI pray to God my soul to take."When starting work I say. "All for Thee O Lord, O My Jesus all for Thee".  When I go into the Church, I dip my hand in the font of holy-water, and I sprinkle the holy-water on the ground saying "Lord have mercy on all the poor
(continues on next page)

4498309/4384053/4498329.title: Old Prayer
4498309/4384053/4498329.text:
(87)Old Prayer.(Skerries, Co. Dublin).To this divine altarI do go.I wish my heart aswhite as snow.And my body freefrom sin, Oh my sweet Jesus enter in.From this divine altar I depart.And my sweet Jesusin my heart.Depart from me the flames of Hell.And in my heart sweet Jesus dwell.
(continues on next page)

4498746/4386033/4498768.title: Old Prayers
4498746/4386033/4498768.text:
Lord, God, all powerful, who hastbrought us safely to the beginningof this day, protect us, by Thy holyprovidence that we may not fallinto sin, but that all our thoughts, words and actions being directedby Thy holy grace may attend toThy accomplishments, and grantthat we may through Thy Divine assistance be delivered and saved,O Saviour of the world, who livestand reignest in peace, and perfectunity, God, world with-out end,Amen.  (To be said when awakening in the morning)O God of Charity without limit, and of love and mercy without measure,it is Thy love induced Thee to cometo me.  I give Thee my body as a temple, my will as a sacrifice, myheart as an alter, my soul as a(?).O Lord, merciful Redeemer of heaven,O noble lovely Infant keep me inThy peace, give me a dwelling in
(continues on next page)

4498746/4386035/4498769.title: Old Prayers
4498746/4386035/4498769.text: Grant me, O Lord the grace to perceivethe vanity and good works of thisday.  May I soar into the bosom of Thy Divine MajestyAmen(To be said on a journey)O most sweet Jesus guide me on my journey, till I start on my way;guide me home, on my journey again,till at last another day is ended and shadows retireAmen.(Going to bed)Grant O God that a happy death may be the end and the crown of a well spent life

4428326/4395196/4499584.title: Paidreacha
4428326/4395196/4499584.text:
Cuirimid sinn féin i bhfiadnuise Dé. Deanamuid gníomh adhraidh Creidim Dia go bhfuil tú annso i lathair go bhfuil tú féachaint orm, go bhfuil tú ag eisteacht liom, go bhfuil fios agat ar mo uile smaointigh. Adhraidhim agus ónóruighim thú. Adhmhuighim gur tú mo Chrúthuightheóir agus mo Ardtigearna Islighim mé feín go h.iomlan faoi do smachtBheirim mile buidheachais duit a thighearna ar son na tiodhlacadh agus grásta thug tú damh ó thainig mé ar an tsaoghail seo agus go speísealta mo thabhairt slán ón oidhche areír un an lae ghilTá rún agam a thigearna le congnamh do naomh grásta mo bheatha leásughadh o seo suas gan nidh ar bith a dheanadh, le smuaintigh le briathra, le gníomh nó le faillige a cuireas fearg ort ; na peacaidh as mó a bhfuil agam claon a sheachnadh  Tá suil agam gach buaireadh agus gach triobloid do dtiocfad ann mo shlighe ar feadh an lae seo iompchur go foighdeach mar sásamh mo peacaidh
(continues on next page)

4428326/4395210/4499609.title: Paidreacha
4428326/4395210/4499609.text:
Fáilte romhat a Mhuire Mhórsiar i reault na maidne sgiath na mbocht agus anam carad thóg arais an blathÉabha is mór an grasta duit támhuigh duinn síothchain Dhe sgaoil na glais a ceangluigheas mé tabhair greim don bhocht don dall a cabharmathair muirneach ríona ndúil sgath na subhailce seact gan reachtMathair na hEaglaise agus ná humhlaidheachtamóltar faoi do coimricceím do mhic ar olc ar éagcoir
(continues on next page)

4428084/4376517/4499876.title: Local Prayers
4428084/4376517/4499876.text:
This is a little prayer you should say when in bed"In this bed I lie to sleepTo God I give my soul to keepAnd if I die before I wakeI pray to god my soul to take.There are four corners in my bedThere are four angels over spreadMatthew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless this bed that I lay on.As I look up at the Blessed LambI see the Blessed Virgin Mary passing onSeven Mass books in her handsSeven priests singingSeven bells ringingOpen the gates of HeavenClose the gates of HellAnd enter my poor soul intoHeaven for evermore. Amen."This is another prayer to be said when
(continues on next page)

4428084/4376519/4499877.title: Local Prayers
4428084/4376519/4499877.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Going to bed say :"Matthew, Mark, Luke and JohnBless the bed that I lay on"When in the bed say :"I lay my body down to sleepI give my soul to God to keepWake now and wake neverI give my soul to God foreverThere are four corners in my bedThere are four angels overheadOne to guard, two to guideAnd one to watch me through the night. Amen.An act of homage to God and to his Blessed Mother :To God we pray both night and dayTo have us in his keeping

4461441/4395174/4500806.text:
Crios Mhuire mo ChriosCrios na gCeithre gCrosCrios in-a rughadh Iosa(Os cionn a thumba)“Éirigh a mháthar a’s gabh fhad leis an bhean atá ingéibhinn báis”“Éirigh fhein a mhic as Tú is feárr baist an leanbh as fág an bhean slán.Tá sé sgriobhtha as Tumba Mhuire anois.Nach bhfuil aon duine a déarfas an paidir seoTrí h-uaire ach uile lá.Nach bhfeicidh an Mhaidhgean MhuireTrí h-uaire roimhe a bhás.



A Iosa mhilis a’s a Iosa ceannsaGo lionaidh tú ar gcroidhe-sa lan de annsachtA Iosa Críost na h-Óige uaisleCuidigh linn anois is i n-am ar gcruadh-cásGach uile fháilte rómhat a Naomh Muire, a mhathair Dé, a Rioghain Flaithis, a Gheaftaí Phárthais, a Bhan-tíghearna an Dómhain, a bhfuil dóigh ort fíor glan. A bhean beannuighthe rugadh tú gan peacadh na sinnsear. D’iomchur tú ar Slánnighthear Iosa Críost ann do bhroin beannuighthe gan sol, gan spot go geanmhnaidhe roimhe iomchur, dhá iomchur indhiaidh iomchur.Och, chum Iosa deán eadarguidh
(continues on next page)

ar ar son, le ach briseadh croidhe agus gach buaid (readh?) a leanain dúinn ar feádh ar mbeatha.Chum De, an Mhic, cosan m’anam anois agus ar uair mo bháis. Tabhair leat m’anam ann do dís lamhe, ann do neamh fhein, ann do ghlór fhéin Ó A Thíghearna Dé amein.

4498043/4345589/4502030.title: The Sight of the Devil
4498043/4345589/4502030.text:
One night a croud of cardplayers were playing cards They started argueing and scolding and quarrelling. Some of them wanted to keep on playing but one of the men said he would not. They heard a knock at the door. They opened the door and a strange man came in a man whom they never saw before He started playing with them. At 12'o clock a card fell. One of them went under the table to pick it up. He saw that the man had cloven feet. He shouted they then threw down the cards and the Devil said "Only for the holy things you are wearing I would have your all killed



I lie in my bed as I lie in my graveAnd call upon Jesus my soul for to saveJesus the branch and Mary the flowerCome to Me in my dying hour

4428085/4376642/4502461.title: Prayers
4428085/4376642/4502461.text:
1. I lay my body down to sleepI pray to God my soul to keepAnd if I die before I wakeI pray to God my soul to take.2. A Harvest PrayerLord, grant that the greater harvestWhich You came on Earth to saveMay be golden and ripe for the reapingEre we go to the lonely grave.That our soul in the last dread AutumnMay be clean as the hill and leaWhen we bring life's grain to the haggardAnd offer it all to thee.3. When we begin workLive, Jesus, live, so live in meThat all I do be done for theeAll that I do or think or sayThroughout the coming day.4. There are four corners on my bed
(continues on next page)

4428085/4376644/4502462.title: Prayers

There are four angels overheadOne to watch and one to prayAnd two to bear my soul away5. Guardian Angel me defendLook on me your little friendBless my life to my last end.



1. I recommend myself to the Blessed Virgin and place myself under her protection to watch over and  guard me for the night.2. Matthew, Mark, Luke and JohnBless the bed that I lie onAnd if I die before I wakeI pray to God my soul to take.

Heart of Jesus, meek and mildLook on me, the little childPity mine and pity meAnd suffer me to come to thee.Heart of Jesus I adoreHeart of Mary, I imploreSweet heart of Joseph, pure and justIn these three hearts I place my trust4. I must die, I do not know how or when or where; but if I die in mortal sin, I am lost forever. O Jesus have mercy on me and Mary, help me!Mary, my mother and my hopeI take refuge under thy mantleThere will I live and dieDeliver me from sin and grant meAlways thy holy blessing.

1, As I look up at the Blessed LampI see the Blessed Virgin coming onSeven Mass books in her handSeven priests singingSeven bells ringingOpen the gates of HeavenClose the gates of HellEnter my soul into HeavenAnd forever more. Amen.2. 4498043/4345613/4503038.title: A Prayer
4498043/4345613/4503038.text:
Oh Angel of God to whose holy care I am committed by the supreme clemency illuminate defend govern and protect me this night from all sin and danger.Amen.



"It was a Good Friday and a good Friday it was Our Lord Jesus Christ was cruelly scourged. His heart and hands were pierced with a lance. His precious blood ran trickling down. His blessed Mother standing by, with a heavy heart and a woeful sigh." Anyone that say that three times by day or by night shall never enter the gates of hell. But is sure of the gates of heaven. Amen.

4498043/4345634/4503181.title: A Witch Minding the Gold
4498043/4345634/4503181.text:
There was a very rich man in Turlough and he had three pots of gold. He told the people that he would divide two pots of Gold among his friends and that he would bury the other pot and also that he would tell three people where he hid it. If they could bring it up they should have it for themselves He had it buried in a puddle of water. The three people he told got three divers and they dived down and they could see the pot of Gold but they could not get to it as there was a witch minding it.



When our Lord Saw the Cross he shook and trembled. the Jews asked Him if he ever had a fever "No Said he, "I never had a fever nor an ague. Blessed be the hearers and the Believer and Blessed be Our Lord Jesus Christ.

4498043/4345644/4503231.title: Mass
4498043/4345644/4503231.text:
Once upon a time a woman made a promise to go to Mass every eveny day for a year. She went wet and dry for the year and every day she went she used to put a peble into a bosc When the twelve months were up she looked at the bosc but there was only one peble in the bosc because while she was at Mass she used to be going on and laughing. She only got the benefit of one Mass.



O merciful Jesues have mercy on me My sould and my body I resign it to Thee. The five beaten bones nailed to a tree. O merciful Jesues have mercy on me

4428086/4376837/4504183.title: A Collection of Prayers
4428086/4376837/4504183.text: The prayers I was taught when I was young were the prayers going to bed and the prayer in the mornings. This is a night prayer."There are four corners in my bed.There are four angels overhead,Mathew, Mark, Luke, and John,God bless the bed that I lay on."This is a prayer which should be said going through life."Death shall come to seek me.A short half hour ere day,And for each guileful action,H'ell make me dearly pay.In the death room lying lonelyWith the brown shroud round me only,How gladly I'd do penance if then I had the way."

4428086/4376838/4504185.title: A Collection of Prayers
4428086/4376838/4504185.text: This is a prayer said going to bed.When I lay down on my bed to sleep,I give my soul to God to keep,And if I die before I awake,I give my soul to God to take.See the Blessed Virgin coming,And seven Mass-books in her hands,Seven Priests singing, seven bells ringing.Open the gates of Heaven shut the gates of hell.Whoever shall say this little Prayer there times by night and three times by day never shall see the fire of hell.

4428086/4376839/4504188.title: A Collection of Prayers
4428086/4376839/4504188.text:
A prayer when going to bed.The Lord bless the bed I'm going to lie onAnd bless the sleep I'm going to take.Sweet Mary my Mother be thou at my headBlessed John the Baptist be thou at my feetAnd the dear Angel of God at my side.May Christ's messenger with the holy oil be in time at my death to put the seal on my soul in the Name of Christ crucified.



In the name of the Lord Jesus CrucifiedI lay down to rest.Bless me O Lord defend and govern me.And after this short and miserable

4427864/4351783/4504695.title: Prayers
4427864/4351783/4504695.text: Brígidh agus a brat, Mhuire agus a Mhac,An dhá Aspol déag bhí mo cuadach aris go maidinHere I lay down to rest I pray to God my Soul to bless, if I die before I awake I pray to God my soul to take, four corners on the bed four angels on the spred Mathew Mark Luke and John God bless me in the bed I lay on.Beannuigheann díbh i loct na sgobal na leig fallaí a beit ar mo hais is maraigh a léigh a bios gan carraig agus beidh muid ar leigh ar féasta an luime muide. huibhream taobh ó dól iad na dteine agus nol muinntir plaise taobh ó dheas agus na héangla tiochfaidh muire agus beannoicht sí gach aon mhach agus foslóige si gúna más feidir.

4428167/4383281/4507039.title: Home Prayers
4428167/4383281/4507039.text:
231House PrayersI lay my body down to sleep. I pray to God my should to keep, and if I die before I wake. I pray to God my should to take, there are four corners on my bed there are four angles round my head Mathew, Mark, Luke and John God bless the bed I lay on.



PrayerIn the morning when I waken I say O my God I will raise myself up from this bed of sleep to adore thee my God to labour for the salvation of soul.



PrayerDear Jesus I give Thee thanks for bringing me safe during this nightShow us thy holy face O Lord and we shall be saved. Thy servant ariseth O Lord have mercy on me. Dear Jesus grant me the grace to love you more and more. O Holy St Joseph  head of the Holy Family pray for me. O my God I love you O my God I adore TheeJesus meek and humble of heart make my heart like to thine.

4428167/4383282/4507043.title: Home Prayers
4428167/4383282/4507043.text:
232Home Prayers.Jesus dear the day is over, now I leave my labour light, and before I seek my slumber, come to say a sweet good night. Would that I could tarry near Thee, rest before Thy lonely Shrine. Thou woulds't whisper loving secrets and I would tell thee all of mine. But I cannot linger Jesus I must leave Thee for awhile, now bestow on me a blessing and a fond improving smile. I will leave my heart beside Thee, it will rest securest there, and within its fond embrace, twill grow to thee more dear, so good night once more my Jesus, grant no matter where I be, all my thoughts and all my dreaming,be of Thee and only Thee. Amen.O my God, I offer Thee this day through the most pure hands of the B.V. M. all the masses that are offered this day (day) throughout the entire world for Thy greater honour and a glory for the honour of the Holy Mother for the holy souls in purgatory, and for the salvation of dying souls
(continues on next page)

4428167/4383284/4507045.title: Home Prayers
4428167/4383284/4507045.text: 234Home prayers.Saviour I love you very much you are so good. O devine understanding which knows all things ever guide me with Thy light. Amen.Holy mother pierce me through in my heart each wound renew of my Savior crusified. Amen.Mathew, Mark, Luke and John. Bless the bed that I lie on. If I should die before I wake pray to God my soul to take. Amen.O Jesus meek and humble of heart. Make my heart like unto thine. Amen.O how I love thee Jesus my soul aspires to thee come rain in my heart smile tenderly on me. Amen.Mary Murphy V ST

4428167/4383285/4507047.title: Home Prayers
4428167/4383285/4507047.text: 235Home Prayers.Remember O most gracious lady that never was known any protection or improyortae in sort or interession was left in aide inspice this confitence I fly unto thee O Virgin O Virgin my mother to thee I stand sinful and sorrowful do not mother of the world income inspice my pertection but inclemation and answer me. Amen.Head I lay my head asleep I give my soul to God to keep wheather I rise now or ever I give soul to God for ever. There are four corners on my bed there are four angles to gard my head Saint Mathew Mark Luke and John God bless the bed that I lay on.Margaret Roy V ST

4428167/4383286/4507050.title: Home Prayers
4428167/4383286/4507050.text: 236Home Prayers.By the sprinkling of thy most precious Blood O Lord Jesus and by merits of thy bitter passion wash me from every stain and cleanse me every sin Amen.Eternal Father suffer me to offer thee the hearts of Jesus Christ. Thy beloved Son as He Himself offers it in sacrifice to thee Receive this offering for me as well as all my desires. Amen.O Mary my Queen and my Mother. I offer myself entirely to Thee, and in order to prove myself devoted to thee, I consecrate to thee, this day my sight my hearing my speech my heart my whole being. Since therefore I am thine, O good Mother preserve me, defend me as thy property and procession. Amen.Mary Carey V.ST.

4428167/4383287/4507351.title: Home Prayers
4428167/4383287/4507351.text: 237Home Prayers.Here I lay down to sleep. I pray to God my soul to make. If I should die before I wake. I pray to God my soul to take.Four corners on my bed, four angles arround me spread. Mat and Mark, Luke and John. God bless the bed that I lay on.Amen.Hear I lay down to sleep. In the name of the Lord Jesus Christ, crucified, may I a rise on the last day with the same body which we have in this life.Amen.O Jesus meek and humble of heart, Make my heart like unto thine.Amen. Annie Gorman. VII

4428167/4383288/4507359.title: Home Prayers
4428167/4383288/4507359.text: 238Home Prayers.O Mary my queen and my motherI take refuge under thy mantle,their will I live and their willI die deliver me from sin and grantme thy holy blessing.Amen.O Jesus most pure of heart O spotless Lamb of God help me that all through my life. I may never displease thee by and wicked thingGive me the blessing of the clean of heart.Amen.PrayerO my god angel thou comest from heaven God sent thee to take of me shelter me and under thy wing lighten my path direct my steps do not leave me stay quite near me. defend me against the spirit of evil but above all come to my help in last struggle of my life.Amen.John McFadden VI ST.

4498200/4383363/4507495.title: Prayers
4498200/4383363/4507495.text: 357PrayersAn old prayer said after the rosary, coming up to Christmas time is-Sweet infant, Jesus, come,into my heart,Come and root out sinAny plans thy virtues there.When we hear of a death we say-"May the Lord have mercy on his/her soul."When we see an invalid or  cripple we say "God bless the mark"When a person is shown a baby or a new beast they say "God bless it." When a person enters a house they say "God bless all here." When we are in trouble we say "God's will be done."If you are passing by people working you would say "God bless the work,: another prayer said after the rosary is"Providence can, Providence did,Providence will provideO'mercy and all provident GodHere my prayers and grant my petition"Collected by P MurrayFullams Stfrom Mrs Kinnane (Granny)Clonard St age 75

4497910/4344838/4507820.title: Paidreacha
4497910/4344838/4507820.text:
Paidreacha.Ar maidin:1:    Éirighim suas le Dia go n-éirighidh Dia liomláimh Dé in mo thimcheall ag suidhe 's ag luighe's ag éirighe dhom.2: ar maidin:Toil Dé go ndéanamaoid, ár n-antoil féin go smachtuighmid,srian le n-ár dteangaidh go gcuirimid,an aithrighe thráthamhail go ndéanamaoid,ar pháis Críost go smaoinimid,gach coir peacaidh go seachnuighmid,bás bheannuighthe go bhfaghmaoid,ceol na n-aingeal go gcluinimid,ag moladh Dé go rabhmaoid.        le linn na saoghal.           Amen.
(continues on next page)

4428169/4383472/4508202.title: Old Prayers
4428169/4383472/4508202.text:
When passing a CrucifixOld people have many beautiful prayers which are to be said at certain times. O Lord my God by suffering rent. Nailed to the Cross my love to gain. Grant through Thy Cross, when life is spent. In death Thy mercy I obtain.When taking Holy WaterBy the sprinkling of The Precious Blood, O Lord Jesus, and by the merits of Thy Sacred passion, wash me from every stain, and cleanse my soul from sin. Amen.When genuflectingWe adore Thee, O Lord Jesus Christ, and we bless thee here and at the Tabernacles all
(continues on next page)

4428169/4383483/4508599.title: A Collection of Old Prayers
4428169/4383483/4508599.text: it is a custom with some of the people in Balbriggan when the fire does not light up quickly to say "Theresa Higginson Spouse of the Crucified pray for us"It is also a custom every night before getting into bed to make the letters I.N.R.I on their forehead saying "Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews, preserve me from a sudden and unprovided death. Amen" Another prayer is "God bless me and make me a true and faithful servant to my life's end. Amen"Also "Bless me, O Lord defend and govern me after this short and miserable pilgrimage, O Lord, bring me to everlasting happiness. Amen"

4498347/4383942/4508600.title: Local Prayers
4498347/4383942/4508600.text: When I was very young I remember my Grandmother teaching me my prayers, and nearly all these were local ones.  When I would be going to bed she would say "Oh my God lay me down to sleep," and also "Bless me o Lord and defend me this night from all dangers Amen."When I would be going to school I would say "Oh my God send me safe over the day and in the beginning of the night.Another prayer to be said in the morning is "God save us from mortal sin and mortal sore and from the hands of our enemies soul and body.

4498873/4387912/4510226.title: Prayers
4498873/4387912/4510226.text:
There are four corners on my bed,There are four angels overspread,Matthew, Mark, Luke and John,God bless the bed that I lie onIf I die in the morn, before I wake,I prey to God my soul to take.I am a little Catholic,I love my holy faith,I love my cross, I love my beads,I'll love them until death.As I went up the Blessed Land,I met the Blessed Virgin,Seven prayer books in he hand,Seven candles lit.Seven bells ringing,Seven priests singing,Shut the gates to hell.Open the gates of heaven,Let the poor suffering soul in.Blessed be the leaf, blessed be the flower,Jesus ever at my dying hour.
(continues on next page)

4498746/4386032/4510250.title: Old Prayers
4498746/4386032/4510250.text: Old prayers.O Lord, bless the bed I am going to lie on.And bless this sleep I am going to takeSweet Mary, my mother be thou at my head.Blessed John, the apostle be thou at my feet.And the dear angel of God at mysideMay Christ's messenger with the holy oils be in time at my deathto put the seal on my soul.In the name of Christ crucifiedAmen(To be said going to bed)

4498746/4386036/4510259.title: Old Prayers
4498746/4386036/4510259.text: Mary my mother, loving and mild.Look upon me a poor little child.With the eyes of pity, I call upon thee.Mary my mother look kindly on me.Pity me and suffer me to come to thee.(To be said when going to bed)."God save all here", (Said going to a house)."God be with you", (Going to bed)."The Lord be near us" (Going on a journey)."May the Heaven's be his bed tonight". (When a person is dead).Guardian Angel keep and protect me form sin and danger.  Amen. (To be said going to bed).O'Holy Father keep me from all danger.  amen.  (Said when going on a journey).Brigid Farrel,73, St. Peter's Tce.Howth.

4498789/4385719/4510467.title: Prayers
4498789/4385719/4510467.text: PrayersThis prayer is said before going to sleep at night, This night I lie down to sleep, I give my soul to God to keep and if I awake and if I never I give my soul to God forever. Heaven is the branch, Mary is the flower, Jesus may be with me at my dying hour. There are four corners on my bed, there are four angels overhead Matthew, Mark, Luke and John. God bless the bed that I lie on. If any evil comes to me blessed Lady awake me that I may have my right hand to bless me.This prayer is said before arising in the morning. I arise from this bed of sleep to adore thee my God and to labour for the salvation of my soul O may I arise on the last day to life ever lasting.Lillie GoughI got this information fromMr Gough16 Station RoadSuttonCo Dublin

4428389/4403096/4511185.title: Seanurnaí
4428389/4403096/4511185.text:
Sean Urnaigh.Gcluin sibh mise lucht na scabaillNa déanigidh faillighe ann mar gcás,Is mairg a bhíos gan a charaidAgus é na luighe ar leabaidh an bháis.A dhuine bhocht gan chéill na déan bréag le MuireNa h-ith feól Dia.Ceadoin' agus na h-éiligh do thinneasUmhluigh do'n chléir agus do na cúig féile MuireGlac comaoineacha Mhic De agus béidh tú ag féasta igcúirt na n-aingil.Bhí Muire agus a mac ag siubhal amuigh lá,Casadh pearsa do dhuine bheannuighthe orthaMar bhí Símeon as a' RóimhShín sé as a dheas láimh daobhthaSgaball Mhuire na [?] óirNíl aon dhuine a iompróchas mo aibidAgus é iomchar mar is cóir.
(continues on next page)

4428389/4403098/4511186.title: Urnaithe le Rá i ndiaidh Dul a Luí
4428389/4403098/4511186.text:
Urnuighthe le Rádh indiaidh dul a luigheLuighim ar an leabaidh seó mar a shíntear mé san uaighGhnídhum faoisidín chruaidh cráidhte leat a Mhic De.Mo shocharthacht, mo chodhlata agus olcas mo chroidhe,A Dhia nach mé tá lochtach, ní [?] aon chomhnuidheMháthair Íosa bí ag mo cheann. Eoin Baiste bí ag mo bhonn.Theachtaire dílis in éadaigh Chríost, bí agam in am.Go gcuiridh tú ola Chríosta ar m'anam Dílis,A cheannuigh Íosa ar an chrann.
(continues on next page)

4428390/4403280/4511395.title: Seanphaidreacha
4428390/4403280/4511395.text:
Paidir na Scaball'gCluin sibh mise, lucht na sgaball, ná déanaigidh faillighe in bhur gcás. Is truagh sin duine gan carad na luighe ar leabaidh an bháis. A dhuine bhoicht gan chéill, ná ith feol Dia Ceadaoine agus ná éagcaoindo thinneas. Umhlaigh do'n chléir agus do na cúig féile Muire. Deán d'fhaoisidín ag Dia agus beidh tú ag féasta Mhuire ag éisteacht cneas na leanbh.Bhí Muire agus a Mac amuigh ag siubhal san lá. Casadh ortha an pearsa Siobáin bheannuighthe ar an Róimh. Shín sí dó is a deis láimh scabaill breágh na mbrainsí óir. "Níl aoin duine a gcaithfidhmo aibid agus í chaithfheadh mar is cóir nach mbeadh séala agam-sa ar a ainm ins an Ghlóir". A Mhiahgdean luachmhar bhlathmhar, bheannuighthe, is tú bhíos ag gabhail romham ins na bealaigh. Nuair bhéas an tóir ar an pheacach, seól mé ar an eolas go pobal na h-aithrighe an áit a siltear na deóra.2. Cuirimid sinn féin i bfidhneise Dé agus na Maighdine Muire, ag iarraidh
(continues on next page)

4428395/4403914/4512380.title: Urnaíocha
4428395/4403914/4512380.text:
UrnaigheachaA Mhaighdean Mhuire is gile ná'n ghrianA Mháthair Dé gan smál.Coinneal Mhuire i bhflaitheas Dé,Go raibh lasta os cionn mo anma ar uair mo bháis.



Paidir i n-éadan fiabhrais Anna, máthair Mhuire agus Muire máthair Chríost,Iseabal máthair Naomh Eoin baiste.iadsan uilig idir mise agus leabaidh an fhiabhraisThainic Íosa go bun na croiche, indiaidh an méid a chur Sé agus a threabhaidh Sé. Thainic crith air agus d'fiafruigh na h Iúdaigh an fiabhras a bhí Air no fiabhras creathach. " Chan fiabhras atá orm nó fiabhras creathach, a's is beannuighthe an té deirfeas mo chuid focla agus chuinneochas i gcuimhne iad. Chá bhíonn fiabhras no fiabhras creathach air anois no go bráthach."Diúltaim dó'n diabhal, dó'n tsaoghal, a's dó'n cholainn,Tógam an chrois agus leanaim Íosa Críost.

4428395/4403915/4512382.title: Urnaí eile
4428395/4403915/4512382.text:
urnaighe eileFáilte rómhat a Rí an DómhnaighFáilte rómhat a Rí na hóige gile,Fáilte roimh na trí haingle is sinne agus is óige 's na flaithis.Gurab iad a  ghárda ar mó anam ar uair mó bháis agus 'mo chruaidh chás.



Urnaighe a deirtear ag coigilt na teineadhCoiglim an teinidh seo mar choiglim crannNaomh Pádraic (mar deantar N. Pádraic)Bríghid ag a bun agus Máire ag a bárrAn dá easbal déag atá i bflaitheas na naomhFágam-sa cúram an tighe seo agus a bhfuil ann go la.leagan EileCoiglim-sa an teine seo mar choigleas cách,Brighid fá na bun agus Máire fá na bárr.Na naoi n aingle  ar fhichid atá i gcathair na ngrásGo raibh fá'n tigh seo a's na daoine go lá.

4428395/4403917/4512383.title: Urnaí eile - An Aiséirí
4428395/4403917/4512383.text: urnaighe eile-An EiséirighAn eiséirigh chualaidh tú léighte as leabhar na nGaedheal'Críost a chuaidh an sochair,  mar rinneadh Íosa a chrochadh ar chrannAoine an chrochaimh cuimhneach,  tabhairgidh iall de bhur gciall a cheannacht Shíol Éabha, bhí Mac na hóighe i bfianA Mhuire chá-n é do chabhair féin a thainic nuair thainic an duine dall anoir as na h Indhiaca thoir agus sleagh ghéar leis 'na láimhA Mhuire, is mairg a bhainfeadh an tsleagh le cur fríd corp mó Shlánuightheóra. bean fá na chosa, bean fá na cheann, an treas bean faoi ghrúis Dé.Fáilte rómhat a Mhícheáil mhaith, is tú a ghéilfeadh dó'n tsleagh ghlain. Braithlín gheal ar shliabh na hóige atharughadh bruighinn agus glóir'. Is iomdha comhartha a's gárda ar an urchóid agus an grian a- fás.An té a mbéadh an eiséirigh aige agus deirfeadh achan lá i, ní dual do leacacha ifrinn anois no go bráthach.is dóiche go bhfuil seo thuas measgtha. Seo mar fuair mise é ó Áine Ní Fíoruisge (dalta)

4428395/4403918/4512384.title: Urnaí
4428395/4403918/4512384.text:
UrnaigheM'anam bog suas do chreideamh , do dhóchas agus do ghrádh nó tá tú annseo i láthair an Té is áirde. Tá tú annseo ar ghnó mór do-chuimhseach do Dhia a ghrádhuigh thú agus a tháinig anuas ar na flaithis mar gheall ort. Ghlac Sé colann daonda agus  d'eug Sé ar an 'croich' le sinn a shlánughadh. Tá Sé annseo anois ins an tsacramaint Naomhtha le do gach aon do éisteachtLabhair leis agus abair, "Ó, mo Dhia, creidim go daingean seasmhach go bhfuil tú annseo anois le sinn do chothughadh chun na beatha siorruidhe le do chuid fola agus feola ins an Cumaoineacha seo.Peacach bocht mé, sínte ag do chosa beannuighthe ag agairt do thrócaire. Ní fiú me a theacht in do láthair. Ní fiú mé oiread agus amharc suas ort. Ó, Dhia, dá bhfuighinn mar thuill mé is losgadh sioruidhe a gheobhainn. Dhia na trócaire, nár dúbhairt Tú féin ins an tsoisgéal go raibh Tú fonnmhar chun ár slánuighadh. Adhraim agus onóruighim thú a gcuideachta do chuid naomh agus aingle agus do mháthair bheannuighthe.Tá uchtach agam in do mhór chumhachta, tá muinighin láidir agam in do mhaitheas agus in do thrócaire agus na gealltanais cinnte a thug tú dhúinn ins an tsoisgeul. Tá dóchas agam a Dhia go dtabharfaidh tú maitheamhnas damh in
(continues on next page)

4428395/4403921/4512385.title: Urnaí
4428395/4403921/4512385.text:
UrnaigheA Mhaighistir Nazareth, Íosa, Rí na IúdaightheSábhail mé ar bhás thobanGan mé réidh fá na choinne.UrnaigheÍosa, mhic Íosa agus athair an t-suain,ort fuil mo Chríost mo cheannacht go cruaidh.Go raibh tú agam 'mo shuidhe a's mo luighe.'Mo chodladh a's 'mo shuan.



PaidirLuighim se ins an leabhaidh mar sínfear mé san uaigh,deánamh mo fhaoistean le Dia.As chaointe mo cholainne agus olcas mo chroidheA Dhia nach mise an duine lochtach.Indiaidh é gheallstan a's nach ndeanaim duit éNaoimh aspail go raibh  ag mo cheann,agus Rí an Domhnaigh ag mo bhonn.teachtaire Dé i n-éideadh Chríost a bheith agam i n-am go gcuiridh sé ola Chríost ar m-anam dílis,A cheannuigh Íosa ar a chrann.
(continues on next page)

4428395/4403923/4512387.title: Urnaí i ndiaidh Paidrín
4428395/4403923/4512387.text:
urnaighe indiadh paidrín'S mé an créatúr lag faoí ualach thromDa mhéad mo pheacaidh is aithreaach liomAdmhuighim creideamh Dé go síor,le grádh mó chroidhe's le dóchas fíorÓ chois na croiche glaoidhim suasA Thighearna Íosa claoin anuas.Fáilte dhuit a Mhuire mhór,Tarraing orainn le do chabhair.A Mhathair Íosa, a Réalt na mara,A sgath na mbocht 's ar n-anam chara Is tú thóg an t-úan a shaothruigh sinn,Is e is mó thug grása duit,Is tú thog arais an blath a thuit le hÉabhaAnois agus ar uair ar n-éuga,Tadhbhuigh dúinne siothcháin DéSgaoil na glas a cheanglas méTabhair greim dó'n bhocht, dó'n dall a shúilA Mhathair mhuirnach 's a ríoghan na nDúl.A sgathán an cheirt 's a airc an reachtA Chathaoir na hEagna agus na húmhlaidheachtSaor mé le céim do  Mhic, ar olc  daigh a's éug
(continues on next page)

4428395/4403925/4512388.title: Paidir
4428395/4403925/4512388.text:
Go tobar na hathirighe 'n-áit a siltear na deora.Go líntear mo chroidhse  mar gheall ar an athairGo níghtear m-anam ó gach smál an pheacaidhA Mhaighdean mhódhmhair, mhodhamhail, mhaiseach,Is tú lón agus stór mo thaisgidh;Is tú an Réalt eolais a'dul romhain ar an chasan,d'ár gcuir ar an eolas, 'san tóir ar an  pheacadh.
(continues on next page)



(continued from previous page)
PaidirCrios Mhuire, mo chrios,Crios na gceithre gcrosCrios ar a baisteadh CríostFaoi chrios an taobh dheis.Eirigh a mhathair, baist an leanbh,Eirigh féin a mhic is tú 's fearr;Nil aon fhear no bhean a deirfeas an urnaigh seo gach lá,nach dual do an Mhaighdean Mhuirea fheiceáil naoí lá roimh a bhás.

4428396/4404028/4512512.title: Aicíd
4428396/4404028/4512512.text:
Tá sé le dhá fhichead bliadhain ó shoin é bhris aicíd amach san áit seo. Ní raibh fhios ag na daoine cá h-ainm a bhí uirthí agus bhaist siad an "Aicíd Mhór" uirthí. Ní raibh fhios ag na daoine caidé ba chionntuigh le seo. Shíl siad gurab'é an rud a thóg é cionn'us go rabh an t-eallach atoigh ins na toighthe ag na daoine. Fuair cuid mhór daoine bás mar nach raibh óisbidéil ar bith ann.



IA Íosa, 'Mhuire, agus a Ioseph, bheirim mo chroidhe agus mo anam duit. 'Íosa, 'Mhuire, agus a Ioseph, go téighidh mo anam fríd do lámha beannuighthe an lá deireannach Amen a Íosa. IISíntear mise sa leabaidh seo 'gus már síntear mo chorp san uaigh. Ceithre choirnéil ar mo leabaidh agus ceithre h-Aingle go rabh innú. Dia amuigh agus Dia istigh, Dia agus Críosta i gcuid de'n teach. Murlamh h-Aingle cumhdaigh mé. Críost ag cionn, Naomh Eoin baiste 'gus na h-easbail ag mo chosa. A Mhaighdean a Mhuire má thig a dhath orm ins an oidche 'gus mé mo chodladh musgail mé. IIIIs mé an créatúr lag faoi ualach throm, ag cois na croiche guidhim suas duit a Íosa a Mhuire le mé chur ar bhealach mo leasa agus mé a shabháil ar gach olc, Amen. IVÓ a Dhia mhór uile-chumhachtaigh is tú mo chruthuitheóir 'gus mo aireach liom. Sábhail mé ar thúbaistí agus ar dháinséir ar feadh oidche agus lá agus go h-aírid ar uair mo bháis Amen.
(continues on next page)

4428396/4404029/4512513.title: Seanphaidreacha
4428396/4404029/4512513.text:
(continued from previous page)
Ó a Íosa  mo anam, a Mhuire mo anam agus mo chruthuigheóir. Ná leig cuid cathuighthe an diabhail nó a chuid oibreacha i n-aice liom.A Maighdean a Mhuire, bí ag siubhal liom ar feadh lae agus oidhche. A Naomh Antóine má chaillim a dhath cuidigh liom é a fhághail. A Pheadar na n-eochracha agus Eoin baiste fosglaigidh an doras damh agus leigigidh isteach mé ar  an lá deireannach.           VITá mé mo luighe san  leabaidh seo 'gus mé tinn 'gus lag, a Íosa milis. Críosta go rabh tú ag mo ghárdáil. A Mhaighdean a Mhuire, 'gus a aingéal Dé déanaigidh biseach damh má's féidir é agus má fhághaim bás, go dtéighidh mo anam fríd bhur lámha beannuighthe.          VIIÉirighim-sa amach as an leabaidh seo 'gus go n'éirighidh Dia liom.Cuirim-sa orm mo chuid eudaigh agus go gcuidigh Dia liom. Guidhim suas le Dia agus go n-éistighidh Dia mé.           VIIIAg coigilt na teineadhDruidim-sa mo dhoras agus coiglim mo theinidh, ionar chrann na páise. Má mhusclann mo charad mé na musgladh mo námhaid mé Loch Finne faoi an teach, loch na dtéigidh ceo uirthí. Caill, breis nó dóghadh na dtigidh ar mo teach nó ar aon duine dá bhfuil ann go maidín.Sorcha Ní Ghallchobhair, Mín-na-Lárach, Gort -an-ChoirceBrighid Ní Ghallchobhair, Mín -na-Lárach, Gort-an-Choirce



Paidreacha eile IIMuire agus a mac ag siubhal amuigh sa la casadh daobhtha an pearsa beannuighthe Siúman as an Róimh. Shín sé daobhtha
(continues on next page)

4428384/4402789/4512574.title: Tomhaiseanna
4428384/4402789/4512574.text:
(continued from previous page)
Chuaidh fear na coilleadh bhaint slatacha, an méid a bhain sé chaith sé uadh iad, agus an méid nár bhain sé, bhí said leis na bhaile.“Fear ag baint féasóige dó fhéin.Cuartaigh mé agus chuartaigh mé é, agus nuair a fuair mé é, chaith mé uaim é.“Dealg an do chois.”Gearán beag bobailte, trigailte donn, siubhlann sé Éire agus ní fhliuchann sé bonn.    “Leitir.Tomhais orm, tomhais ort, caidé an dealg a chuir Brighid sa bhrat.    “Súithche.Comh h Ard le balla, comh milis le mil, comh bán le bainne, comh dearg le fuil.   “Ubhla.”Tarann sé isteach ar dhruim na ndaoiní agus téigheann sé amach go mín le síoda.   “Móin.”Bíonn sé amuig agus bíonn sé astoigh agus dhá céad suil air.   “Rideal.”Ceathrar na rith, ceathrar ar crith, beirt ag déanamh eolais agus seoidín ar deireadh.    “Bó.”



A Íosa dean trocaire orm.Go ngrádhuighthear  croidhe naomhtha Íosa an gach áitA Íosa atá ceannsa agus umhal ar gcroidhe dean mo croidhe sa cosamhail le dó chroidhe sa.A Íosa mo Dhia, grádhaim tú ós cionn gach uile nídh.A chroidhe ró mhilis Íosa iompuighim ort, leig damh tú a ghrádhughadh níos mó agus níos mó.Ó mo Thighearna agus mo Dhia.

4428384/4402641/4512613.title: Máirín Baibín
4428384/4402641/4512613.text:
(continued from previous page)
agus chuir sí ná ribíní ar an triúr aca fhéin. D'éirigh an fathach go luath ar maidín agus mharbhuigh sé a thrí n-inghin fhéin, mar shíl sé gur an triúr eile a bhí ann. D'éirigh Máire annsin agus d'imthigh sí fhéin agus a dhá deirbhshiúr leo. "Tá tú thall annsin a Mháire Baibín" arsa an fathach.  "Tá go díreach" arsa Máire Baibín. "Mharbh tú mó thrí n-ingheanach" arsa fathach léithe. " Ní mharbhuigh" arsa Máire "ach mharbhuigh tú fhéin iad a ghaduidhe cáidheach."



Oidhche na Marbh1. Bá eadh an gnás a bhí ag ná sean daoiní fadó, teinidh mhór a chur síos, an t-urlár a scuabadh agus pota bruightín a fhágail cois na teineadh agus spúnóg a shathadh ann, fá choinne na mairbh. Ar maidín lá thar ná bhárach ag éirigh dobhtha bhíodh an pota folamh.2. Bhíodh gnás eile acu fad ó shoin fosta. Gach Oidhche Shamhna rachadh cailín óg as gach teach amach go gáradh an cháil. Bhéarfadh siad leobhtha cúpla ceirtlinn isteach an toighe. Chrochadh siad anuas as na creataí iad. Cé bith an chead fhear a thiocfadh isteach an toighe an oidhche sin, sin an fear a bheadh aicí lé pósadh.3. Gach Oidhche Fhéil Eoin fad ó shoin bá ghnáth leis na sean-daoiní teinidh mhór a chur amach in onóir Eoin Baiste. Bhéadh siad uilig cruinnighthe thart ar an teinidh ag Urnaighe. Nuair a bhéadh siad ag imtheacht ná bhaile, bhéarfadh duine as gach teach leis smután dearg amach as an teinidh. Rachadh sé thart ar a chuid talamh uilig leis, D'eurfaidhe annsin go raibh an talamh sin Beannaighthe.



1.	Bhí mé ag siubhal ar thalamh Beannuigh, thárla damh an Mhaighdean Bheannuigh, seacht leabhar  urnaighe ina lámh, seacht gcoinnle lasta ar achan taobh, seacht sagart a léigheamh, seacht gclog (?)a bualadh, Geaftaidhe ná bhFlaitheas a bhfoscladh, agus dorsacha Ifrinn a dhruid.2.	Gcluinnsibh mise a lucht na Scaball, ná déanaigidh faillighe in bhur gcás. Is mairg a bios gan caraid ná luighe ar leabaidh an bháis. A dhuine bhocht gan chéill ná dean bréag lé
(continues on next page)

4428384/4402762/4512625.title: Urnaithe
4428384/4402762/4512625.text:
UrnaightheLuighim ar mo láimh dheas agus codlam ar mo láimh chlí, diúltuighim d'ón ainspiorad, gabham leis an naomh. Mó láimh dheas ar Dhia, láimh Dé go raibh liom. Beannacht Dé go raibh liom go maidín.Ceithre cóirneal ar mó leabaidh, ceithre haingle go raibh annsin, Dia go raibh amuigh, Dia go raibh astoigh(?), Dia go raibh amuigh. Dia go raibh fá dtaobh d'en teach seo go maidín.



Bairille ar an tráigh agus a dhá cheann druidte.   (uibh)Chuartaigh mé go bhfuair mé, agus nuair a fuair mé chaith mé ar shiubhal mé, agus nuair nach bhfuair(?) mé é, thug mé liom ná bhaile é.  (dealg in dó chois)Chuaidh sé thart ar an teach, agus isteach i bpoll na h-eochrach.  (gaoth)Tcím é, is ní fheicim é, tcím ar chnoc na h-aiteanaighe é, siubhlann sé an bán agus ní imthigheann sé gan cuideachta.   (bás.)Siúd thart ar an teach é, agus an dreibhlín ina diaidh.   (chearc agus ná h-éanacha)Go h-árd lé balla, go milis lé mil, go bán lé bainne agus go dearg lé fuil.   (ubhla.)Tá sé amuigh, tá sé istoigh, tá sé ina shuidhe sa chlúduigh agus dhá chéad súl air.   (reidil.)Chuaidh mé amach idir dhá chnoc, agus isteach eadar dhá uisce.   (bean agus gabha uisce léithe.)Chuaidh mé suas air, tháinig mé anuas air, agus thug mé liom ar mó dhruim é.  (dréimire)Chuaidh mé isteach i siopa lé dhá phinghinn, caidé an rud ba éadtroma bheadh amach liom.   (stampa)Chaith mé rud geal suas ins an aer, agus tháinig sé anuas buidhe.   (uibh.)Dá gcaillfinn sá leath choróin agus í fhághail, caidé dhéanfainn nuair a gheobhainn í.   (stad a cuartughadh)Rug cearc go leith, ubh go leith ina lá go leith, cé mhéid lá ghlacadh sé cearc amháin sé uibhe a rugadh,  (?)Corcán óir lán de fheoil bheo.   (méaracán)Tháinig sé isteach ar dhroim na ndaoine agus chuaidh sé amach chomh mín lé síoda.   (móin.)Bog, bog idir dhá bhog, bog thusa bog aca, agus bogaidh an dhá bhog.   (asal is péire feadhnógaí)Má chumhduigheann crúb elephant leath acra tallamh, caidé chumhdóchadh an ruball   (tóin)
(continues on next page)

4428401/4404989/4513047.title: Urnaithe
4428401/4404989/4513047.text:
UrnaigheathaEirighim suas le Dia go n-éirighidh Dia liom. Láimh Dé in mo thimpeall ag suidhe agus  ag luighe agus ag éirighe damhBrian Ó Curáin, a fuair an (sgéál) urnaigh seo ó shean Maghnuis Ó Curáin, Glaisecú, Mínlarrach, Tír Chonaill



urnaigheathaBhí Muire agus a mhac ag siubhal amuigh sa lá casadh oirthi pearsa beannuighthe. Shín sí Dó i na dheis láimh sgaball deas na mbrainsí óir Níl a' nduine oimtharas ináirde beannuighth eiomchur mar is cóir na bhfuil séala ar a anam ins an ghlóir.A Mhaighdean an gceileabhair agus a ardríogh na Glóire is leat a ghuidhe mo chasnaidh maidín is tráthnóna.Seachann mé ó pheacaidh agus cuir mé ar an eolas go poball na h-aithrighthe an áit na deora.
(continues on next page)

4428401/4404991/4513057.title: Na Deich nAithne
4428401/4404991/4513057.text: Na Deich nAithne91) Is mise an Tighearna do Dhia dá dtabharar grádh(2) Ainm an Tighearna do Dhia na tabhair gan  fath.(3)Cuimhnigh an Saoire do Naomtha mar is coir(4) Do athair agus do de mhathair módh agus  onóir tabhair(5) Ná deán druis nó gaoin(5) Na deán marbh seachann fuach agus fearg(6) Na deán drúis na gaoin na geatha garg(7) Ná deán goid nó éagcóir ar aon (8) Ná tabhair in dhiaidh do chomharsan fiadhnaise cham(9) Ná sanntuigh bean do chmharsan le do lá(10) Agus a cuid na buighinn ná sanntuigh fós go deo.

4428402/4404748/4514477.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404748/4514477.text:
PaidreachaFáilte romhat a Mhuire Mhór, Mháthair Íosa, réalt na maidhne, sgiath na mbocht agus do anam thárat Is tú thug aráis an bád do thuig Gheibheas mór an ngrásta dhuit.Tabhairigh dúinne síothchán Dé, sgaoil na glais a cheanglas mé. Greim de'n bhochtaibh, dalladh siiúil, Mháthair Mhuirneach ar thí na n-uball. Saor sin fríd céim do Mhic ar olc agus ar fheadhas fríd Éirinn. Moltar faoi do choimridh gan mhuigheadh, an t-Atháir, mac, agus an Spiorad Naomh.Eibhlín Ní Ghallchobhair, Caiuseal - na -gCorr a thug an urnaighe seo domh.



Gheall phaidir bheannuigh car chodail tú aréir? Chodail mé san leabaidh an áit ar chodail Mac Dé.Ca gcodhlochaidh tú anocht? Fa Íosa Chríost. Caidé sin romhat? Tá n-a aingle. Agus caidé sin do dhiaidh? Tá n-a h-Easpail. Caidé sin in do láimh dheis? Tá uisge coisreachta a chur Muire liom a chuirfeadh ar an eolas go toighe an Phápa mé. La é gu liom an dabhach udaidh thall a bhfuil an choinneal gheal lásta i n-a lár, Brighid fa n-a brat, Muire fa n-a Mac, agus dhá l,aimh Dé fa mo mhuinneal.
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404749/4514480.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404749/4514480.text:
an urnaighe seo damh fosta.Maighdean Mhuire is gille do'n ghréin, Mháthair Íosa gille gan smáll.Coinnéall Íosa Flaithis DeGo mbéidh Íosa liom ar uair mo bháis.Maighdean Mhuire agus a Mháthair Dé , bhfuil fuasglughadh na cruinne ar do láimh go bárr. Amuigh ar dá leanbh a d'fhulaing a pháis go  géar, a Mhaighdean Mhuire a Mháthair Dé, bhfuil fuasglughadh na cruinne ar do láimh go bárr.



(continued from previous page)
Luighim sa ar mo leabaidh-se mar shíntear mé san uaigh. Seo an fhaoisdín chruaidh ghlan a ghnídhim-se le Mac De. fa eochairí mo cholna, agus fa olcas mo chroidhe. O, a Dhia is iomdha rud a geallaimíd is nach ndéan muid. Mhaighdeán Mhuire suidh ag mo cheann. Naomh Eoghan Báiste, na naomh easpail suidhe ag mo bhonn. A theachtairí dhílse n-éideadh Chríost, bí agam i n-am, go gcuiridh tú séala Chríosta ar mo anam dhílis a cheannuigh Iosa ar an chrann.

4428402/4404750/4514483.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404750/4514483.text:
Ar ghabhail a luighe ar mo leabaidh domh. I gabhail i mbáis coladhta dom. O Dhia bheirim m-anám duit ar do aon Mac.Coinnigh anois é, coinnigh aráist é.Ó Íosa coinnigh a choidhche é. ceithre cóirneal ar  mo leabaidh, ceithre aingle go rabh fa dtaobh de. Dia go rabh amuigh, agus Dia go rabh astoigh Dia agus Críost go rabh fa'n teach, agus ma thig a dhath orainn agus muid ar gcodladh, is í an Mhaighdean Mhuire a mhusglochas muid. Dia Mhuire fa nar ndruim, dídeann fa nar dhá bhonn, idir Bríghid agus a brat. Muire agus a Mac agus Micheal Pháis Dé Dhá láimh Dé fa nar n-anam an lá deireannach.Sorcha Ní Ghallchobhair, Caiseal -na-gCorr, Gort-a-Choirce



Éideadh a fuair mé o Mhuire  peacach bocht mé. Ní fiú mé a glacadh muna rabh Críost agam ar uair mo bháis.Gcluin sibh mé locht na scabal na déanaidh failighe in bhur gcás.Is truaighe sin fear i bhfad o na caraid agus é 'na luigh ar leabaidh an bháis. A dhuine bhocht gan céil na dean bréagh le Muire na h-ith
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404750/4514484.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404750/4514484.text:
Ar ghabhail a luighe ar mo leabaidh domh. I gabhail i mbáis coladhta dom. O Dhia bheirim m-anám duit ar do aon Mac.Coinnigh anois é, coinnigh aráist é.Ó Íosa coinnigh a choidhche é. ceithre cóirneal ar  mo leabaidh, ceithre aingle go rabh fa dtaobh de. Dia go rabh amuigh, agus Dia go rabh astoigh Dia agus Críost go rabh fa'n teach, agus ma thig a dhath orainn agus muid ar gcodladh, is í an Mhaighdean Mhuire a mhusglochas muid. Dia Mhuire fa nar ndruim, dídeann fa nar dhá bhonn, idir Bríghid agus a brat. Muire agus a Mac agus Micheal Pháis Dé Dhá láimh Dé fa nar n-anam an lá deireannach.Sorcha Ní Ghallchobhair, Caiseal -na-gCorr, Gort-a-Choirce



Éideadh a fuair mé o Mhuire  peacach bocht mé. Ní fiú mé a glacadh muna rabh Críost agam ar uair mo bháis.Gcluin sibh mé locht na scabal na déanaidh failighe in bhur gcás.Is truaighe sin fear i bhfad o na caraid agus é 'na luigh ar leabaidh an bháis. A dhuine bhocht gan céil na dean bréagh le Muire na h-ith
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404753/4514496.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404753/4514496.text:
(continued from previous page)
Ceithre coirneail in mo leabaidh, ceithre h-aingle go rabh amuigh agus Dia go rabh istoigh. Dia agus Críost go rabh fá dtaobh dúinn go dtí an t-am seo imbarach. Ma thig dadaid orm Dia mór musgail mé. Muire aingle congbuigh mé. Dia tabhair anois damh é. Tabhair go bráth siorruidhe damh é.Brigid fá na mbrat. Micheal fa na cheann dhá láimh Dé go rabh thara m-anam an la deireannach.



Beannuigh  inne a Dhia ar mbiaidh agus ar ndeoch. is tú cheannuigh sinn go daor agus shaothruigh sinn thar eile olc. Cúig arán agus an dá iasg ar na cúig mhíle do rann Dia. Reath an rí roinn an roinnt go dtigidh ar gcuid agus ar gcomhrainn. Go mbeannuighidh Dia ar gcuid agus ar gcuideachta.Chonnaic mise an Mhaighdhean Bheannuighthe  agus í ag siubhal ar thalamh beannuighthe, Bhí trí leabhar Aifrinn leithí agus trí sagairt ag gabhail a cheóil. seacht gclog da mbuaileadh
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404754/4514506.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404754/4514506.text:
(continued from previous page)
Le geaftaí na bhFlaitheas a fhoscgladh agus le geaftaí ifrinn a dhruid. Is maith an éis slighe a mhathair.(Níl fear na bean  deirfeadh í seo agus a ráit trí h-uaire achan lá nach bhfuil do an ghlór shiorruidhe agus nach bhfuil do go brath ifreann.)Seo í an  leabhaidh ar sínfear mise. Seo í an uaigh ar sínfear mise. Ceithre coirneail go rabh ar mo leabaidh.ceithre aingle go rabh ann mo leabaidh. Dia go rabh  amuigh,Dia go rabh istiugh. Mhaighdhean Mhuire musgail me ma thig droch rud ar bith orm.



Éideadh a fuair mé ó mhathair ÍosaIs peacach mé ní fiú mé a fhaghailGuidhim-se Muire agus a h-aon Mhac Íosa go raibh sibh agam ar uair mó bháis.An gcluin sibh mise lucht na sgaball na déanaidh faillghe in bhur gcásIs mór an truaighe fear gan carad agus é ina luighe ar leabaidh an bhais.A dhaoine bhocht gan cheill na deán  bréag le Muire, na h-ith feoil Dia h-Aoine no cor Ceadaoin fríd an bhliadhain
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404756/4514516.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404756/4514516.text:
(continued from previous page)
shúil le Dia go rachfadh an urnaighe seo i sochair do m'anam agus do mó chorp agus go spéisealta do mó anam le n-uair na n-grást goh rabh  fuadail mó bháis agam.Cuirfidh mé mé fhéin ann d'fiadhnaise a mhic Dé agus iarrfaidh mé cuiduighadh ón Spiorad Naomh Ó a Spiorad Naomh guidhim thú theacht agus seilbh iomlán a glacadh ar mo croidhe, mó coinsias a ghlanadh ón uile smal pheacaidh, grásta  a thabhairt damh, a bheith siothcanna carthannach le mó chomarsann tríd Iosa Críost ar dtighearna Amen.



Failte romhatsa a Mhuire mhathair a realt na maidhne sgein amach adhbhar mhór na ngrasta.Is tú thog a  dom do shaothruigh Tamhuigh dúinn siothchan De sgaoil na glais a cheanglas sinn. Tabhair greim do'n dall bhocht.Mhathair muirneach rí na suilce, Athair na h-eaglaise ins na h-umhlaidheachta, is tú an t-ein do Mhic go moltar thú faoí do
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404758/4514520.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404758/4514520.text:
(continued from previous page)
sge, gur imthigh an t-athair agus an mhac agus an spiorad naomh.Beannuighim sa de seapal De,Beannuigheann seapal De damhse,Adhraidim ar mo ghluin dheis,Claoinim ar mo ghluin chléde bhrig go sabhaileochaidh Rí luineas[?] de m'anamsa ar leic na Pianna agus gach anam a thiocfas agus mo dhiaidh.



Fáilte duit a Mhuire mhór,A Mhaighdean síor nacht gan cabhairmathair Íosa réalt an maidhne,Mo sgéal im bhocht mo anam tharatIs tú thug ar ais bláth do ceiltmar bhí Dia mhór na ngrásta duit"Health" do thamuigh bíadh ar sinn Bí anois ag ar an-abha linnTamhuigh dúinne siothchan Dé,Sgaoil na glais a cheanglas méfa ghreim do bhocht in dalim thú
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404759/4514522.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404759/4514522.text:
(continued from previous page)
Mathair mhuirneach faoi na n-úirAthair na suailce agus air gan luchtAthair na h-Eaglaise agus an umhlaidheachtFríd féin a mhíc, réalt na maidneIs fearr DiaTáthair sinn o thaobh na bpianGo moltar thú gach áit sa domhanAn t-athair san mac san Spiarad Naomh



Luighim ann mo leabhaidh mar luighim ins an uaigh, ag iarraidh toradh agus brigh na Sacrámaint, os Mhuire agus grádh Dé. Gábhaim le Muire m'athair agus gábhaim le Righ flaitheas Dé ar mo anam bocht.



An urnaigh a dubhairt an Mhaidean Mhuire le na h-aon mhac Iosa nuair a bhí sé ag fághail báise ar chrann na chroiche
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404760/4514539.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404760/4514539.text:
Dubhairt sí "Aon Mhac throcaire agus gnásta spás a thabhairt dúinn ar an  t-saoghal seo cum go ndéanfamuid  siothcán le dia agus leis an chomhursain.
(continues on next page)



(continued from previous page)
Luigim ar an leabaidh seo mar shínfear mé san uaigh.Ceithre cóirneáil ar mo leabaidh ceithre h-aingle ar achan  cóirneál. Dia amuigh agus Dia astigh agus Dia go rabh fa dtaoibh damh go maidín.Fuair mé an urnaigh sin ó Bhean ins an  chomhursain Máire Ní Shidheail.Luigim ar an leabaidh seo le h-Íosa Críost. A anal go rabh fa dtaoibh damh ar an  smeach déireannach, agus go mbéidh mé leis go síorruidhe, Amen.Ó a Íosa dean trócaire ar na h-anamnacha atá a' dogadh i dteine purgatóir. Ní thig leo cuideadh leo fhéin indiu agus tá siad ag iarraid cuideadh orainne.Ó a Íosa cuid leis na h-anamnacha bochta agus tabhair áit mhaith ins na flaitheas daobhtha, Amen.Fuair mé an dá urnaighe seo ó Mháire Ní

4428402/4404761/4514544.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404761/4514544.text:
(continued from previous page)
Shidheail fosta.A Íosa as Nasureth Rí na nIudach sabhail mé ar bhás thobann neamh mhullaigh.Fuair mé í seo o mó mháthair.



Muire agus a Mac ag siubhail amuigh sa ló. Tharlaigh ortha Siomon beannuighthe, pasaid beannuighthe is a ró.Tarraingt sé amach an Abaid bheannuigh seo. Níl aon duine da n-iomchrochadh an Abáid bheannuigh seo na mbéidh sealla agam-sa air a annam ins na  glóir. Íora luthmhar is tú mo stór mo chur ar an éolas go Pobal na h-Áirighthe an áit a silltear na deóra.



Aduighim creideamh Dé go fíor, Siór le grádh mo croide is dochas fíor .Ó chois na croise guidhim suas, A Thighearna Íosa guidhe anuas.
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404761/4514546.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404761/4514546.text:
(continued from previous page)
Shidheail fosta.A Íosa as Nasureth Rí na nIudach sabhail mé ar bhás thobann neamh mhullaigh.Fuair mé í seo o mó mháthair.



Muire agus a Mac ag siubhail amuigh sa ló. Tharlaigh ortha Siomon beannuighthe, pasaid beannuighthe is a ró.Tarraingt sé amach an Abaid bheannuigh seo. Níl aon duine da n-iomchrochadh an Abáid bheannuigh seo na mbéidh sealla agam-sa air a annam ins na  glóir. Íora luthmhar is tú mo stór mo chur ar an éolas go Pobal na h-Áirighthe an áit a silltear na deóra.



Aduighim creideamh Dé go fíor, Siór le grádh mo croide is dochas fíor .Ó chois na croise guidhim suas, A Thighearna Íosa guidhe anuas.
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404762/4514551.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404762/4514551.text:
(continued from previous page)
Thug an urnaigh seo damh.A Aingeal Dé a chuir Dia ann a naomhtrócaire le bheith mar dhídeantoir agam, soillsigh agus cosain mé ,treoruigh agus riaghluigh mé. Amén



Na Brighid Bheannuighthe fuair mé Muire peacach mé naomh nó fa agam-sa naomh Muire Dé bheith agam ar uair mó báis, Ó a dhuine bhocht gan céill na h-ith féoil na ceadaoin-na eágcaoin do'n tinneas-sóllaidh do'n chré na feice[?] a Mhuire, ach déan do fhaoiside le le Mac Dé is béidh tú ag feasta ag cas na n-aingeal. Níl aon duine n-iomrócaidh amach brighid bheannuighthe agus a h-iomchair [?] mar is cóir nach mbéidh a anam ins
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404763/4514560.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404763/4514560.text:
(continued from previous page)
an ghlór. As a mháthar na gile 'gus a mháthar na glóire-is leat a guidhim=sé mó chasoide maidin as tráthnóna. Is tú an realt éolais gabhail romham ins na bealaighe ahgus a chuireas an dóigh ar an  pheacach.



A Mháthair Pheadair ce'n áit ar chodhluigh tú aréir? Chodhluigh mé ar neamh an áit ar chodhluigh Mac Dé. Cá gcodhlochaidh tú anocht?Fá chosa Chríost. Goidé sin romhat? Na h-aingle. Goidé sin do dhiaidh? Na h-easbuig.Goidé sin leat in dó lámh? Soitheach uisge choisreactha a chuir Iosa liom le h-ól ar leabaidh an bháis.Brighid fa na mbrat, agus Muire fá na Mac, Mícheal geal fá na ceann-dhá lámh Dheis Dé go rabh fá dtaoibh damh go maidin.Fuair mé an urnaigh seo fosta ó Bhrighid Ní earcáin, fana-bhuidhe, Gort-a-choirceIs mé an  creatúr bocht fé ualach throm, ar úr mó pheacaidh is aireach liom. Ach admhuighim creideamh Dé go
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404764/4514562.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404764/4514562.text:
(continued from previous page)
síor, seo grádh mó chroidhe le dochas fíorA chois na Croidhe guidhim suas, fríd Iosa air dTighearna guidhim anuas



Luigim ar mo láimh dheis, codhlamh ar mo láimh chlé, Dúiltigham don ain-spiorad, geillstimid don  spiorad naomh, mo lámh dheis le Dia, agus lámh dheis Dé liom,  na luigim se le holc, agus na luigheadh olc liom.Luigim le Dia, luigheadh Dia liom, Muire agus a mac, Brighid agus a breatóg, Seán faoi mo sgiathaín, dhá lamh De, agus dhá láimh Mhuire, go rabh fa dtaoibh de mo Anam, agus de mo chulainn go maidiín.
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404765/4514580.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404765/4514580.text:
(continued from previous page)
Mhaighdean Muire is gile do'n ghrian.máthair Íosa is gile gan smálCoinneál Mhuire flaitheas Dé.Go rabh Iosta ag mo anam ar uair mo bhais.



Mhaighdean Bheannuighthe níos gile no an ghrianMathair Dé nach dearn smál,Coinneal Mhuire na bhFaitheas DeGo rabh ag m'anam ar úair mo bhais.Codhlaidh sin ort a mhathair ní h-eadh a mhic Éisle, Cé'n eis slighe go bhfuilfear mo strócadh agus le mo spolladh agus le mo cheasadh ar mhullaigh na n-árd le tal, le cúig ropa caola cruaidhe, coran spíonadh ag gabhail ar mo cheann mo chuid fola uaisle ag éirigh in airde agus ag tuitim aráis ar cuid  lacacha na sráide.
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404767/4514591.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404767/4514591.text:
(continued from previous page)
is duitse a bhéirim mo chasaid maidín agus tráthnóna le me a shabhail ar an  peacadh agus a chur ar an eolas go pobal na h-airighthe an áit a siltear na ndéor.



Ó a mhaighdean a mháthair Mhuire agus a Mháthair Dé, bhfuil fuasgladh na cruinne ar do lámh go léir. Iompuigheann ar do leanbh a d'fuiling páis go gé. Ó a Mhaigdean Mhuire agus máthair De 'go bhfuil fuasgladh na cruinne ar do lám go léir.Is mé an creatúr lag faoi ualach trom. Ar mhéid mo pheacadh is aireach liom. Aduigim creideamh De go síor, Grádh mo chroidhe agus dochas fíor. Ó chois na croise glaoidim  suas, a Thighearna Iosa glaoidim anuas.
(continues on next page)

4428395/4403915/4514611.title: Urnaí eile
4428395/4403915/4514611.text:
urnaighe eileFáilte rómhat a Rí an DómhnaighFáilte rómhat a Rí na hóige gile,Fáilte roimh na trí haingle is sinne agus is óige 's na flaithis.Gurab iad a  ghárda ar mó anam ar uair mó bháis agus 'mo chruaidh chás.



Urnaighe a deirtear ag coigilt na teineadhCoiglim an teinidh seo mar choiglim crannNaomh Pádraic (mar deantar N. Pádraic)Bríghid ag a bun agus Máire ag a bárrAn dá easbal déag atá i bflaitheas na naomhFágam-sa cúram an tighe seo agus a bhfuil ann go la.leagan EileCoiglim-sa an teine seo mar choigleas cách,Brighid fá na bun agus Máire fá na bárr.Na naoi n aingle  ar fhichid atá i gcathair na ngrásGo raibh fá'n tigh seo a's na daoine go lá.

4428395/4403919/4514623.title: Urnaí
4428395/4403919/4514623.text:
(continued from previous page)
pheacaidh go h-uile tríd luaigheacht do pháise, go dtabharfaidh tú grásta damh le dul ar aghaidh in do sheirbhis go dtí deireadh mo shaoghail, agus go mbéidh mé ag feuchaint ort-féin, aghaidh ar aghaidh le do ghrádhadh agus a mholadh le saoghal na saoghal i ríoghacht flaitheamhnais.Ó a Dhia de bhrugh go bhfuil tú maith agus geanamhail as cuimse, grádhuighim tú le mo chroidhe go h iomlám os cionn gach uile nidh, agus grádhuighim mo chomarsa mar mé féin.Dá mbiodh mo mían agam badh é mó mhían an saoghal mór a ghrádhuighadh mar is airidhe ort. Ó, Dhia, goidé tá agam le toirbhirt duit? Tairgim suas mo chroidhe agus mo anam duit, m'urnuighe agus grádh mo chroidhe go h-iomlán. Amén, Íosa.



UrnaigheÍosa ró-naomhtha m'fhuasgailteóir agus mo shlánuightheóir, ofrailim suas dó do mhordhacht naomhtha an urnaighe thrócaireach seo. Ofrailim suas í i gcuimhne gcúig chréachtha mo shlánuightheora, i gcuimhne a chuid fola agus feola fíor-uasal a strócadh le sgiúrsal, Ofrailim suas í i n-onóir do'n ioncholnughadh a mbroinn gheanamhail na Maighdeana glóramhail
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404784/4514642.title: Seanphaidreacha
4428402/4404784/4514642.text: Sean PhaidreachaFailte romhat a Mhuiire Mhór, Mathair Íosa, realt na maidhne, sgiath na mbocht gus do'n anam tharat. Is tú thug arais an badh do thuit. Gheibheas mór na ngreasta dhuit Tabhairigh dhuinne siothan Dé, sgaoil na glais a cheanglas mé. greim de'n bhochtaibh, dalladh súil, mhathair Mhuirneacha ar tí na n-ubhall Saor sinn fríd ceim do Mhic ar olc agus ar fheabhas fríd Éirinn Moltar faoi do coimhridh gan mhuigheadh, an t-Athair, mac agus an Spiorad Naomh.Gheall phaidir beannuigh car chodail thú aréir? Chodail mé ins an leabhaidh an áit ar chodail Mac Dé. Ca gcodlocaidh tú anocht? fa chosa Chríost. Céide sin romhat. tá na h-aingle.Agus caide sin do dhiaidh. Tá na h-Easbail. Cáide sin in do lamh dheis? Tá uisge coisreachta a chur Muire liom a chuirfeadh ar an eolas go tighe papa mé. Is é gil liom an dabhach udaí thall a bhfuil an coinneal gheall losta i n-a lár. brigidh fa n-a brat, Muire

4493630/4405589/4514813.title: Na Paidreacha
4493630/4405589/4514813.text:
Seanmóir na n-Aithreach NaomhthaIs ar an bhás is mian liom saointiú'Sé an cáim atá doiligh shaorú,'t-Iseal agus a t-uasal, 't-óg agus a'seanlag agus a' láidreacht, is leis a chlaoidhtear;'gCualaidh sibh seanmóir na n-aithreach naomhtha?
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404856/4514820.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404856/4514820.text:

Urnaigh an SgabailAn gcluin sibh mise lucht na sgabalna deánaigidh faillghe in mo chás, na truaigh sin fear gan caraid 'na luighe ar leabaidh an bháis. dhuine bhocht gan chéill, na h-ith feoil Dia ceadaoin gus na h-éigin do a thinneas. Bí umhal do'n chleir agus do na cúig feilte Muire ma tá ar Céasta ag Mach Dé agus ar féastaí ag na leanbhaí.Bhí Muire agus a mhac ag
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404856/4514831.text:

Urnaigh an SgabailAn gcluin sibh mise lucht na sgabalna deánaigidh faillghe in mo chás, na truaigh sin fear gan caraid 'na luighe ar leabaidh an bháis. dhuine bhocht gan chéill, na h-ith feoil Dia ceadaoin gus na h-éigin do a thinneas. Bí umhal do'n chleir agus do na cúig feilte Muire ma tá ar Céasta ag Mach Dé agus ar féastaí ag na leanbhaí.Bhí Muire agus a mhac ag
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404857/4514832.title: Urnaí an Scabaill
4428402/4404857/4514832.text:
(continued from previous page)
siubhal amuigh ins an lá Casadh dobhtha Siómon beannuighthe agus Peadar as a róim Shín an Mhaigdean Muire a deis lámh sgabhal breágh na mbrainnsí oír, Níl aon nduine a iomprochas mo sgabal-sa agus a iomprochas mar is cóir, na mbéidh séala ar a anam ins  an ghlóir. Bhainriogain na gile, agus a bhainrioghain na glóire  an áit a gníomh-sa mo chasaidh maidín as trathnóna pobal na h-aithrighe agus an  áit a siltear na ndeór.



Naomh Mhuire guidhe mé fhéin leat, aingeal Dé bíos mo choimead, na sgar liom soilisigh mé cuidigh mé anois, agus ar uair mo bháis amen.         Máire Ní Shearcaigh (aois 65 bl)Luigim ar an leabhaidh seo mar shínidh mé ins an uaigh. Ag iarraidh, agus  brígh na sacramainte beannuighthe. As riocht Mhuire, agus grádh Dé Ghabh le Dia mar athair agam. Gabh le Muire mar mhathair agam agus gabham leis an athair Síorruidhe. Amen

4493628/4405178/4514863.title: Paidir Aithrí

"Ag dul na luighe"Luighim leat a Dhia. Is go luighe thú Dhia liom.Éirighim leat a Mhuire. Is go n-éirighe Mhuir liom.Céithre coirneál ar mo leabaidh.Céithre h-eang lán áit sín.Dia amuigh, Is Dia istoigh.Mhaighdéan na Mhuire sgairt orm.Má thigadhach orm is mé mo chodladh muscail mé.Maighdean a Mhuire béidh romhain sa phortach Is na léig m'anam bocht thart.Ag Dul na LuigheLuigh im le Dhia.Is luigheann Dhia liom.Lámh Dhia chumailtNa suidhe is na luighe is ag eirigh damhDan a BhaisToisigheann an bás ag bun dó choise,Is gearann leis do shaoghal go teann.Cuirtear duine fa choinne an t-Sagairt.Ach deirtear leis go bhfuil sé mall.Níor cúr tú'n faoisaoide leith do pheacaidh.
(continues on next page)

the graveyard. Doe Castle and Ray Castle were places for hanging people  long ago.



Long ago when people went into a house they would not say Good - night but "God Bless all here" and when they were leaving again they would say "May God and Mary bless you all. If they saw anyone doing any work they would say God Bless the work.



When the old people would (say) sneeze they used to say a short prayer such as, "Dia is Muire liom. After lighting the lamp they used say "Buideachas don Righ sá choinne an t-solais.
(continues on next page)

leaves the animal in a yard for the dealer.A pig market is held every week for people who have fully grown pigs to sell. Very often the halter is given with young fillies. The May fair and Lammas fair are the two biggest fairs of the year. Cows, horses and pigs are sold at mostly every fair. More horses are sold in the Springtime than at any other time of the year.



"God is here; stand [first?] Prayer to be attached to the inner doors of house in order that the [inmates?]

4493632/4405648/4515783.title: Toibreacha Beannaithe
4493632/4405648/4515783.text:
(continued from previous page)
is rarely made now,  except by one or two old people who still keep up the pious practice.From one of these Mary Gallagher of Pollsallagh aged 80 years I got the following directions for making the Turas.



Prayers at Turas.1. Stand on the rock facing the Turas and say Five Paters and Five Aves.2. Go round the Turas three times and say the same prayers.3. Say these prayers facing Tory Island.4. Stand with your back to Turas and say the same prayers.5. Repeat the same kneeling facing Tory Island.6. Then touch any diseased part with the water, and touch it on the blood stains on the stones.7. Say your beads at the old Altar in the hazel bushes.

4493658/4408672/4518894.title: Doon Well
4493658/4408672/4518894.text:
(continued from previous page)
the water on their sores. The people who live beside the well are called Gallagher, and they take care of the well.Some people leave money on a flag at the well, and it is for the Gallaghers.  Around the well there are many old crutches and sticks, left by the people who got cured there, and went away without these.Nobody ever tried to destroy the well.There are no fish in the well.People go to Doon well on St Swithin's day, St Patricks day, and Easter Sunday.They very often go on any week day, but usually on a Saturday or a Sunday.



Prayers.Our Father who art in heaven. Hallowed be thy name. Thy Kingdom come, thy will be done on earth. as it is in Heaven.Give us this day our daily bread, and forgive us our tres - passes, as we forgive them who trespass against us
(continues on next page)

4493663/4409025/4521859.title: A Collection of Prayers
4493663/4409025/4521859.text: O My God I a rise from this bed of sleep to adore and to honour my God to labour for my soul. O may I arise the last day to life everlasting. This Prayer is said when awakening in the morning. O my God clothe my soul with a nupitial robe of Charity.Grant that I may wear them pure and undefiled before thy judgement seat.This prayer is usually said while dressing.Glory, praise, and thanks be to God is a prayer I have often heard said after meals.

4493665/4409205/4522058.title: A Collection of Prayers
4493665/4409205/4522058.text:
Night PrayerJesus Mary & Joseph I give you my heart and my soul, Jesus Mary and Joseph assist me in my last agonyJesus Mary and Joseph may I breathe forth my soul in peace with you.Amen.Night PrayerO my God my Guardian dear, to whom his love commits me here, ever this day be at my side to light and guard to rule and guide. Amen.Night Prayer.Save us O Lord, working, and watch over us sleeping, that we may rest with Christ. Amen
(continues on next page)

Nuair a tchíonn na daoine an ghealach úr an chéad úr deireann siad:-Tchím an ghealach úr agus tchíonn an ghealach úr (mé) mise beannaith Dé ar an ghealach úr agus beannaith Dé orm-sa.Nuair a bhíonn duine ag imhteacht deireamm siad:-Slán Dé ort agus go gcuirid sé an droch uair thartNuair a bhíonn siad ag ithe na prátaí bruithte deireann siad:-Altughad do Dhia ar son na prátaí breeithte.
(continues on next page)

Beannaich Dé ar an ghealach úr agus beannacht De orm-sa.Nuair a chloiseann na sean daoine an chuach an chéad úr deireann siad:-Tá mé beó ar an bhliadhain seo agus cloisim an chuach agus ta siúl agam go mbáidh mé beó bliadhain eile leis an chuaich a chluinstin.Nuair a bhíonn siad i ag cur síos an teine ar maidín

4493687/4410812/4524700.title: Paidreacha
4493687/4410812/4524700.text:
PaidreachaWhen people are out on a journey if they see anyone working in a field near by they "Good luck to the work".When people are driving animals to a fair if they meet anyone on the road the people they meet say "Good luck to you".I someone goes into a house borrowing milk or butter they say to the people of the house when receiving the loan "may God send you plenty" "May you never want" or "may God bless your cow"When my mother rakes the fire at night she cuts the sign of the cross on the hearth stone and as she does so she says "In the name of the Father and of the Son".When we go into a house we say "God save all here". If the people of the house speak first they say "you are welcome".At Christmas when we meet people
(continues on next page)

4493697/4412008/4525041.title: Seanphaidreacha
4493697/4412008/4525041.text:
(1) Ó a Tighearna Íosa Críost, a thógfas ar shiubhal peacaidh an Dómhain, tré do thrócaire ata eifeachta tabhair párdun damh in mo pheacaidh agus ar ucht do chrois naomhta, sábhail mé indiu ar gach uile olc. Tá mé ag iomchar fa dtaobh dím bonn naomhtha le grádh ort in éadan mo laige féin.I ngut cosamhlacht leis an caomhlacht agus leis an simplidheacht ofrailim suas duit an Iodhbairt seo go hiomlán i gcuimhne ar an Íodhbairt a h-ofraladh ar mo soin ar crann na Croiche. Go rabh an Íodhbairt taitneamhach in do lathair. Moladh go síorruidhe duit. Amén.(2) Sínim mé fhéin ar an leabaidh seo anocht i gcuimhne mar síntear mo corp ins an uaigh. Dheánfidh mé faoisideach le Dia fa eochraidh mo codladh agus olcas mo croidhe mo croidhe. Mathair Críosta agus Athair Íosa go rabh ag mo ceann agus mo chosa. Naom Eóghan baisteach agus a cuid Easpal Peadar agus Pol. Naomh Padraic agus na naomh go heile agus teachtairí díleas Dé no go dtigidh chugam in am go gcuirfidhe an Ola Críost ar mo Anam Dhílis mar céasadh é de crann na phaíse.
(continues on next page)

4493708/4413359/4526301.text: There are four corners on my bed. There are four angels round it spread, Martha, Mark, Luke, and John. God Bless the bed that I lie on. If any evil spirit comes to me. O Blessed Jesus waken me.As I kneel down on my confession Chair. I hope that Jesus will meet me there.And every sin that I forget.O Blessed Jesus wipe it out.God bless Friday and good Friday too.The day Our Lord was crucified.The wicked Jews were standing by,With sharp spears in their hand.Good Saviour, Saint Saviour pity me.And don’t let me die in misery.

4493726/4414374/4528380.title: Prayer
4493726/4414374/4528380.text:
Mother are you sleeping. I am in a dream, I dreamt I saw you hang on nails to the cross, and spochious spear does be in your side, and your gentle blood to spill, Mother shall anyone who says this prayer, by night and by day, shall be free from the dangers and be free from the flames of hell.This prayer is said, by night and by day.



Good Friday's morning after noon, the cruel Jews pierced our Saviour true, with heart and hand, blood to fly, Blessed Mother be standing by, with a heavy heart, mournful cry. Those who say this prayer by night and by day, great danger of mortal sin, or the Gates of hell shall never enter them.This prayer is said by night  and by day



O Mother of Doloures, by the anguish and love, with which, you stood beneath the cross of Jesus, stand by me in my last agony. To your maternal heart, I commend the last hours of my life. Offer these hours to the Eternal Father, in union with the agony of our Dearest Lord. Offer frequently in atonement for
(continues on next page)

4493726/4414375/4528385.title: Prayer
4493726/4414375/4528385.text:
(continued from previous page)
my sins. The Precious Blood of Jesus, which mingled with your tears on Calvery to obtain for me the Grace, to receive Holy communion immediately before my death, and breath for my soul, in the actual presence  of Jesus, in the Blessed Sacrament, and O dearest Mother, when the hour of my death arrives present me as your child to Jesus, say to him in my behalf. Father forgive her, for she knew not what she did, Receive this day into they Kingdom.



This prayer was found in the fifth of Our Lord, and our Saviour Jesus Christ, in the year 1505. It was sent from Pope Gregory  X111, To Emperor Charles of Austria, when he was going to battle for safety.Whoever shall repeat this Prayer, or hear it read, or keep it about them, shall never die a sudden death or shall poison take effect on them, or shall they be over powered in any battle. If it be read over a woman in labour she shall be safetied delivered and glad. When a child is born lay this on her
(continues on next page)

4493726/4414376/4528387.title: Prayer
4493726/4414376/4528387.text:
(continued from previous page)
or his right side and he or her shall not be troubled. With thirty misfortunes if you see a man with fits, lay this prayer on his right side, and he shall rise up and thank you. He who shall write this prayer from house to house shall be blessed from me said the Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ. And they that laugh at it shall suffer.



O Adorable Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ dying on the Gallows tree, of the cross for our sins altogether, O Holy Cross of Christ see how I believe in them, O Holy Cross of Christ stir up in me all good and truth. O Holy Cross of Christ ward off from me all dangerous death and always give me life o sacrified Jesus of Nazerath.Have mercy on me that the enemy may keep off from me now and for ever more. In honour of his Holy Ressurrection and God like Assension to which He like to bring us in the right way to Heaven. True as Jesus was born on Christmas Day in the stable of Bethlehem

4493707/4413092/4528943.title: Prayers
4493707/4413092/4528943.text:
The will of God be done by us,The law of God be kept by usOur evil will controlled by usRepentance timely made by usChrist's Passion understood by usAll sinful deeds be shunned by usOur last end pondered oft by usAnd death be blessed [?] by usWith Angel's music heard by usAnd God's high praises sung by usFor ever & for [?].As I lie down to take my sleepAs I bid God to be my guideIf any evil comes to meGive my eyes to see, [?] hand to blessThe Cross of Christ upon my breastO sweet Jesus lay my soul to restO Queen of the holy rosaryO bless us as we pray
(continues on next page)

4493732/4414909/4529052.title: Paidir le Ráit ag Gabháil ar Aistear
4493732/4414909/4529052.text:
Once upon a time there lived in Gartan a man named Fionn Mac Cumall and he was a giant and there was another giant in Scotland. The giant in Scotland. The giant in Scotland heard how brave the other man was and said that he would go over and fight him. Fionn Mac Cumall heard that he was coming and he went home to ask his wife for a plan. She was a giant and she told him to go into the cradle and to let on that
(continues on next page)

4493761/4417815/4531838.title: Prayers
4493761/4417815/4531838.text: Prayers.1. As I lie down on my right sideI pray to God to be my guide.God of the branch and lady of the flowerGod be with me in my last hour.2. I have 4 corners on my bedI have 4 angels overspread,Matthew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless the bed that I lie on.3. As I lie down this night to sleepTo God I give my soul to keep.Waken now, waken neverTo God I give my soul forever.4. On my right side as I lie hereAs Jesus did on Mary's knee.If any harm comes on meThe Lord of Heaven waken me,That I may have my eyes to seeAnd my right hand to bless me

4493761/4417823/4532333.title: Prayer Beads
4493761/4417823/4532333.text:
In our house here in Linsfort is a pair of prayer beads which were made or in use in the year 1817 or about thirty years before the famine. There are 36 small beads on a cord and 4 big ones. There is a cross on them which is made of wood and the image of our Lord is carved on it. Also is the date 1817 cut out on the back of it. The beads belonged to my great grandfather.



This is a solid log-oak char yet in the house of Owen Kelly, Namfrus, Bunarand. Stools and beds were made of bog oak.



People who walked barefoot used wear sock legs on the legs to keep the legs from b eing scourged. Young boys never wore shoes.

4493771/4418826/4533853.title: Old Prayers
4493771/4418826/4533853.text:
The Almighty God seeing we are uncertain going to bed this night, whether we shall rise from thence, give us the grace never to banish the thoughts of death out of our hearts. That we may not commit mortal sin during this life or even venial with deliberation.The Almight God crucified bless me, O Lord! defend and govern me, and after this short and miserable pilgrimage bring me to everlasting life. God the Father bless me. Jesus Christ defend and keep me, the virtue of the Holy Ghost enlighten and sanctify me, into Thy hands I commend my spirit, Lord Jesus receive my soul.O my good angel, whom God has appointed to be my guardian, enlighten and protect me, direct and govern me this night. Amen.
(continues on next page)

4493771/4418521/4533855.title: Old Prayers
4493771/4418521/4533855.text: Heart of Jesus I adore thee, Heart of Mary I implore, Heart of Joseph pure and just. In these three hearts I put my trust. Jesus be our safeguard, Mary be the tower and may the resurrection of the body be our life everlasting. Amen. Heaven is the branch, Mary is the flower, Lord Jesus in my dying hour I commend my spirit to thee, Lord Jesus receive my soul.
