4602697/4595980/4606743.title: Seanphaidir
4602697/4595980/4606743.text:
Ó a Thíagharna na dTiagharnaA d'fhulaing an PháisA sgaoilteadh lé iarann ó bhaithis go tráchtA fuair tiagharnas na dtiagharnas uilig ar láimhÓ a Día dílis táim a'iarraidh do pháirt.Bhí bean ánn fadó is bhí sí dáll is bhí sí ag casadh shátha uair amháin is goideadh an snátha uaithe is dubhairt sí nuair a d'aithin sé go raibh sé goidtighte uaithe"A Mhuire Mhúirneach a bhain díom mó shúile cé ndeaca sugraidh mo cuid circlíní".Annsin tháinic a hamarc dhi ar an bpoinnte boise.
(continues on next page)

4602671/4594188/4613798.title: Seanphaidreacha
4602671/4594188/4613798.text: Eighrim suas le dia go néighridh dia liom.Láimh Dia im mo thimcheall ag suidhe agusag luighe agus ag eirighe dhom.1.Go raibh ainim Íosa go daingin sgríobhthai lár mo chroídhe-sa2.A Mhuire a mháthair Íosa go raibh ainm Íosaagam agus mise ag Íosa.3.Ceangal grádh go raibh eadtrainn go bráth gan sgaoileadh.

4602671/4594191/4613800.title: Seanphaidir
4602671/4594191/4613800.text: Ofrailimíd suas an páidrín pairteach. I ngáirdin Partháis ag moladh na mathar a bhí agus atá gan locht, A Mic na ngras a d'fhulaing pais. Saor ár n-anam o cuile olc. Amén.

4602671/4594193/4613802.title: Seanfhocla
4602671/4594193/4613802.text:
(continued from previous page)
a bhean Sabha ag an aonach lá le muic. Tháinig ceannochair aige agus d'fhiaruigh sé dhé cé mhéid ar an sabha. Agus dubhairt sé, "Ná bach le Sabha ach ceannuigh an mhuic."



A Mhaighdean ghlórmar a bhfuil mhaiseach gur tú mo stór mo lón agus mo thaisce gur tú an realt eólais ag dul róan ins gach bealach ó ghlainse na ndeórTóg me feasta dean threor, tá'n cóir ar m'anam. Fhill mo láimh asmáll gach peacadh agus ar úair ár mbáis go raibh tú againn.

4602671/4594197/4613804.title: Seanphaidreacha
4602671/4594197/4613804.text:
A Mhaighdean Ghlórmar gúm do choimirc, iarraim impidhe ort a Rígh na ngrás, gach a ndearna mé ariamh i n-aghaidh do thola go maithfidh tú dhomsa ar uair mo báis. Amén.Rígh na h-Aoine sineadh ar an gcrois, d'fhulaing na mílte lot, bronaim m'anam duit anocht go ndibirighidh tu uainn chuile olc, Namhaid anam agus cuirp a bhfuil ag brath orrainnAmén A Thighearna.Go mbeannuighidh Dia dhíbh lucht a sgábal na leigidh faillighe ar bith na gcás. S'mairg atá gán a charad agus é na luighe ar leaba a bháis. A dhuine bhocht gan ciall ná déan bréag le Muire. Na ithi feoil Dia Ceadaoin. S'ná tréig í indothinneas
(continues on next page)

4602671/4594222/4613834.title: Seanphaidreacha
4602671/4594222/4613834.text:
A Mhic Dia bhí Eoin baistighe agus na Naomh idir mé sa trom-luigheAmén.Go luighidh mé lé Dia s' go luighe Dia liomnár luighidh mé leis an t-olc s' nár luighidh an t-olc liom.AménTá ceithre phosta faoi mo leabatá ceithre aingeal orm sgarthamá fagham bás as seo go maidingo Flaitheas Dia go raibh m'anamAmén.Anna máthair Muire.Muire mathair CríostEibhlis máthair Eoin báistígheidir mé agus galra na leaba.Amén.
(continues on next page)

4602671/4594227/4613852.title: Seanphaidir
4602671/4594227/4613852.text:
Amén a Thigearna, a ceannuigh go daór gné ar an gcrainn Dé h Aoine. A raibh do min chorp da gearradh le sgiursibh go deangain. Ar an daor crois dia h aoine dha ceangal chun báis.Guidhim chugat feasta a Righ ghil na bflaitheas feachaint ar m'anam gan a leigean chun fán. Gach ocáid le peachadh fáisteanaighe 'tá in mo croidhe istigh lé fada do sgaoladh is do sgaipeadh 's me 'saothrughadh led ghrádhAmén A ThighearnaA Íosa a mhic Mhuire saor sinn ar an teinedh; na leig sa gcaorán geir sin muid go bráth;De reir mar do tuigim do dlighe-se do briseas, lem smaointibh 's im choirtibh 's nach eachtach pardúnach mo chás.A Mhuire 's a bhruinneall grádhaim tú lé cumainn.
(continues on next page)

4602671/4594234/4613874.title: Seanphaidir
4602671/4594234/4613874.text: Luigim leat a Ríogh Mhic Dé bíodh Eoin baistighe agus na naomh idir mé agus trom-luighe na h-oidhcheA bhanríoghan na n-angeal a bhanríoghan na nglóire níl mo chroidhe cruadh aithrighthe go silidh mé deorá. Sábhailigidh me ó ná peacaidhe agus cuireaigidh mé cun eolas.A Mhaighdean glórmhar buadann gabháil is tú mó stor mó lón agus mo thaisge, is tú mo realt eolais, rún gach bealach is i ngleannta na ndeor is tóg mé feasta.

4602671/4594235/4613877.title: Seanphaidir
4602671/4594235/4613877.text:
"Codladh dhuit a máthair" "ní headh a mhic acht aisling""Cé'n taisling í a mháthair" "go mbéadh tusa go do cheangailt, go do fórsáil, is go do sguirseál, go posta cloch, go mbeadh tú crochta ar an gcránn ceasta, go mbeadh táirngí cruaich dá dtomáint tre do lámha is do chosa"Aon duine íarras é sin trí i luighe is ag eirghí dhó ní fhéicfidhe sé spící ifrinn go bráth



A bhfaca aon duine ariamh uisge ag dul inaghaidh cnuicFreagra: capall ag ól uisge ag tobar



Díol bealla is ag ceannacht mílseán.Bhí cailín beag ag dul chuig an



Díol bealla is ag ceannacht mílseán.Bhí cailín beag ag dul chuig an

4602673/4594311/4614801.title: Aontaí
4602673/4594311/4614801.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Paidreacha.   Go mbeannuighid Dia dhuit a Pheadair gheal. Go mbeannuighid Dia is Muire dhuit fhéin. Cé'r codhladh tú aréir?  In áit a codail Mac Dé. "Cé'r gcodhlóchaidh tú anocht? "In áit a codlóchas na boicht. Cé gcodhlóchaidh tú oidhche amárach? "Faoi cosaí Naomh Pádraig. Cé'r sin romhat. "Tá na h-aingeall. Cé'r sin in do dhiaidh? Ta na h-easpail. Cé'r sin ar do láimh dheas. Tá na naoí ndeór uisge bheannuigthe an Domhnaigh atá ag deanamh t-eolas do Naomh Pádraig. Muire is a mac, Brígid is a brat, Miceál árdaingeal leis a dá sgitheán gheal ag fanacht leis na h-ainmneacha go bhfuigfidh siad bás. Duine ar bith a abróchas an paidir sin ceannsa chuile lá ní thiocfaid a ainm go h-Ifrinn go deo ná go bráth.
(continues on next page)

4606380/4593690/4614854.title: Ar Theacht na Cásca
4606380/4593690/4614854.text:
Ar theacht na Cásca go raibh grásta Dé agat.Ar theacht na Cásca go raibh grádh gach éinne agat.Ar theacht na Cásca go raibh bárr an t-séin agat.Is a chara mo chléibh sin duit mo ghuidhe.Athas na Cásca go raibh agat coidhcheSolus na Cásca go raibh ar do shlighe.Is a Chara mo cléibhe sin duit mo ghuidhe.Is í Cáit Ní Ghoill a d'innis an paidir seo dom. Chuala sí ag a athair é. Rugadh i tuairim's na bliadhna 1900
(continues on next page)



Go dtugaidh Dia slán ó'n ní muin.Agus le mar thug sé slán ó'n ní muinGo dtiubhradh sé slán ó-n-a lá muin.Agus go mb'fearr a béas muid anochtAgus go mba seacht bhfeárr a bhéas muid bliadhain ó anocht.Cuala mé an paidir seo ó Tomhás Seóige, ar Iarairne Arainn  Rugadh é timcheall na bliadhna 1910. Cuala sé ag a mhatháir é.Santa Bairbe i-n- aghaid na toirnighe

A Mhuire Mhuirneach a mhathair DéNa soillse gléigéala atá ins na flaitheas.A choinneal lóchrannach atá i bhflaitheas DéGo raibh tu agam ar uair mo bhais  Amén.



Hata Iarainn ar mo cheann.Lultrach(?) iarainn ar mo chomh.Ceo Mhuire Ceo te CríostaSonas agus séan ar chuile bhéal dá ndéarasAgus ar chuile chluais dá n-eisteas,Agus Amén a Thighearna.

4602676/4594500/4614940.text:
9Sean-Phaidreacha Beannachtai srlGha n-aithris ag Padraic O Ceallachain Cul na Binne, Beal Atha an Fheada a fauair bas 1935 d'aois 88 mb. 13 bliathna o soin o chualas iad uaidh.An schribhnoir: an Br. Angelo.1.  In ainm an athar agus an Mhic agus an Spioraid Naoimh. Amen. Tre eachta comhachta Caisreacain De  'rainn.2.  Going to sleep:Four corners on my bedFour angels and them spreadMark and Michael Luke and JohnGod bless this bed that I lie on.3.  Going to sleep"When I lie on my right-hand sideI give my soul up to God to guide,And if any evil spirit comes,The Blessed Virgin will come and 'waken me.4. 4602699/4596354/4614988.title: An Phaidir Gheal
4602699/4596354/4614988.text:
Cár tú aréir? Fá chosaí mhic Dé. Cá gcodlóchadh tú anocht?Fá chosaí na mbocht.Cé sin romhat? Tá na h-aingle.Cé sin in do dhiaidh? Tá na h-Aspail césin ar do láimh dheis tá braon de uisge an Domhnuigh.Chuir Muire liom ag déanamh an eolaisÓ dhoras go doras go doras Phárrthaís.Eochair Phárrtháis atá mé ag iarraidh atásan dabhac údan tháll a bhfuil fleasgóir ar a ceann agus an coróinsoillseach in a láthair.Tháinig oidhche, tháinig ceó tháinigBríghid le na brat tháinig Míceál lena sgiath brionglán fada brionglángearr an té déarfhas an phaidir ghealceann d'oidhche agus de ló go m'aoibheann dó.



Nuair is mó an deifir seadh is mó an mhoill.
(continues on next page)

4602699/4596356/4614990.title: Paidir le Rá ag Coigilt na Tine
4602699/4596356/4614990.text:
Coiglím an teineadh seo mar a coigleachCríost Cásg Muire na bun agusBrígidh i na bárr na trí Angealsollasmhar atá i bhflaithis na ngrástgo raibh ag clúdach an tighe sé gus a n-aoinne go lá. Améin.



Tá cheithre phosta ar mo leabad aguscheithre Angeal uirthi sgarrtha máfhágaimh bás anoct na ar maidin ibhflaithis Dé go raibh m-anamh.

4602676/4594614/4615112.title: Paidreacha
4602676/4594614/4615112.text: A mhuire a Mháthair an riogDean mo siothtain lé  do mach a gnuis is gile ná a ghrian .Na fulaingh m-anam i bpian i bfadbronnaim m'anam ort. Iosa Criost . Ní iarrfaidh mé é coidhche aris . A  fiadhnuise  ortsa a mhaigdean mhuire  gur chuir mé m'anamh ar láimh do mhich.

4602674/4594343/4615627.title: Seanphaidir
4602674/4594343/4615627.text: A Mhaidin glóreamhail, mhóreamhail, aisgeamhail, is tú mo stór, mo lón agus mo thaiscint.Is tú an réal solus romham gach ród agus ar chnuic na ndeór go mba thú mo charaid.

metadata.Teacher:: An tSr. M. Treasa Ní Bhriain

4602679/4594797/4615644.title: Paidreacha
4602679/4594797/4615644.text:
Coirighim an leabaidh in  Ainm an Athair agus an Mhich agus an Spioraid Naoimh. I n-onorughadh don oidhche a geineadh mé  don oidhche a rugadh mé 's dhon oidhche a  baisteadh mé agus  in onorghadh dhuit a Mhic Dé.'Is deas é do phaidir a Mháthair''O a mhich shil mé nach dtiocfá go lá'Níl aon duine adearfas do Phaidir a mháthair tri huaise  léis  luighe dó nach bfuil na Flaithis le fághail  aige agus ni baoghal dhó droch aisne.Dia dár sábháil is a Mháthair go bfuighimíd bás in Éirinn: A Íosa a aon Mhic. A Athair an Uain a thug ofráil do Dhia, dár gceannacht go cruaidh  bí nár n-éadain bí nár ndiaidh agus bí nár n-aice
(continues on next page)

4613675/4607389/4615688.title: Tobar Naofa
4613675/4607389/4615688.text:
Tá dhá tobair naomhtha thar timcheall na háite seo. Tá ceann i lisín na heilte ar a dtugtar tobar na láithríní agus ceann eile i Saonach. Bhí fear ann uair amháin agus bhí sé ag baint crainn a bhí ag fás in aice an tobar i lisín agus thuit sé isteach ins an tobar. Lá amháin chuaidh bean deirce go dtí an tobar  i Saonach agus nigh sí a cosa ann agus an lá in a díadh sin bhí an tobar imthighthe go dtí páirc eile a bhí in aice leis.



Tá páirce ag m'athair ar a tugtar an Gort beag. Seo é an fáth a glaoidhtear an t-ainm sin air. Tá sé síos le fána agus bíonn uisge ann go minic agus tá an talamh an bog mar gheal ar sin. Tá páirce eile ag bean Uí Coileáin agus ghlaoidhtear Gort buidhe air. Seo é an fáth a ghlaoidhtear an t-ainm sin air mar ní bhíodh aon rud ag fás an ach bláthanna buidhe agus sin é an fáth a thugadar an t-ainm sin air anois.



Coigligheann mé an teine seo in ainm De agus Mhuire.

4602674/4594391/4615728.title: A Collection of Prayers
4602674/4594391/4615728.text: A collection of prayers As I lay down on this bed to sleep, I pray to the lord my soul to take Matthew, Mark Luke and John God bless the bed that I lay on and if I die before I wake I pray to the Lord my soul to keep.

metadata.Teacher:: An tSr. M. Treasa Ní Bhriain

4613675/4607421/4616388.title: Paidir
4613675/4607421/4616388.text:
A Phaidrín Phairteach a bhí i Gairdin Phádrais. Moladh na mna a bhí ariamh gan locht. Aon Mhic Mhuire is athair na n-Grasta gur reidthigh tú an cás ata ar ár anam bocht. Trúst agus caird agus grast ó Dhía agam do cabhair gach lá ata muid ag iarraidh. Is airce mé na h-Airí go neartuig Dia linn agus Cuimligheann muid ár n-anam a Mhuire Bhan Tigearna.



Tá pairc ag m'uncáil agus an t-ainm atha air Gort a Gainimhe agus sé an fath a glaoidheann siad an t-ainm sin air mar tá clais mór gainmhe ann agus is annsin a beathuigeann sé na beithdhig agus tá páirc eile ag Seamús Ó Gloinn agus an t-ainm ata ar Glasí Aird mar tá cnoch mór árd ann.



Is truagh gan mé posta in áit ar tógadh mé riam. Thall ar chois na b-aibhne nú ar an oiléan taobh thair. Is truagh gan mé in mo meidtear nú mo caiptin ar luing nú mo foséir breag gréine ar sliab na mban finn. Phogann i
(continues on next page)

4613675/4607423/4616405.title: Scéal
4613675/4607423/4616405.text:
Bhí fear i gcúairt i dteach. D'fan sé san teach go raibh sé in a mheadhan oidhche. B'fhada le fear a'tíghe bhí sé fanacht ar chúairt aige. Bhí pota fataí ar an dteine agus bhí súil aige le cuid do na fataí a fhághail le n-iththe. Dubhairt fear a'tighe leis go raibh pota fataí ar an teine droch bhruighte broch nighte froch cuirthe síos. Tá an tuisce ag an abhann agus an poca ag an ríogh. Téirigh abhaile anois agus muna bhfuil fataí agat féin dein do ghor leis an ngréin.



Lúb do glúnaibh agus brúgh an talamh cuimhní ar gach nídh a rachas tharad fuair cead ó Dhia do chuid peacadh nochtúghadh dhuit.

4613675/4607457/4616550.title: Seanfhocail
4613675/4607457/4616550.text:
(continued from previous page)
lán dá chuid.20. Is fearr an sláinte ná na tnáithte.21. Ní geallaide gáiridhe a bíonn san áit nach mbíonn an biadh.22. Gach duine ag iarraidh bheith ag tocras ar a cheirtlinn féin.23. Marbh le tae agus marbh gan é.



Nuair a luighim san leabaidh luighim san uaigh faoisdin cruaidh a dhéanamh le Dia. As bólóid iaraimse ort a Dia mór na n-Uile Comach. Agus adhmuigimh duit a slánuightheór Ró-Glórmhar. A Mhuire is a Maighdean ró-comhachtach tabhait dúinn radharch ar na soillse ró-glórmhar. Solas na soillse agus radharch na tríonóide agus grásta na foidhne in aghaidh na heugóra. A Mhuire Beannuighthe mo mhíle gradh tú. Mo liagh leigheas in aghaidh an bháis tú Achtnuighe cuirimse chugatsa a Micil Náomhtha. Is chun na Maighdeana cuaidh a túnlach an Aon Mhic. An t-athair Uile comachtach do bíodh ár n-éisteacht. Agus a Muire beannuighthe nár leagair uait féin sin. Go n-éistear lén ár bpeacaí is ár n-aithridhe le chéile. Faoisdin glan agus leis a chorp Naomhtha. Olla roimh bás le grásta an Aon Mhic. Agus deas lámh sagart ar an uair deireannach. Na trí asboil is sine na trí asboil is óige. Solas na soillse agus radharc na Trionóide agus grásta na foidhne in agaidh na heagóra.

4602687/4595248/4616564.title: Seanphaidreacha
4602687/4595248/4616564.text: Deireann na daoine an paidir seo nuair a chluineann síad an clog ag búaladh.Glóir na h-Aingil go gcluinimíd,soillse na Flaithis go bfhághimíd, glóir d'on Athair agus do'n Mhach agus don Spiorad naomh.

4602684/4595135/4616619.title: Paidir a Deirtí tar éis an Phaidrín
4602684/4595135/4616619.text:
Paidir a deirtí tar éis an Phaidrín. A Mhaighdean bheann uighthe buadhmar mhaiseach. Tú mo stóir mo lóin agus thairge. Tú réalth óghdha rómhainn go bealach críoscín síos as smál go bpeascaidh ar mo bháis go raibh tú agam. Séamus Ó Mainnín. ‘Sé Micheál Ó Mainnín (59). Torrus Flainnín, Clochán a chuig an Paidir seo dho. Béil OideasSeo paidir a deirtí ag éirigh dóibh ar maidin. Éirighim suas lé dia go n-éirigh dia liom. Lámh dé i mo chimcheall ag suidhe is luighe is ag éirigh dom. Paidir ag cogail an ceine dóibh. Cogluigim an teine seo már cogluigheas Críost cá. Ó rigid in a bhun is Muire na lár, secant n-Aingil frehid ag flacheas na ngrást seo cuadach an chigre seo is na daoine go lá.



1/Seo paidir a deirtí ag éirigh dóibh ar maidin.Eirighim suas lé dia go n-éirigh dia liam láin dé in mo timcheall ag suidhe is luighe is ag éirigh dom.2/Paidir ag cogail teine dóibhCogluighim an teine seo már cogluigheas  Críost cá Brighid in a bian  is Muire na lár, Seacht n-aingil fichid ag flitheas ma nGrást seo cuidado ach na tigre seo is na daoine go lá.Dá mbéinn-se = Mana na gamin Dubhach is paipéa bheith agam ann.Is deas a scriobhfiain duit .Aníos n mbán an moadh áluinn.A bhí ar an gleánn.'Sé d'iarrfainn ariompuigh dhomsa ar Rí na nGrást
(continues on next page)

4613675/4607425/4616753.title: Comhairleacha
4613675/4607425/4616753.text:
1. Cuir tús le do chuid oibre go moch sa ló.2. Breathnuigheann bean maith tighe roimpi.3. Ná leig do rudaí teacht san mullach ort. 4. Nigh saspán acht glan friochtán le ruainne arán.5. Bain feidhm as uisge agus gallaoirigh.6. Ná cuir cos na sgeana in uisge te.7. Saith sgian ar gearradh innúin léi i gcréatóig.8. Cuairtigh cnuimh i glasraí sul ar gcuirtear ar bogadh iad. 9. Ba ceart glasraí glasa a bhruith gan clár ar an bpota.10. Fluich an tae ar an bpuinnte is bhíos an t-uisge bruithte.



A Paidrín Pádhraic a ngáirdín Phadhraig. Moladh na mná bhí riamh gan locht. Aon Mhic Mhuire is athar na Grásta go réidtigh tú an cás ar an anam bocht.

4591094/4590128/4616787.title: Seanphaidir
4591094/4590128/4616787.text:
Is Beannuighthe thú, A Theampaill Dé,Is go mbeannuighim péin DhuitMar shúil le go mbeannóchadh Mac Dé agus a dá aspal Déag dom.Is beannuighthe thú, A Chrois ,A Chrann Dhéisigh de Dhuilleabhar  ghlasIn ar céasadh Críost fáoi do bhunUmluighim péin síos ar mo ghlúin dheisGo gcuiridh tú mé as mo leasGo gcuiridh tú mo chroidhe lán de na deora athruightheGo dtugaidh tú dúinn toradh agus tairbhe agus ar gcionn do ghlór an an Aifrinn beannuighthe
(continues on next page)

4591096/4590334/4623151.title: Travelling Folk
4591096/4590334/4623151.text:
(continued from previous page)
of this class in this district. Their names are Sweeneys. These are a married couple but are now old. They come to this district very often. Long ago they lived in Polredmond a year. The man was a soldier and was away, and the wife and her daughter remained in this district during his absence. Now he is getting a Pension as a soldier and both are getting the Old Age Pension also.All these folds intermarry. Most of these are very good Catholics and go to mass every Sunday. They also are present at the fairs and races. Their usual camping places in this district are Cararoe cross, Williamstown bog road, Lodge Hill, Moore field, Springfield, and Cowberry. The above information was obtained from the children's parents.



O glorious St. Patrick Apostle of Ireland in behalf of the children at home and abroad Thank the Almighty for the faith of the Irish race and for the heros fidelity of our fathers. O Blessed St.pray for the children at home and the exiles beyond
(continues on next page)

4591096/4590335/4623154.title: Old Prayers
4591096/4590335/4623154.text:
(continued from previous page)
the seas. O sweet saint pray that our children be steadfast in faith till death and pray that their sanctity may be kept holy. May St. Patrick, St. Brigid and the saints in Heaven pray that Erin may keep the faith and bless the Irish people everywhere.



Úlighim agus íslighim Duit a Shlánuighteóir Íosa Críosta le mo chroidhe atá faraoisc (faraoir) cráidhte faoí go cúl agus go cam dá cúir mé fearg ort a Rí na Righthe maitheamhnas agus párdún atá mé ag iarraidh ort ar mo pheacaidh.Tabhair trocairé iarriadh bas don docar a thabairt dhuinn, bás Críost, óla agus sithrighe. (Tabhair trocairé dhuinn, iarraimid bás gan dochar a tabhairt dhuinn, (bi) Corp Criost, óla agus aithrighe) Ofráílim-'sa suas na cuig deichneahbhair neilich ár bpeacaidh le Aifreann le Saoire no Domhnaigh le cailibh le cill faillí nelich bás agus bás mo Shlánuightheóira Íosa Críosta a dfhulaing tú ar ar son. Ofráilim-'sa suas iad le h-anam, ár nathair agus ár máthaireacha, durbsheireacha agus dearbhrathaireacha agus le h-anam an creatúir nach bhfuil duine le fhéin a guidhe ar a shon le mach Dé agus don Mhaigdin Glórhar bheannuighthe mo chuid is mo dhaoine. Slighe beath ar an Saoghal seo dhuinn agus glor na bflaitis ar an saoghal eile. Go dtugaidh Tú slighe ar na
(continues on next page)

4591096/4590336/4623155.title: Old Prayers
4591096/4590336/4623155.text:
(continued from previous page)
fiaca dhuinn. Go dtugaidh Tú saoghal ar saoghal dhuinn agus glor na bflaithus ar an saoghal eile. Míle moladh go deo agus buidheachas do mo Shlánuightheoir Íosa Críosta a thug slan o'n lá indiú sinn go dthugaidh tú slán ar oidhche anocht sinn. Go sabilid Tú muid in aghaidh Namad cuirp agus codlata Tú le h-anam mharb Purgtadóirteachta.

This prayer is already written, but   this is it again in a different version. Obtained from the same person.Úluighim agus íslighim Duit mo Shlánuighteoir Iosa Criosta le mo chroidhe ata faoraisí craidte faoí go h-uair agus faoí go h-am  dá chúir mé fearg ort a Rí na Righthe maitheamhnas agus  pardún  atá mé ag iarraidh ort ar mo pheacaidh. Trocaire  agus grást a thabhairt dhuinn, bás gan docar a thabhairt dhuinn bas, Criost, (?)  agus Aithrighe, Ofráilim-'sa suas na cuig deicneabair seo í ndoilig ár bpeacaidh, Aifreann, lá Saoire, no Domhnaigh a chailleadh (?)  le cill faidhe, i ndoilig bás agus bás mo Shlanuightheoir Iosa Criosta a d'fhulaing tú ar ár son. Ofráilim-'sa suas iad  le h-anam ár nathair, ár matháireacha, agus ár deirbséireacha agus le h-anam cairde beo is marbh agus le h-anam an creatuir nach bhfuil duine aige fein a guidhe ar a shon le mac (?) Dé agus don Maigdhin Glormhar Bheannauighthe  mo chuid is mo  dhoaine agus mé fein a chuir slán tar thubaiste agus tar anachain, aichead, garla coichthighe na bliadhna. Go dTugaidh Tú slighe  bheatha ar an tsaoghal seo dhuinn, agus glór na bFlaitis ar an tsaoghal eile. Go dTugaidh Tú slighe ar na fiacha dhuinn, agus go dtugaidh tú saoghal ar saoghal dhuinn agus glor na bFlaitis ar an tsaoghal eile. Mile moladh go deo agus buideachas mo Shlánuightheoir Iosa Criosta a thug slán o'n lá indhiú sinn, go dTugaidh Tú slán o'n oidhche anocht sinn. Go Sabhailidh Tú muid in aghaidh gach gadh, agus in agaidh Namad curip agus  codhlacha Tú le h-anam mharb Purgadóireachta.
(continues on next page)

4613671/4606915/4623378.title: Prayers and Rhymes
4613671/4606915/4623378.text:
As I lie down my right hand side I pray to God to be my guideAny evil come to me,Blessed Lady waken me.There are four corners on my bed And four angels on them spread.Mathew Mark Luke and JohnBless the bed that I lie on.



As I look up, as I look down,As I look up into God's crown,I met the Virgin Mary coming down,Twelve books in her handTwelve bells ringing,Twelve priests singing,Shut the doors of hellAnd open the gates of heaven.



If this prayer is said three times morning and evening, you'll never see the fires of hell.

metadata.Teacher:: Séamus Ó Dochartaigh, Bean Uí Dhochartaigh

4613671/4606915/4623379.title: Prayers and Rhymes
4613671/4606915/4623379.text:
As I lie down my right hand side I pray to God to be my guideAny evil come to me,Blessed Lady waken me.There are four corners on my bed And four angels on them spread.Mathew Mark Luke and JohnBless the bed that I lie on.



As I look up, as I look down,As I look up into God's crown,I met the Virgin Mary coming down,Twelve books in her handTwelve bells ringing,Twelve priests singing,Shut the doors of hellAnd open the gates of heaven.



If this prayer is said three times morning and evening, you'll never see the fires of hell.

metadata.Teacher:: Séamus Ó Dochartaigh, Bean Uí Dhochartaigh

4613671/4606916/4623383.title: A Rhyme By a Young Man on Death of His Mother
4613671/4606916/4623383.text:
In speaking of the grief of a certain young man at the graveside of his mother Jude Henry said poor fellow made a fine speech:-"Mo mháthairín bocht do chuir ar an saoghal mé,Go dtugaidh Dia bhFlaitheas bán dá hAnam bochtAgus 'cuile anam da bfuil ins an teampall seo indiúGo dtugaidh Dia Flaiteas dóibhthea amháin"(When the old woman repeated this she said "Mo chuid an tSaog"-)



Luighmuid ar lámh dheis agus codluighmuid ar an lamh chléLuighmuid le Dia agus glaodh Dia linnGuarda na naoi aingeal ar ár gcuirpluighmuid le Muire 's go luigheadh Muire linn.O Muire Máthair mo mhíle grádh thúMo chabhar chúntai in aimsear go gcathugadhGo mo thuan réaltóga roinn agus gan bealach ár luigheNá nóir dár leigheadh tú ár nAnam.
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: Séamus Ó Dochartaigh, Bean Uí Dhochartaigh

4613682/4608204/4623384.title: Paidreacha
4613682/4608204/4623384.text:
Cainnt a chualas ó mo shean-athair Pádhraic Ó Reachtaire a aois ceithre sgór bliadhain d'aois.This is a prayer which every person used say. There was no particular time for saying it but it was never forgotten when people went into a church. It was almost the first prayer every child learned to say from its mother. "A Dhia atá thuas sa bFlaitheas líon mé le gean ort fhéin. Cuir in mo chroidhe    do ghrádh-sa is na leig ar shiochrán uait mé.A Mhuire a Mháthair an Aon-Mhic tugaim duit fhéin onóir.Iarr tuse na grásta go léir dhom agus cuir do brat thart orm le'm chosaint ar bhaoghal go bráth.A Íosa éist le Do Mháthair atá ag guidhe ar mo shon-sa agus ná iúltuigh  a paidreacha a Dhia ró-Thighearna, Ámén.This was a prayer which was said when in bed at night. Four corners in my bed four angels on them spread Mathew Mark, Luke and John God bless the bed that I lie on, and if I die before I wake you pray to God my soul to take.It was the special prayer to be said on that occasion. My grandfather thinks      that there was no special prayer to be said when raking the fire. Sometimes they used make the sign of the cross on the ashes with the tongs before going to bed. When going
(continues on next page)

4613683/4608299/4623473.title: Paidreacha
4613683/4608299/4623473.text:
Utuígadh roimh biadhDeirtear an paidir seo roimh gac béile.Bheannaigh a thígearna an oileamhain seo is mian línn do chaitheamh chum ar neartú cum do thóil naomta a coimlionadh in-ainm an athair an mhic agus an spiorad Naomh Amen.Ag bualad an chlogDeirtear an paidir seo nuair a bhualann an chlog gac lá. A thigearna déanaigh dom tú a ghrádú anois agus ar fead na siorruidheacta.
(continues on next page)

4613685/4608353/4623509.title: Paidreacha
4613685/4608353/4623509.text:
Coiglighm an teine seo mar a choigligheas Chríost cách. Brighid in a bhun agus Muire in a bárr. Trí fichead aingle is aoired i gcuairt Flaitheas Dé. I mbun ár ndaoine is an teine seo go lá. Nuair a bhíonn duine ag dul a codladh. Deannuighim isteach  sa leabadh seo. Islighim arm o thaobh is codhlaim ar mo thaobh clé. Dúilguighim d’aon olc agus iompuighim le Mac Dé. Tugaim mé fein suas don trúir is fearr, an t-hAthair, an Mac agus an Spiorad Naomh. Ceithre coinnéil ar mo leabadh. Ceithre haingle ortha scartha. Má fhaghaim bás as seo go maidin. Flaitheas Dé do m’anam. Imeasc na nAspol, na nOllamh agus na Naomh agus Glóir na bFaitheas go bfághadh siad labha I Mhuire, Máthair, Deannuighthe is a Dhainríoghan na Glóire, leat a dhéanaimse mo casaoid maidin is tráthnóna Dhuiltigh mé do na peacaidh agus cuir me ar an eólais suas do na Flaitheas go Cathair na Glóire.
(continues on next page)

4613685/4608354/4623517.title: Paidreacha
4613685/4608354/4623517.text:
(continued from previous page)
Ag Coigilt na teineCoiglíghim an teine seo mar a coiglígheas Críost cách. Bríghid in a bhun agus Mhuire in a lar. Seacht n-aingil fichead as Fláitheas na n-Grást. Ag cumhdach an tíghe seo agus a daoine go lá.Nuair a bhíonn duine ag dul a chodhladhCeithre coirnéal ar mo leabhad. Aingle Dé ortha sgartha. Má fhághaimhse bás as seo go maidin agus bFláitheas De go raibh mo leaba. Seacht lán roilig Padhraig agus Brat Brighde agus beannacht leath na go bfiolaidh mé aríst ort.Ar Thaobh an BótharMuire agus Íosa go raibh tú ag mo cheann. Árd Easbog agus Éon Baistigh go raibh tú ag mo bhun. Teachtaire Naomhtha le oladh Críosta go raibh againn an am. Cuirfheas séala ar a n-anam dhílis agus n-ainm Íosa céasadh ar an gcrann. Sí Muire crann seasta gach peacach gach aoinne agus cé a rachas fé na brat agus a

Paidir GealGo mbeannuighe Dia dhuit a Phaidir gheal. Go mbeannuighe Dia is Muire dhuit. Cé codal tú aréir mar a codal Mach Dé. Cé codalochas tú anocht mar a codalochas na bocht. Cé codalochas tú san oichdhe amárach mar codalochas Naomh Padhraig. Cé sin romhat amach, céad aingeal. Cé sin in do dhiaidh aniar cead Easbog. Naoi mbraon d'uisce an Domnaigh cuir Muire liom Dia ar eolas Dia Phadhraig. Dia liom a chomhnuigheann Drighidagus a brat, Mícheal agus a sgiath dhá láimh gheala Dia ag teacht againn le manaim sad, sad do dhiaidh dhá láimh tharis siar fáinne óir ag dul in a seacht grian. Mairig a cruthaigheanns mairig a céasfadh í ngeall ar an grocain teacht aniar ag éisteacht le sruth cruinn gan bhrat ór dearfad go clára go bfeicfidh sé Muire Mháthair dhá uaire roimh a bás.

4583360/4583039/4623609.title: Aisling Mhic na Páirte
4583360/4583039/4623609.text: Aíne Ní Fhágarta do chuir síosTomás Ó Fagharta a dearbhrathair (21) ar baile na hAbhann a dinnis dhi é.-Céard sin ort a mháthair?-Níl aon rud acht ag aisling ort a bhím-Cén aisling sin ort a mháthair?-Go mbíonn tú go do bhualadh go do mharbhúigh go do chrochadhGo do chéaradh go do cheangal go phortaí cló;Coróin spíonta le dhul ar do cheannSleagh nimhe le dhul in do thaobh deas,Do chuid fola bréagh beannuighte na srutháiníní síos leat.-Nach maith an aising í sin a mháthair!Níl aon duine a déarfhas an páidir seo trí h-uaire romih dul i mbás chodalta na h-oidhche dhó ní baoghal dhó Ifreann go bráthach acht beidh flaitheas Dé mar luach saothair aige.

metadata.Teacher:: Tadhg Ó Séaghdha, Máire, Bean Uí Dhuigneáin

4583360/4583040/4623610.title: Aisling Mhic an Pháirte
4583360/4583040/4623610.text: "Codladh sin ort a mháthair"?Ó ní h-eadh a mhic na páirte   Ach aisling""Céard é t-aisling a mháthair"?Aisling go raibh Tusa go do phúrtháilGo do cheangal go phostaibh clóAgus do chuid fola beannuighthe fhéin ag  rith leat""Is fíor é sin a mháthairAn té a déarfhas t'aisling trí h-uaire tar éis luighe ar an leabaidh dhóNí baoghal dhó go bfheice sé geata dubh Ifrinn go bráthach ná aon    droch-aisling go maidin"

metadata.Teacher:: Tadhg Ó Séaghdha, Máire, Bean Uí Dhuigneáin

4613671/4607035/4623952.title: Johnny the Sugar Stick Man
4613671/4607035/4623952.text:
Johnny used to put down sugar and water in a cannin and when is was boiled he would thicken it and roll it on the hearthstone. He had red paint and he would put a few stripes of this through the sugar stick. It was just as good as any sugar stick to-day.His wife Biddy used to bring it to the market to seel it, and get drunk. When she would want to sell it she would take up a piece and say, "Bigger one, longer one, stronger one, thicker one.



"Ár nathair tair new neifer ainim gadar do ríocht go neinter a thoil ar an talamw mar a neintear ar neamh tower ún new an taráin laee maith chún na bheacaodh le mhaith a muid héin mur a saorse na gcaitheadh amain.

fairy tale but a fact. (end of Mr Connell's ace)



Mrs P. Brennan, Knockmaskill said when she would finish her meals my grandmothers would say:-"Seact lán déag munboughCríosta bráth bhrigid agus roillig Phádráig go bheanuigh. Dílis de i naomh agus asbhol i anam a Seáin a Stór isteach go bhflaitheas De.Tom B the fatherinlaw (90 yrs of age) heard her  and said "that's nearly like what I used to say my-self after my meals":-Díar áw sios le Dia, an fear a tug an bheatha sin duinn. go dtugadh sé bheatha hearie ins na flathais duinn.Go mba seacht míle fearr, bheas muid bliadhain ó indiú in ár gcuid agus in ár grádh Dia agus in ár gcomharsaine míol saoghal agus Sláinte Amen



How would you bring a fox and a goose and a sheeve of oats across to the other side of a river, not letting the fox eat the goose, or the goose to eat the oats:-Bring the goose first across leaving the fox and the oats on the other side as the fox won't toatch the oats until you come back again. Then come back again for the sheeve of oats and bring back the gooses with you to the foxes(P.T.O. to page 147 x)
(continues on next page)

4613672/4607102/4624023.title: The Potato Crop
4613672/4607102/4624023.text:

The pits are dug a few inches down in the soil in order to mark the place for the potatoes. They are first covered with rushes and then with bog (side) sods and clay.The chief potatoes that are sown in this district are:- Kerr Pinks, May Queens, Aran Banners, Skerries, Queens, Red and White Champions and



In olden times when the poor Irish people had no education and were not able to read Prayer Books they had many beautiful old prayers which were probably made up by themselves or handed down. They had prayers for every time (for) of the day but since the Irish began to learn English all the lovely prayers are forgotten. The following are some of the prayers which were said on
(continues on next page)

4602700/4596672/4624060.title: An Phaidir Gheal
4602700/4596672/4624060.text:
Cár chodail tú aréir fá chosaí mhic Dé.Cá gcodlóchaid tú anocht v. fá cosaí na mbocht.Cé sin romhat v. tá ha h-aingle.Cé sin in do dhiaidh tá na h-Aspail.Cé sin ar do láimh dheis tá braon de uisge an Domhnaigh.Chuir Muire liom ag deanam an eólais ó dhoras go doras gó doras Parrtháis.Eocair Phárrtháis atá mé ag iarraidh atá san dabhach údan tháll a bhfuil fleasg óir ar a cheann agus an coráon soillseach in a láthair.Tháinig oidhche tháinig ceó. Tháinig Bríghid le na brat tháinig Miceál le na sgiath. Brionglán fada brionglán gearr an té a déarfhas an pháidir geal ceann oidce is de ló go m'aobhann dó.
(continues on next page)

4613690/4609114/4624067.title: Paidreacha
4613690/4609114/4624067.text:
PaidreachaTá sean-paidreacha ag m’athair acht tá an Ghaeilge comh sean nach féidir iad a sgríobhah síos, nó aon mhíniú d’fághail ionnta. Nuair a thagann bliadhain nua deireann na sean daoine . “Go mba seacht fearr a bhéas muid bliadhain ó'n oidhche seo anocht.” Nuair a chloiseann siad droch- sgéal deireann siad, ‘go bhfoiridh Dia orrainn, agus má siad sgannruighthe, deireann siad , “Fada uainn anachain”. Nuair a geibheann laogh bás deirean siad. ‘Go gcuidiú Mac Dé linn.Tá paidir eile aige agus déir ré liom, aoinne a déarfaidh é gach oidhche nach seasfadh sé ar leacrachaibh ifrinn, go deo.  Seo píosa de; Ceithre cosa faoi mo leabaidh, ceithre aingeal ag rádh paidir. Má geibheann- sé bás ó oidhche go maidin gur i bhFlaitheas a bhéas m’anam.  Tá mé féin ag iarraidh déirce. Súil go mbeadh lé teacht na féile. An uair nach b'féidir, bhí ná éadan lé féil na glóire is fiú éistheacht.Deireann m’athair paidir eile nuair a bíonn ré ag rádh an paidrín páirteach gach oidhche. Níl fhios agam cé'n chiall atá
(continues on next page)

4613673/4607157/4624084.title: Scéal
4613673/4607157/4624084.text:
Bhí buachaill ág ar aimsear ag mnaoi darbh ainm dí Nóra Sean Liaim. Bhíodh sí an dhian ar fad ar an mbuachaill agus ar éigean thugadh sí blúire le n-ithe dhó. Ag buachailleacht caorach fo chaitheadh sé an lá agus é ag trúith leis an tráthnóna agus béile na h-oidhche dá dhonact é.Bhí se lá agus é ag dearcadh ar an ngréin agus é ag dul go mall réidh treasna na spéire. Leabair se leis agus séard a dúbhairt sé "A ghrian. A ghrian, an raibh tú riamh ar aimsear? Dá mbeiteá ráite ar aismear ag Nóra Sean Liam. Ritheá níos tapaidh i do cheanntar.



An paidrín páitreach, an gairdin parrais i mboladh na mBláth Bhí riamh gan locht Is a haon Mic Mhuire atá i fcathaoir neimheGo rúdhtigh tú an gab seo do m'anam bocht.



Uan dubh ag caora-bánSearrach óg is a agaidh leat.Nó gealach ar thaobh do cúlI mbliana ní bheith ort rath.

4613673/4607217/4624174.title: Old Prayers
4613673/4607217/4624174.text:
1. Seacht lá an déag roilig Padhraig, túmbha Críost, brat Bgighide gur beannacht Dí. Dílis Dé le hanam a bhfuil beo agus marbh agus le na nAnam Féin ar uair ár mbáis Amen.2. Árd ríog na bhFlaitheas b'ling ins gach bealach agus cuinnling na h ódh seo aoinne, Na  dtrí hainglibh bréagh greú láthair an Máirt go atá Íosa Muire agus Naomh Seosamh. Ámen.3. Nuair a tiocfas a tanam bocht go geata na bhFlaitheas tiocfad Naomh Siomon fé ná dhéin ar 'sed na Maughoine Muire ar caith tú an  liov réidh. Ar sead na Maighdin mise idir beag agus mór ar cad a brat. Beid siad leath ar Máire stráige.4. Huirling Mac Dé faoí na braon do dá capaigh Má tiocas dá gréine ní pleacfad se gloinne.5. As I lie down this night to sleep.I pray to God my soul to keep.
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: Brighid Ní Náradaigh, Cáit Bean Uí Standúin

4613673/4607219/4624176.title: Prayers
4613673/4607219/4624176.text:
God Bless Good Friday the day on which our Saviour died nailed to a cross from the cross to his hands, His Heart was bleeding sore. His tender Mother standing by with a dreadful cry and a Heart full Sore.Amen.Lord my God I am sorry and beg pardon for all my sins and I detest them above all things because they deserve Thy dreadful punishment and most of all because they offend Thine infinite Majesty and I firmly purpose by Thy holy grace never more to offend Thee and carefully to avoid the occassion of sin.Sweet Mary Christs Mother you may be at my head St John the Apostle may be at my feet Jesus messenger with Christs oil may be to me in time to put a seal
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: Brighid Ní Náradaigh, Cáit Bean Uí Standúin

4613673/4607221/4624183.title: Old Prayers
4613673/4607221/4624183.text: God bless this house from dawn to dark. God bless our work and play. God bless our loved ones far and near and guard them night and day.God be the branch, Mary be the flower. Sweet Jesus be with me at my last dying hour.The Cross of Christ is my sure salvation. The Cross I ever adore. The Cross of the Lord is with me and I love it ever more.From the ashes of the past, Lord of mercy, Jesus blest. Grant the faithful light and rest. Mother I trust and confide in Thee Mother I send my sighs to Thee. Mother assist thy poor week child. Mother's protection and strength I seek.May the peace of God's angels and the prayers of God's saints make my soul like a vision before God without taint.

metadata.Teacher:: Brighid Ní Náradaigh, Cáit Bean Uí Standúin

4613692/4609263/4624361.title: Paidreacha
4613692/4609263/4624361.text:
Nuair a bhíonn duine ag dul a chodladh san oíche deireann sé " Ceithre phosta ar mo leaba. Ceithre aingeal mhac Dé, má fhághaim  bás as seo go maidin i bhflaitheas Dé a bheas m'anam bocht"Luighim le Dia agus go luighidh  Dia liomlámh deas Dé fá mo chloigeann agus dhá láimh Mhuiretimcheall ormTá crois na naoi n-aingeal geal ó bharr mo chloigeannGo bun mo sháileNár  luighe mé le olcas agus nár luighe olc liom.A Íosa óir ciste déan trócaire ormA Íosa uachtar ár mbeatha déan trocaire orm.Nuair chuirtear an chéad fata deirteargo gcuiridh Dia toradh agus tairbhe ar a gcuirimíd agus a nglacaimid agus a gabh muid thrídNuair fhaíghtear an chéad uan deirtear"Mo Dhia dhá thárrtháil agus go dtárraigh Dia muid agus go mbeirimíd beo ar an am seo arísAg dul thar reiligSeacht roilig Pádraic agus iomháigh Críost,Molfar thuas thú agus molfar thíosagus molfar ag righ na glóire thúagus go ndéanaidh Dia trocaire ar anamnachaibh na marbh

4613693/4609319/4624398.title: Paidreacha
4613693/4609319/4624398.text:
PáidreachaA Pháidir milis mhíorúilteach tá lán de ghrása.Cuirim chugat, a Íosa, mo chaomhaint ar mo námhaid'luighe dom anocht, i's ag éirigh dhom imbárachI n-onóir do'n Trionóid, síothcháin na Páise.Íosa mhilis na fírinne, Mic na Maighdean CúmharaSeachan mé ar na pianta 'tá na h-aoite (?) dorcha dúnta.A Bhainríoghan na bhFlaithis & a bhainríoghan na h-óigeCuir mo chroidhe i n-aithrighe go silidh sé deora.Airte gula chreidimh chruaidh (?) tar chugainn ar uair báisMar thagas an t-Aingeal anuas, & fanann's i gcluais na mná.Ní'l both ar tuath, na both le gnúis na h-óige.A bhean chroidhe chómhair a bhí'g iomchur CríostNíl brat óir ná connradh chláirAn té a déarfas é sin uair gach lá ní tiocfaidh a ainm ar leac a'phroinn go bráth. AménAn Pháidir GéalGo mbeannuighidh Dia dhuit, a Pháidir Gheal.Go mbeannuighidh Dia is Muire dhuit.
(continues on next page)

4613688/4608753/4624404.title: Seanscéal
4613688/4608753/4624404.text:
Paidreacha a deireas na daoine. - Fuaireas na Paidreacha seo uaidh:-Bean Uí ConlainBaile an t-SagairtAn SpidéalCo.na Gaillimhe(Nuair a eirigheanns duine ar maidin deirtear:-"Buidcheas le Dia agus le MuireA thug slán ón oíche muidGo dtugadh tú slán ón lá muidSlán o gach dhámh agus chuile contabhairtIndiu is go bráthÁmén.Nuair a thosnuighthear ar obair an lae deirtear:- G"Gach nidh ar do shon-sa ÍosaGach nidh ar do son-sa a stóirFagann chuile shórt faoi do comairce agus faoi do comhairleÁmén.

4613693/4609334/4625164.title: Paidreacha
4613693/4609334/4625164.text:
(continued from previous page)
A Seoladh – Cnoc, Maghchuilinn, Co. na Gaillimhe.



A Seoladh – Cnoc, Maghchuilinn, Co. na Gaillimhe.9Nuair atá duine ag dul a choladh san oidhche deireann sé:-“Ceithre phosta ar mo leaba,Ceithre aingle Mhic Dé,Má fhághaim bás as seo go maidinI bhFlaitheas Dé a bhéas m’ainm bocht”.Luighim le Dia, go luighidh Dia liom.Lámh dheas de Dhia faoi mo chloigeann,Agus dhá láimh Mhuire timcheall orm.Tá crios na naoi n-Aingeal ó bhárr mo chloigeann go bun mo sháile.Ná luighfidh mé le olc i’s ná luighfidh olc liom.A Íosa, óir-chíste na gCriostuigh, déan trócaire orm.A Íosa, uachtar na mbeatha, déan trócaire orainn.Nuair a chuireann siad an chéad fata deireann siad:- “Go gcuiridh Dia toradh is tairbhe ar a gcuireamar i’s ar a nglacamar i’s a gabhamar thríd”.Mo Dhia ghá tháráil, a’s go dtáraidh Dia muid, a’s go mbeirimíd beo ar an am seo arís.Seacht roilig Phádraig a’s iomadh ChríostMolfar thuas thú agus molfar thíos i’s molfar i Righ na GlóireAgus molfar Dia go trócaireach ar ainmeacha na marbh.
(continues on next page)

4613693/4609335/4625165.title: Paidreacha
4613693/4609335/4625165.text:
(continued from previous page)
Is maith an rud a bheith fíor de’n bhocht,Agus gan ár gcroidhe a bheith cruaidh le nocht.Gheibhímíd ó Dhia arís faoi ochtMá thugaimíd cuid de’n stór uainn.Má dóirteann siad braon bainne deireann siad: “Go leigidh Dia slán amáireach. B’féidir gur theastuigh sé i n-áit eile”.



Is maith an rud a bheith fíor de’n bhocht,Agus gan ár gcroidhe a bheith cruaidh le nocht.Gheibhímíd ó Dhia arís faoi ochtMá thugaimíd cuid de’n stór uainn.Má dóirteann siad braon bainne deireann siad: “Go leigidh Dia slán amáireach. B’féidir gur theastuigh sé i n-áit eile”.An Sgoláir – Caitlín Ní OireachtaighA Seoladh – Leamhchoill, Mághchuilinn, Co. na Gaillimhe.An duine a thug dí iad – Micheál Mac Oireachtaigh.A Sheoladh – Leamhchoill, Mághchuilinn, Co. na Gaillimhe.Cóirighim an leaba seo i n-ainm an Athar agus an Mhic agus an Spioraidh Naomh agus i n-ainm an oidhche a rugadh thú.“Céard sin atá tú ag rádh?” arsa an Spiorad Naomh, ag teacht isteach an doras, “Ní tada, a Mhic, acht páidreacha beaga beannuighthe mar shíl mé nach dtiocfadh go lá”.“Is fíor sin, a mháthair”, ar seisean, “Is beannuighthe iad do chuid pháídreacha agus ní’l aon duine a déarfadh do chuid pháidreacha nach geal é a leaba go Athair na Glóire”.Nuair a bhaineann duine na fataí nua séard a deireann sé: “Go mairfidh muid beo ar an t-am seo arís”.
(continues on next page)

4613693/4609380/4625207.title: Seanamhráin
4613693/4609380/4625207.text:
Éist a Laraí na masla mé gan ádhbharBhéarfaidh mé cár tornópaí dhuit có maith ariamh is d’fás siad.Má tá Peadar Crosach ní crosach ceart atá séAcht gur thuit sé lá ‘na chodhladh thiar i gCurra UaitéirTháinic builc druideacha agus thugadar meas báis airAgus sin an dfág Peadar bocht chó crosach is tá sé.Táséasúir ar an gcnú acú agus séasúir ar an áirneAgus tá séasúir ag na caillíní  nuair a bhíonn’s Acht deamhan blas ag Peadar bocht acht chual a cosa ghearra.An Sgoláir – Máire Ní Raghallaigh.A Seoladh – Leamhchoill, Maghchuilinn, Co. na GaillimheAn duine a thug dó é – Pádraig Ó Raghallaigh.A Sheoladh – Leamhchoill, Maghchuilinn, Co. na Gaillimhe



Ná smaoinigh go minic ar an nidh gan feachaint, acht smaoinigh go minic ar na críocha deirnach. Is siad is fuide a thiocfas i mhein duit. Smaoinigh ar an mbás thiocfas go técaint. Bé fá na coinne i n-arm is i n-eadach.
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404748/4625223.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404748/4625223.text:
PaidreachaFáilte romhat a Mhuire Mhór, Mháthair Íosa, réalt na maidhne, sgiath na mbocht agus do anam thárat Is tú thug aráis an bád do thuig Gheibheas mór an ngrásta dhuit.Tabhairigh dúinne síothchán Dé, sgaoil na glais a cheanglas mé. Greim de'n bhochtaibh, dalladh siiúil, Mháthair Mhuirneach ar thí na n-uball. Saor sin fríd céim do Mhic ar olc agus ar fheadhas fríd Éirinn. Moltar faoi do choimridh gan mhuigheadh, an t-Atháir, mac, agus an Spiorad Naomh.Eibhlín Ní Ghallchobhair, Caiuseal - na -gCorr a thug an urnaighe seo domh.



Gheall phaidir bheannuigh car chodail tú aréir? Chodail mé san leabaidh an áit ar chodail Mac Dé.Ca gcodhlochaidh tú anocht? Fa Íosa Chríost. Caidé sin romhat? Tá n-a aingle. Agus caidé sin do dhiaidh? Tá n-a h-Easpail. Caidé sin in do láimh dheis? Tá uisge coisreachta a chur Muire liom a chuirfeadh ar an eolas go toighe an Phápa mé. La é gu liom an dabhach udaidh thall a bhfuil an choinneal gheal lásta i n-a lár, Brighid fa n-a brat, Muire fa n-a Mac, agus dhá l,aimh Dé fa mo mhuinneal.
(continues on next page)

4428402/4404759/4625228.title: Paidreacha
4428402/4404759/4625228.text:
(continued from previous page)
Mathair mhuirneach faoi na n-úirAthair na suailce agus air gan luchtAthair na h-Eaglaise agus an umhlaidheachtFríd féin a mhíc, réalt na maidneIs fearr DiaTáthair sinn o thaobh na bpianGo moltar thú gach áit sa domhanAn t-athair san mac san Spiarad Naomh



Luighim ann mo leabhaidh mar luighim ins an uaigh, ag iarraidh toradh agus brigh na Sacrámaint, os Mhuire agus grádh Dé. Gábhaim le Muire m'athair agus gábhaim le Righ flaitheas Dé ar mo anam bocht.



An urnaigh a dubhairt an Mhaidean Mhuire le na h-aon mhac Iosa nuair a bhí sé ag fághail báise ar chrann na chroiche
(continues on next page)

4613702/4610331/4625312.title: Seanphaidreacha
4613702/4610331/4625312.text:
Mbeannuighe Dia dhuit a phaidir gheal.Mbeannuighe Dia is Muire dhuith. Cé chodhail tú aréir, mar chodail Mac Dé. Cé a gclodach tú anocht, mar chodladas na bocht. Céard sin romhath, tá fiche aingeal. Céard sin i do dhiaidh, tá fiche Easpól. Céard sin ar do ghulainn chlé, tá Corp Chríost. Céard sin ar do ghulainn dheas, tá naoi ndeora go uisge an Domhnaigh chuir Muire liom-sa ag déanamh eolais ó tígh Phádraic go dtí Phárais. Muire agus a mach, Brígid agus a brat.
(continues on next page)

4613702/4610339/4625316.title: Paidir le Rá ag Dul a Codladh dhuit

4613702/4610348/4625322.title: Paidir
4613702/4610348/4625322.text: A Muire na Grást a mathair mic Dégo gcuirfidh tú ag ar mo leas mégo sabhaladh tú mé ar cuile olcgo sabhaladh tú me idir anam agus corpgo sabhaladh tú me tar mhuir, agus tar tirGrásta na n-Aingeal os ar gcionnDia romham agus Dia liom.(Críoch)

4613703/4610459/4625426.title: Paidreacha
4613703/4610459/4625426.text:
Coghluinid an teine so mar cogluigheas Criost Árd.Muire na bun agus Bríghid na barrNa trí Aingle is aoirdeAr Flaiteas Mhic Dé na n-GrástAg chumhdach ár dteach ar g-cuid agus á ndaoine slán.Deireann bean an tíghe an Paidir seo nuair a bhíos sí ag coigilt an teine san oidche*   *   *Go n-déanfaid Dia trócaire ar anamnachaibh na marbhSeo Paidir adeireas nuair atá  duine a dul tar Roilig*   *   *A Mhuire is truaghDeirtear é seo nuair a innsigeas duine sgéál an bhrónach go duine eile.
(continues on next page)

4613706/4610730/4627141.title: An Mharthain
4613706/4610730/4627141.text:
(continued from previous page)
gan aithne gan easba a coise ná láimhe.  Marthainn Phádhraic is rádh i nGaedilge se gurbé mo lean gan í ag fearaibh Éireann.  Mar a mbeadh aige acht na trí pearsannaí deireannaí déidheannacha go dtógfadh sé ó chathúghadh an diabhail go Flaithis Dé thú.  (a chríoch)Tá seacht bpaidreacha le rádh leis an mharthainn a chur do dhuine.

4622974/4619128/4628135.title: Seanphaidreacha
4622974/4619128/4628135.text:
Sean Phaidreacha1 Bhí an Mhaighdin Muire ag bríonghóidgh oidhche amháin "Codhladh dhuit a Mháthair" a dubhairt Mac Dé léithí."Ní h-eadh, a Mhic na Páirte" a dubhairt sí " ach aisling go raibh tusa go de sgúirseáilgo de phúráil,go de chrochadh,go de chéasadh,go de ceangal faoi phostaí clocha le rópaí caol cnáibe,go de chrochadh as crann an Páise,an corón spionta ag dul ar do cheann, an sleagh ag dul trí do thaobh deas,agus do chuid fola beannuighe dhá dóirteadh."Is fíor t-aisling" a Mháthair" a dubhairt Íosa Críost. "Níl aon neach, fir nó mná, a déarfas dochaint trí h-uaire gach lá, ní baoghal
(continues on next page)

4613700/4610160/4628160.title: An Phaidir Gheal
4613700/4610160/4628160.text: Luighim-se le DiaGo luighidh Dia liomSgáth Dé ós mo chionnCros na n-aingeal fá mo chomCá luighidh tú anochtFaoi cosa na mbochtCá luighidh tú oidhche i mbárachI ngáirdín PhárrthaisCé h-iad so romhat tá na h-aingleCé h-iad so in do dhiaidh dhá chéad aingilCé h-iad so ar do ghualann clé is deisBraon uisge a chuir Muire liomAg déanamh eolais ó dhoras go dorasGo doras PhárrthaisEochar Phárrthais atá mé ag iarraidhBríghid is  a bratMícheál agus a sgiathAgus a dhá láimh geala gléigeálTimcheall ár n-anam go h-uair ar mbáis.Amén

4622974/4619136/4628172.title: Seanphaidreacha
4622974/4619136/4628172.text:
(continued from previous page)
mé. Agus cuimrigh m'anam ort, a Mhuire bhaintighearna.



Codhladh dhuit a mháthair ní headh a mhich ach aisling. Ceard a thug tú as aisling do mháthar go mbeadh tú go do fhánaill agus do sgúrsáil, do ceangal go phostaí cloch go do chrochadh leis an cránn chéasta. Do chuid fola fíor uasal dhá dhoírte leis an talamh. lean do taisling

4622966/4617981/4628403.text: "Cogar dhuit a Mhic""Céard sin a Mhathair,""Sleagh ag dul in do thaobh dheas,"Do chuid fola min uaisle a bualadh faoi'n talamh."Paidir in am luighe."Cé gcodhlochaidh mé anocht?Idir Muire is a Mac.Idir Brighid is a brat.Idir Colmcille is a sgiath.Idir Dia is a lámh deas."Ceithre phosta r mo leaba,Ceithre aingil go m'aire go maidin,Coimric na naingeal ós mo cionn.Ceithre phosta ar mo leaba,Ceithre aingeal ós a gcionn,Is m'fhághann bád as seo go maideanAr dheis Dé go raibh m'anam.

4622972/4618967/4629192.title: Paidreacha
4622972/4618967/4629192.text:
Abruightear an pháidir seo gach maidin Luain"Déirigh Muire agus a mac go moch sa lá. Sgar sí a brat síoda agus rúim. Casadh fear beannuighthe, fear diamonds ón ruim. Is breágh é do bhrat adubhairt sé. Is breágh agus is beannuighthe dubhairt sí. Brat na dtrí mbeárna óir. A rugadh agus a baisteadh Íosa críost faoí" An té a deireadh é gach Luain, tiocfaidh an Mhaighdean trí h-uaire roimh a bhás aige agus ní baoghal dó damnúghadh.
(continues on next page)

4622990/4621506/4629403.title: Prayers
4622990/4621506/4629403.text:
Prayers Prayers said when "raking" the fire before  bed-time:-I spare this fire as Christ spares allMay Jesus and Mary guard us allI pray to the Host of Angels brightTo guard ourselves and our home tonight.When going to bed:-The Cross of Jesus, Mary and St. Joseph this night may be about us.When being in bed:-As I lay on my right handI pray God to be my quideGod bless this bed that I lie onThere are four corners on my bedFour angels on my spreadAnd if I die in mortal sinThat I may never see the depths of hell.God Bless Good Friday and Friday too.Before bed-time:-God bide with us this nightAgain until dayGod and Mary bide with us
(continues on next page)

4622996/4622042/4629769.title: Prayers
4622996/4622042/4629769.text: There are four corners on my bed,There are four angels at my head,Matthew, Mark, Luke and John,God bless the bed that I lie on.God save this fire as Christ saved all, May Mary and Briget protect those walls. We pray to the hosts of angels bright to guard our house and our home to night.As I lie down on my bed to sleep, to God above I give my soul to keep:  if any evils come to me. Hail Mary save me.

4622998/4622195/4629837.title: Old Prayers
4622998/4622195/4629837.text: Caigle midh an teine seo Mar chaigleann Criosta an cá. Muire na bón agus Brigidh in a báir. Dá oispeak dhé. Tá blasa mich dé. Cuigid an tigh seo agus na daoine go lár.As I lie down on this bed of sleep my soul I give to God to keep; whether I rise now or ever, my soul I give to God for ever. Four corners on this bed four angels on them spread. Matthew, mark, Luke and John God bless this bed that I lie on. If I die before I wake I pray to God my soul to take. If any evil spirit comes before day mother of Jesus come save is and send them away.

4622979/4620048/4629947.title: Paidir
4622979/4620048/4629947.text:
A Mhaighdean glórmhar, muínte, measamail'S tú mo stór  mo rún 's mo thaisge
(continues on next page)

4622979/4620051/4629950.title: An Phaidir Gheal
4622979/4620051/4629950.text:
Go mbeannuighidh Dia dhuit a phaidir ghealGo mbeannuighidh Dia agus Muire dhuitCé'r chodail tú 'reírMar chodluigheas Mac DéCé  gcodlóchaidh tú anochtMar codluigheas na boichtCe gcodlóchaidh tú  san oidhche mbárachMar chodluigheas Pádraig.Céard  sin  romhat?Tá na h-aingleCéard sin i do dhiaidh?Tá na h-aspoilCéárd sin ar do dheasláimh?Trí bhraon d'uisge an DómhnaighA chuir Muire liom ag déanamh an eolais go tí  PádhraigEochair Pádraig atá mé iarraidhEirghe Pheadair is glac mo láimhDeán mo shíothcaín  le Mac Dé.Má  ceadramh (?)  ar mo thaobh Mac le Dia idir mé 'gus í'S árd  's árd  atá an ghrian'S a dá diolán aiste síor'S mairg  a  chroith 's mairg a  chráidh'S mairg nach  raibh  aran gcnoc  údaigh thállAg éisteacht leis an gclog binn á bualadh  faoí'n mbinn.Ní'l aoinne a bheith ag éisteacht leis  an gclog binnA bhualadh  fá'n mbinn ar bhaoghal dó teine Ifreann go bráth.
(continues on next page)

4622999/4622292/4630038.title: Old Ruins
4622999/4622292/4630038.text:
(continued from previous page)
built by the Normans. It is not known was any attack was made on them or not. They say there is an under ground passage in Ballydavid castle that passage goes from the castle to Andy Loughnanes garden and crosses to road between Potters and Dillons.



Long ago the old people were very good and holy. They used to say the rosary every night. It was the rosary that kept the faith alive in the Irish people when the English Government made a law that a Priest could not say mass.When a person came into a house he would say "God save all here" "God bless" or if it was going home you were the people of the house would say "Safe home" meaning that you would get home safely by " Gods help" or if you did a good turn for a person he would say "God spare you your health or your eye sight"



There are three gareyards in this parish. The names of them are, "Tample Moyle", the "Old Abbey" and the "New Cemetery.
(continues on next page)

4622997/4622157/4630430.title: Prayers
4622997/4622157/4630430.text: Long ago the people said the following prayer when going to bed"When I lay down my right hand,I pray to god to be my guide,There are four corners on my bed,There are four angels on them spreadMatthew, Mark, Luke and John,God bless this bed that I lie on.A Night PrayerWhen I lie on my right hand sideI pray to God to be my guideWhen evils come to me Our Blessed Lady will waken meGod within, God without God blessAll about this houseFour corners on my bedFour angels on them spreadSaints,Mark, Matt, Luke and JohnGod bless this bed that I lie onIf I die before I wake I pray of God my soul betake, AmenWhen the Clock StrikesOh Lord this hour I give to theeFor all the past pardon meI know that I must soon departThen hide me in thy Sacred Heart

4623000/4622417/4630486.title: Prayers
4623000/4622417/4630486.text:
(continued from previous page)
The love of my heart is Thy Heart O Saviour dear. My treasures untold is to hold, Thy Heart in my fond heart here, Foraah: it is known Thy Own overflows with love for me.



Looking at the Sun.There is a prayer said when looking at the sun. Oh Lord, You are the sun of my soul and the light of my soul and the light of my soul too. Give me the grace to keep it as You would I should. Leaving the House. When leaving your house say:Stay with me O Lord every place I goBecause it is on You we depend for our life. Going HomeWhen going home say: Open the door of my heart and
(continues on next page)

4623000/4622419/4630487.title: Prayers
4623000/4622419/4630487.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



The old people believed that if you would say this prayer three times by day and three times by night that you would never die in mortal sin. God Bless Good Friday and Friday too, Friday was the day Our Lord was crucified. The Jews came up with their spears sharp And struck Our Lord across the heart His Blessed Mother standing byWith a heavy heard and a dismal sigh,His Blesssed Blood began to flowFrom the Heart to His HandsGod Bless those people that says this prayerThree times by night and three times by dayYou never shall die in mortal sin or see the gates of hell. Amen.
(continues on next page)

4623000/4622420/4630488.title: A Prayer
4623000/4622420/4630488.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



In bygone days the old Irish had prayers to say beginning every work. Going to BedAs I lay down to sleepI leave my soul to God to keepSt. Matthew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless the bed that I lay onWhen the Sky is DarkWhen the sky would be dark and gloomy they used to say "As in the day of thy resurrectionWhen the sky did shake and rockO Lord God of Heaven and EarthDefend us from an earthquake shock.

4623002/4622607/4630513.title: Urnaithe
4623002/4622607/4630513.text: Dul a chodladh dhuitNá bí balbhIsligh síos agus póg an talamhAgus cuimhnig ar gach nidhda leig tú tharadhAgus go bhfuil tú ag triallAr chuan na marbh. ------------Bhí fear a filleadh abhaile on margadh lá agus bhí braoinín beag ólta aige. Casadh an sagart leis ar an mbóthar. Thug an sagart comhairle a leasa dó; sé sin le radh, fanach on ól. Seo an freagra a thug an fear don sagart: -"Muna dteighid ins an bhflaitheas dá bhfuil ins an ngleannAch an méid nach bhfuil ag ól uisge beatha no leannSílim féin gur beag a bhéas ann."

4623002/4622641/4630567.title: Seanphaidreacha
4623002/4622641/4630567.text: Sean Phaidreaca ó bhéal shean mná a fuair bás cúpla mí ó shoin  (bhí sí ceithre scór)Bean Shéyn Uí Dhiscín,  Annach Beag,  Cillchoirín, Béal Atha na SloghOIDHCHE  SHAMHNASeo rann beag adeireadh muinntir na h-áite so leath  chéad  bliadhain ó shoin  -  Oidhche Shamhna,  agu cibé duine  adeireas é faoi trí ní abróchaidh sé droch fhocal go ceann bliadhna.Anocht Oidhche ShamhnaChuaidh an ghaoth ar amhránLean bradán Easa RuaidhAgus liom féin buaidh m'urlabhra.

4602708/4597327/4631095.title: Paidreacha
4602708/4597327/4631095.text: (1)A Mhaighdean mhórdha mhór-mhaiseach,Is tú mo stór, mo lón agus mo thaisce,Is tú mo réalt eolais, agus lón sa bhealach,Súl a bhfuil ár mbáis, go tú i gairid. Amén.(2)A Chroidhe Naomhtha mo ShlánuightheoraAgruighim thú, grás do tabhairt duinn,Lé grádh dhuit, 'chuile lá nios mó. Amén.(3)A Íosa Criosta, a fuair bás Dia h-AoineIs a d'eirigh airíst i do Rígh gan locht,Is tú a thug sligh duinn, leis an earraigh a dheanamh,Is maith a smaointigheanns muid,Má cuimhnigheanns muid ort. Amén(4)A Naoimh Iosep mo chara, bí romham ar an mbealachgo dtreoir mo cathair go dteighimíd,Míle buidheachas go bráth le Righ geal na Grásta,A thug duinn an spás ar an saoghal seo,lé na trí ainmneacha breaghtha,bheith againn ar uair ár mbáis,Mar tá Iosa, Muire agus Naomh Iosep.(5)Ceithre pósta ar mo leabaidh, ceithre ainglí  orra  leagtha,Má fhághaim bás anois go maidin, I bhflaitheas Dé go raibh mo anam. Amén.(Maitías Ó'Griobhtha, aois 10, as Ceathramhadh na Riabhach  a chuala  na paidreacha seo ó'n a sean-mhathair, Eibhlín Ní Griobhtha, aois, 75, as Ceathramhadh na Riabhach)

4622965/4617892/4631120.title: (no title)
4622965/4617892/4631120.text: Tháinic Peadar go sruth Chórnáinagus tháinic Críost os a chionnCéard sin ort a PheadairM'fiacal atá tinnEirigh a Pheadair agus bí slánNí tusa amháin ac gac neachComh fada is beas an ghrian ag dul deiseal ar an aerbíodh an phian agus an athra in aonfact (?).

4622965/4617896/4631124.title: (no title)
4622965/4617896/4631124.text: Ceithre posta ar mo leabaCeithre aingeal ortha sgarthaMá fhághaim bás as seo go maidin I bhFlaitheas Dé go raibh m'anamA Mhuire dhilis a mháthair DéA Shoillseach glé gal atá gan smálA Choinneal lóchranach atá i bhFlaitheas DéGo raibh a ainm fhéin ar uair a mbáisSainte bairbre in aghaidh na tornaigheÓ a mhic is mór an gleo seo chugainn ins an gleannSeadh a mháthair ach ní baoghal dúinnSábhailfidh an t-athair sinnGo mba dún daingean an dún seo a bhfuil muid annGo mbás sluaigh dall ár námhaid atá ag tígheacht orainnÍosa Críost atá inár bhfochar go gcuirid tú tharainnGach nídh gan dith gan dochairAmén a thighearna Áine bhean Pheadair Uí Cheallaigh Tuairín a fuair mé iad seo.

4602728/4598877/4631538.title: Old Prayers
4602728/4598877/4631538.text:
The following prayers are said when going to bed at night.I. There are four corners on my bed, and four blessed angels over my head. St. Mathew, St. Mark, St. Luke and St. John, God bless this bed that I lie on.II. As I lie on my right side, I pray to God to be my guide, and if I die before I wake I pray to God my soul to take.III. As I lie on my right side, as Jesus sat on Marys knee, Mary the branch and Heaven the flower, Jesus, may be at my dying hour.
(continues on next page)

4602714/4597887/4631704.title: Paidreacha
4602714/4597887/4631704.text: Seacht bpaidir gan í gan óSeacht bpaidir dan cóir gan ceartSeacht bpaidir ar an dtaobh thall do'n abhainnAgus bas gan sagart do droch-mná an domhain.MumhanPaidir agus cré le na chur go bhflaitheas de agus seacht gcinn déag le na coingheal as.ConnachtAg gabháil buidheaochas do dhuine, a tabarfad deoch bainne duit deirtear -Na raibh tú coidhche gan bo bheartha bó durtha agus bó fe dháir"Fágann san ba gan dáir ag silce" arsan Athair Peadar O'Laoghaire.ConnachtAg coigilt na teine dheireadh an paidir seo - Coiglim an teine seoMar choigil Críost cách (pronounced? brean) ? Braighdhin ? na ? nduine agus Brighde'n a bpáirt.An taingeal is aoirde! Flaitheas nar  ngrástCumhduigh an tigh sei Agus na'daoine slán.

4602715/4597946/4631933.title: Prayer Going to Bed
4602715/4597946/4631933.text: Balinasloe - Page 104              Prayer Going to BedAs I lie down on my right side, I pray to God to be my guide.If any evil comes to me,that I might have my eyes to see.and my right hand to bless me.There are four corners on my bed,four blessed angels on thy(em) spread.Matthew, Mark, Luke and John.God bless this bed that I lie on.If I should die before I wake,Lord God my soul to take,Lord have mercy on us,Christ have mercy on us. AmenMrs. Ward,Creagh, KilgorrineBsloe

4602715/4597947/4631935.title: Prayer Going to Bed
4602715/4597947/4631935.text:
Prayer Going to BedI own Good Friday, I own Good Friday. It was on Good Friday. Our Savior was crucified. They platted a corona of thorns. They perched them on his head. The Jews they came with their spears so sharp and they pierced Our Savior through the heart. Whoever says this prayer by night on day neither death nor danger nor the gates of hell shall the ever enter.



May the will of God be done by usMay the death of the Saints be won by usand the lights of the kingdom begun in us
(continues on next page)

Night PrayerJesus be with me this night every stir and move I do that I may do so in honour of you Jesus. All for thee my Jesus sweet Jesus its you I do adore. Holy Blessed Virgin intercede to Jesus for me and keep me in sanctity and purity all the days of my life for Jesus sake. Amen.

There is a stone sitting on the level land on ODonnel's rock. It is about ten tons in weight. It was thrown from Benbow about three miles distant by a giant.



There are four corners in this bed. There are four angels lying spread. Father, Mathew, Luke and John. God bless this bed that I lie on. When I sleep if I happen never for to wake: To God I give my souls to keep.You will have a saint's curse if you put on one stocking and one boot. You must put on both stockings first. Then the boots.



On may eve Children and where there were none grown ups gathered marigolds (may flowers) or Mary's flowers and sprinkled them in and around the cowhouses, stables and piggeries to prevent diseases and bring good luck for the ensuing year.

4602748/4600839/4633564.title: Prayers
4602748/4600839/4633564.text: PrayersA nice prayer I heard of said by old people was when lighting the fire on lighting a candle lamps, or any light was "May God grant us the light of Heaven" When getting up or [?] out of bed they used to say "may  rise on the last day in external glory

4602748/4600840/4633568.title: Prayers
4602748/4600840/4633568.text: O God who through the labours       of Blesses Oliver Plunkit,Thy martyr and Bishop didst preserve the Irish people in the        catholic faith.Grant through his intercussion a       bundant favours and gracesSo that soon he may be        Glorified by thy churchWith the honour of canonization, Through Christ our Lord Amen

4602748/4600841/4633573.title: Prayers
4602748/4600841/4633573.text: Prayers.There are four corners on my bead there are four angels on it spread, one to watch two to pray, and one to carry my soul away.If I die before I wake, I pray that god my soul may take, Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. God bless the bed that I lie on.O Mary my mother, I place my undying trust in thee, that you will be there are my death - bed side, to take my soul safely to the feet of your Divine Son Jesus.

4602748/4600842/4633597.title: Prayers
4602748/4600842/4633597.text: Prayers.When the old people long ago used to meet one another they used to sayGod be with you.God direct you.God save you.God bless you and spare you the healthWhen any person would die the old people sayLord have mercy on her or his soul.When the old people go to bed they used to sayI must die I do not know when, nor where nor how but if I die in mortal sin I am lost forever.         O Jesus have mercy on me. AMEN.

Signs of good weather.A circle around the moon is a sign of storm. A circle close to the moon foretells a storm soon, a circle far out from the moon, a storm far off. The cat lying near the fire is a sign of storm.The sheep and goats come down from the mountain before storm.There are four corners on my bedThere are four angels at my headOne to watch, one to prayand two to bear my soul awayIn the name of our Lord Jesus Christ that was crucified I lay me down to rest. Bless me, O Lord, defend and govern me and after this short and miserable pilgrimage bring me to life everlasting. Amen. These prayers were said when going to bed.Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. Bless me on this bed

4602743/4600370/4634177.title: The Old Prayers
4602743/4600370/4634177.text: An old prayer.I got this prayer from my mother and she said she got it from her grandmother.There are four corners on my bed and four angels over head. Saint Matthew, Saint Luke, Saint Mark and St. John God bless this bed that I lie on. And if I die before I waken I give my soul to God to keep. God be my guide and mary be my flower and God be my guide at my last dying hour.This is to be said when you go into bed and it is said it was made by a man one night there was big wind and he thought the house would be blown up.By Kathleen A. McPartlin Meenymore N.S.

4602743/4600412/4634225.title: An Old Prayers
4602743/4600412/4634225.text: An Old Prayer.This is an old prayer that I heard from my mother and she heard it from her grand other.When I go into bed I fold my arms in the form of a cross and I say og my Jesus i have to die and i do not know when nor how nor where but if I die 'em mortal sin I am lost for all etrenity.By Brigid McPartlinMeenymore N.S.

4602758/4601789/4634363.title: Folklore - Old Prayers
4602758/4601789/4634363.text:
As I lie down on my right side to sleepI give my soul to God to keepIf any evil death or danger comes over meMary, Mary waken meHeaven the branch, and Mary the flowerAnd Jesus be with me in my dying hour.(said after lying down to sleep)As I get up this mornign dayThe Lord may keep me from going astrayThe Lord may keep me from sin and shameWherever I go wherever I beMy heart and soul I give to theeO Merciful Jesus have mercy on me (said on awakening)There is four corners on my bedThere is four angels over my spreadMatthew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless the bed that I lie on(Said when lying down to sleep)As I like down my right had side to sleepI give my soul to Christ to keepWaken now or waken neverI give my soul to Christ forever(This prayer is said in bed at night)

4602737/4599839/4634697.title: Old Sayings
4602737/4599839/4634697.text:
If you meet a red-haired woman, you will meet with ill-luck except you go back three steps and bless yourself with your left hand.



It is considered unlucky to begin any work on a Saturday.  It is considered lucky to set the first of the potatoes on Ash Wednesday.  It is considered unlucky to turn back from a journey, having once begun it.  If you wash your hands in the dew and dry them in the sun, you can open any knot.



The people formerly wore no shoes until they were about twenty years of age.  Some wore no shoes until they were getting married.  There is only one shoemaker in this district now.  My father remembers when there were six, all of whom were kept busy.  Edward Rooney, the local shoemaker does repair work chiefly, as practically all boots and shoes are bought in shops.

4602759/4601838/4634844.title: Prayers
4602759/4601838/4634844.text: Blessed spirits who surrounded the holy altars, Premit me to unite my self with you in the Homages which you render to the Sacred Heart of Jesus.  Vouchsafe to join with me in my prayers and by your love supply I beseech you whatever is wanted in me to honour worthily my Savour and my God.2Blessed be the hour in which the son of God was born of the most pure Virgin Mary at Midnight in Bethlehem in piercing cold.  O my God hear my prayers, grant my desire through the merits of our our Savour Jesus Christ and of his Blessed Mother Amen.IIIBless O Lord the repose I am now going to take, By renewing my bodily strength.  I will be better able to praise thee.  All ye holy Angels and saints especially thou, O Mother of God intercede for us this night but more particularly at the hour of our death Amen.

4602759/4601860/4634891.title: Prayers
4602759/4601860/4634891.text: Lord Jesus be pleased with the Father and the Holy Ghost to grant me thy Sacred Blessing.  Keep me always in Thy Grace Enable me always to willingly embrace thy most Holy will so that I may now, and at the hour of my death worthily with perfect Faith, Hope, and charity receive Thee the Bread of Angels.  This I implore through the merits of thy Precious Blood and of Thy Blessed Mother. Amen.God bless Good Friday and Good Friday it was, the day Our Saviour was crucified with a crown of thorns upon His Head.  Up came the Jews with their sharp spears and pierced Our Saviour from heart to hand.  Our Blessed Lady standing by with a heavy heart and a mournful cry.  He that says this prayer three times by day and three times by night neither death nor danger nor mortal sin or the gates of hell the poor soul shall not enter in.

We grow potatos on our land every year.  A half an acer is the largest amount of ground we put under potatos.  Sometimes we do not set a half an acer.  Some scatter lime on the ground before turning it up.  Some sow their potatos in drills and others in ridges.  You could not make ridges where
(continues on next page)

4602750/4601025/4642382.title: A Collection of Prayers
4602750/4601025/4642382.text: When I rise in the morning I say: "I will rise from this bed of sleep to adore and glorify my god" grant, o my Lord, that I will arise on the last day to life everlasting.Starting work."All for Thee my Lord, O my Jesus all for thee." Going on a journey:"May the Almighty and merciful Lord guide me on my way, that I may in peace, health and happiness return to my home."When sneezing I say:"God bless us and save us"Meeting a ghost: "God between us and harm" Taking a drink: "I take this drink in honour of Thee, O Lord, help me to take it"Going to bed: "As I go to bed I go to my grave, O, merciful Jesus, my soul for to save, Lord with the branch, Lady with the flower. O Merciful Jesus and Mary be with me at my dying hour.""Bless me O Lord, defend and govern me and after this short and miserable pilgrimage, bring me to everlasting happiness."When thunder and lighting is coming: "God protect us from harm."Going to bed at night."Ere I lay myself down to sleep, I give myself to Christ to keep. If danger overcomes me Blessed Virgin waken me. There are four on my bed, there are four angels that overspread - St. Matthew, Mark, St. Luke and John. God bless this bed that I lay on."

4605923/4602884/4643264.title: An Olden Prayer
4605923/4602884/4643264.text:
As I lie down my right-hand sideOh, Blessed Lady be my guidefor fear I sleep and not to wakeI give my soul to God to take.There are four corners round my bedThere are four Angels round my spreadMathew Mark St. Luke and JohnGod Bless this bed which I lie on.And our Saviour crucified from his head to his heart, from his heart to his hand from his hand to his foot. O Blessed Lady standing by with heavy heart and mournful cry. For those who bless Good Friday and honour Good Friday and those who shall say this 3 times a night shall be free from the gates of Hell.

Old Prayers(1) Lord be the bramble, Lady be with the flower, Jesus be with me in my dying hour.(2) Jesus my Saviour, my God my friend.In life and in death my soul defend.In joy and sorrow, in good and ill.Be thou my hope and protector still(3) Thus guarded in life and in death may I be,And Jesus be forever a Jesus to me(4) O sweetest heart of Jesus I implore,That I may ever love thee more and more(5) My joy, thy glory, my hope, thy name,Aimable Jesus my heart inflame,In virtues way all my steps direct,Powerful Jesus, my soul protect.Information received fromMrs CurneenDrumconnor(Age 12 years)Written byMargaret CurneenDrumconnorDromahair

Mary is the mark Jesus us the flowers and may they all be with me if I die in hour. Morning Prayer As I rise from this bed for love of thee Who did'st die on the cross for love of me. The folling prayer is to said before going to sleep at night. O Lord I must die I dont

know when, nor where, nor how soon but if I die in mortal sin I am lost for ever. Sacred Heart of Jesus have mercy on me.



The following prayer is to be said before going to sleep at night.Night is falling dear mother the long day is over and before thy loved image I am kneeling once more to thank thee for keeping me safe through the day to ask thee this night to keep all evil away. Many times have I fallen to-day Mother dear, many graces neglected since last I knelt here wilt thou not in pity my own Mother mild ask Jesus to pardon the sins of thy child and if ere the dawn I should draw my last breath and the sleep I take be the
(continues on next page)

4605931/4603492/4643793.title: A Prayer
4605931/4603492/4643793.text: Hail and blessed be the hour, and the moment in which the Son of God was born of the most pure Virgin Mary at mid-night at Bethlehem in piercing cold in that hour vouchsafe. O my God to hear my prayer and grant my desires through the merits of our Savour Jesus Christ and of his Blessed Mother amen.This prayer should be said during the advent of Christmas to gain special favours.

4602760/4602031/4643880.title: A Collection of Prayers
4602760/4602031/4643880.text:
1. O my God I awake from this bed of sleep to adore my God and to labour for the salvation of my soul.  O me I rise on the last day to life everlasting.To be said when dressing2. O great Saint Anthony apostle full of goodness.  Who hast received from God the privilege of causing lost objects to be found assist me at this moment that by your help I may obtain the favour I ask (mention it) that I may glorify more and more the Lord who operates by you such great and wonderful marvels. AmenTo be said if lost anything3. I adore thee O most precious cross which has been adorned with a tender desolate and venerable hands and feet of our dear Lord Jesus Christ and embraced with His precious blood.  I adore thee O Holy cross for the love of my Lord and God Jesus Christ.This prayer is to be said on every Friday.
(continues on next page)

4602760/4602033/4643882.title: A Collection of Prayers
4602760/4602033/4643882.text:
1. God bless Friday for it was on Good Friday our Saviour was crucified.  The cruel Jewes as they stood by pierced our Saviour from Heart to Hand and His Blessed Mother she stood by with her mournful talk and dismal cry.Anyone says this prayer three times by day and three times by night the gates of Hell they never shall enter or die in mortal sin or anyone belonging to them.2.  As I lie down on my right side,I pray to God to be my guide.If any vengeance happens me,Oh Blessed Lady awaken me.There are four corners on my bed.There are four angels o'er it spread.Mathew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless the bed that I lie on.This prayer is to be said when going to sleep at night.
(continues on next page)

4605935/4603834/4643912.title: Old Written Prayers in Drumkeeran District
4605935/4603834/4643912.text:
There are four corners on my bed,There are four angels to guard my stead,St Matthew, Mark, Luke , and John,Christ bless the bed that I like on,One to watch one to pray and two to carry my soul away.As I lay down my head to sleepI pray to God may soul to keepAnd if I die before I wakeI pray to God my soul to takeThese are common prayers in this district and are said by most of the old people when they lie down at night to sleep.
(continues on next page)

4613717/4611966/4643997.title: Prayers
4613717/4611966/4643997.text:
God bless Friday and Good Friday too.That's the day Our Saviour was crucified.A Jew passed by with a spear in his hand.And stuck Our Saviour through the heart.From the heart to the hand.His precious blood began to flow and as His tender mother was standing byWith the heavy heart and the dismal cry.Three times a day and three times a night.Who ever shall say these holy words.Shall never enter the gates of hell nor die in mortal
(continues on next page)

4605931/4603547/4644324.title: Prayer
4605931/4603547/4644324.text:
I rise myself up from this bed of sleep to adore my god and labour for the salvation of my soul. So may I rise on the last day to life everlasting. Clothe my soul with the Nuptial Robe of Charity and grant that I may wear it pure and undefiled before the judgement seat of Christ.



What is it that you cut a bit off to make it longer. A grave. Who may marry a wife and yet live single all his life. A clergyman. What is the best way to make a coat last. Make the trousers and vest first. What is it that a cat and no other animal has. Kittens. Why do you go to bed. Because the bed will not come to you. What is full of flesh and bones in the

4605938/4604014/4644986.title: Saint Brigid
4605938/4604014/4644986.text:
Saint Bridgid was very kind to the poor.  Once upon a time a man dressed himself up in disguise and went to her where she was minder sheep and begged a sheep from her flock. She gave him one and he brought him home to his pen and laughed at how he played the trick on her. He went back again in a different disguise and he played the same trick. Seven times he did this, and laughed to himself that night and rejoiced at the addition of seven sheep to his flock. When he god up the next morning and went to his pen the sheep had gone back to Saint Bridgid and there was no trace of how they went.
