4687698/4685102/4706974.text: Cailín a bhí ag obair i dtig Ministir, agus níor theastuig uatha í leigint chun an Aifrinn. D'fhiafruig an Sagart dí lá cad iad na paidreacha a deireadh sí, agus seo mar dubhairt sí:Dia am stiúradh Dia am theagasc, Dia am sheoladh ar gach bóthar chun mo leasa, Dia am sábháilt ar gach ócáid a dheineann an peaca is a Mhic Dé na Glóire tugaim suas duit m' anam.Paidir nuair a beithfá istig on tAifreann:Go dtuga Dia ár gcuidiú agus ár gceannaireacht do idhbhirt naomhtha an Aifrinn dúinn. D'úrnuighthe na hEaglaise agus do dheaghatharacha na bhfíoraon Ins gach áit na bhfuil siad ag adharú agus ag onórú. Ins gach teamhpall Caitlicí sin am.Le linn eirighe ar maidin duinn:Toil Dé go ndéanaimid Radharc Dé go bhfeicfimid Grásta Dé go bhfaighimid Ceol go bhflaitheas go gcloisimídAr Pháis Íosa go smaoínímídSiobhán Ní Laighin

4701661/4690499/4707050.title: Traditional Prayers
4701661/4690499/4707050.text:
Traditional prayers. 10 - -1939.O Merciful Jesus, Lover of Souls, I beseech Thee by the agony of Thy Most Holy heart, and the sorrows of Thy Immaculate Mother, to cleanse with Thy Precious Blood, sinners of the whole world who are now in their agony and about to die this day.Agonisinge Heart of Jesus, have mercy on the dying.As I lay on my bed asleepI give my soul to God to keep.And if i die before I wake,I trust the Lord my soul to take,O waken now! O waken ever!O! Lord receive my soul for ever,Holy Mary, Queen of Heaven,You are always kind to me,And when my trial does come on,I hope you pled for me,
(continues on next page)

4701661/4690500/4707053.title: Traditional Prayers
4701661/4690500/4707053.text:
(continued from previous page)
Lest I'd be turned away,No more Your Son to see,O! Holy Mary! Purest of Heart,I hope you plead for me.



As I lay down my head to sleep,I give my soul to God to keep,There are four corners on my bed.There are four angels overhead,Matthew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless this bed that I lie on,If I die before morning,Holy Mary come and take me.

4678389/4675508/4707474.title: Paidir le Rá roimh Chodladh
4678389/4675508/4707474.text: Luíghim ar an leabaidh seo mar a luighfheadh san uaigh. Deinim m'faoistin go cruaidh leat a Íosa Mhic Mhóire. Aspolóid a iarraim ort a Íosa Críosd. A Mhuire Mháthair a Mhaighdean ró naomhtha, tabhair dúinn radharc ar do theaghlach agus ar do mhór chómhacht. Solas na Soillse agus Radharc na Tríonóide grásta na foidhne i n-aghaidh na h-éagcórach. Cros na n-aingeal sa leabaidh 'na luíghfhead.Braon dá ngrásta  i lar an croídhe againn. Bratacha na bFlathas go leatthar 'nár dtímcheall a thógfaidh ceó na bpheacaí dhinne. Glaoidhim Dia mar Athair agus Muire mar Mháthair. Flathas Dé mar dhúthaig agus diúltuíghim do'n áirseóir. Tugaim suas m'anam ar mo leabaidh do'n Rígh Glórmhar, dá Máthair bheannuighthe , an bhanaltra sítheóilte , do's na aingil go léir i gcathair na Glóire, ár ngárdáil , ár sábháil, ár seóladh 's ag breith ár n-anam go cathair na Glóire.

4687717/4686903/4707861.title: Paidreacha
4687717/4686903/4707861.text: Dia 'm stiúradhDia 'm mhúineadh'S Dia 'm theagascDia 'm shábháilÓs gach áit go bhfuil a peacadhA Dhia glórmhar ós agat-sa na beartaCuir m'anam ar do dhead láimh, lán chátha.Beannuig me, Athair Mhic ÍosBeannuig me, Bhrighde bhreat bheannuightheBeannuigh me, teampail an Spioraid NaomhAgus benanuig me, reilicí an Aifrinn.

4701710/4694900/4708031.title: Old Prayers
4701710/4694900/4708031.text: Old Prayers O Mary my Mother, my refuge, and any hope, under they mantle I take protection. There will I live, there will I die. Grant thy holy blessing.Infant Jesus meek and mild pity me a little child. Jesus take my heart and bless it, that nothing evil may posses it.

4701710/4694923/4708065.title: An Old Prayer
4701710/4694923/4708065.text: Look down O Mother Mary,From Thy bright throne above.Cast down upon thy childrenOne only glance of love.And if a heart so tender.In pity flows not oer.Then turn away O Mother.And look on us no more.May little Jesus bless you thiscoming Xmas morning.May you be as glad as Marythe night that He was born.May all the joy of Joseph beglowing in your heart.May Angles songs be near youand never more depart.Told to me by my mother.

4701710/4694940/4708109.title: An Old Prayer
4701710/4694940/4708109.text: Look down O Mother Mary, From Thy bright throne above.Cast down upon they children. One only glance of love And if a heart so tender. In pity flows not oer. Then turn away O Mother And look on us no more.May little Jesus bless you this comming Xmas morning. May you be as glad Mary the night that He was born May all the joy of Joseph be glowing in your heart. May Angles songs be near you and never more depart.

4701658/4690686/4708361.title: Prayers
4701658/4690686/4708361.text:
1)There are four corners on my bedThere are four angels overheadMathew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless the bed that I lie on.2)Here I lie down to sleepI give my soul to God to keepIf I die before the morningThat the heavens may be my bed3)Heart of Jesus I adore theeHeart of Mary I implore theeHeart of Joseph pure and justIn these three hearts I put my trust4)Go bfuascailidh Mac Dé dhúinnIs go gcuididh Mac Dé dhúinn5)Jesus of Nazareth King of the JewsPreserve me from a sudden and unprovided death
(continues on next page)

4701735/4697367/4708508.title: Strange Animals
4701735/4697367/4708508.text:
(continued from previous page)
[details of informant]



Hail, O sacred Heart of Jesus, living and quickening source of eternal life, infinite treasury of the Divinity, burning furnace of divine love.  Thou art my refuge and my sanctuary. Oh my amiable Saviour, consume my heart with that burning fire with which Thine is ever inflamed, pour down on my soul those graces which flow from they love, and let my heart be so united with thine, what our wills may be one mine in all things conforms to thine. May thine be the standard and rule of my desires, and of mine actions amen

4701740/4697646/4713630.title: Old Prayers
4701740/4697646/4713630.text:
The old people of this district long ago were notes to be very religious and they used to always praising and Thanking God for his goodness. I will now give a list of all I know if there would be a new moon they used to join hands and say "God five us the light of heaven" as if a femur came in to a house and would not take lies the woman of the house wold address him in Irish and say "Qe, when putting down a fire or lighting a candle they used to say "God give us the lights of heaven" if the people of a house were them and a person is come in he would have to say "Good luck is the work" and "God bless your cows"before meals they used to say Thank god for this goodness when sneezing they used to say God Bless us when a person would be coming into a house he would say God save all here" When sneezing in the morning and undressing in the
(continues on next page)

4701668/4691454/4713940.title: Paidreacha
4701668/4691454/4713940.text:
(1)   " A Íosa na (neádure)?  na (nGiudar)?          na n-iudaigh...............................a mhic          (Dáibhí) ?..............déan trócaire  orainn"Peter McGowan,Kilmacannon,Cloughboley P.O.(2)   When lying down in bed:-"I must die, I don't knowWhen or how or where,But if I die in mortal sinI am lost for ever.Sweet Jesus, have mercy on me".(3)   When dressing:-"I offer Thee all my thoughts, words and actions of this day, that they may be wholly consecrated to Thee", that they may procure for me Thy holy love which is all I desire.Mrs Walsh Cloughboley
(continues on next page)

4701668/4691465/4713964.title: Paidreacha
4701668/4691465/4713964.text: When rising out of bed:- I arise this day Jesus, Guard me against all evil temptation and help me to be in the state of grace for ever".

4701735/4697368/4714451.title: Prayers
4701735/4697368/4714451.text:
This prayer was told to me by my mother, she told me it is said in the prayer the time to say it. It is as follows -Twas on good Friday morning a day before noon, to pierce our poor Saviour through the Heart our Blessed Mother standing by a heavy sign and a morn for cry, anybody who says this prayer three time by night. Three times by day shall never die with a mortal sin upon their souls or the flames of hell shall never enter in.



St Peter sat on a marble stone, Jesus came to home and asked what aols you Peter. Peter answering said I'm troubled with the toothache. Jesus said, arise and thou shalt I heal. Anybody who says this prayer in remembrance of me shall never be troubled with the toothache.
(continues on next page)

Mary the virgin of virgins, I beseech thee. I conjure thee through Jesus and Mary obtain for me that being preserved from all stain pure of heart and chaste of body. I may constantly serve Jesus and Mary in perfect chastity.



When I am dying how glad I shall be, that the lamp of light, has burned for thee.That sorrow has darkened the path way I trod. That thorns, not roses, were stern over the sod. Since anguish of spirit, so often was thine. Amen this prayer is to be waid when you are dying.

4701743/4698038/4714592.title: Prayers
4701743/4698038/4714592.text: The golden cord through every moment of this day be with me, Lord, Through every day of this week, be with me, Lord. Through every week of all this year be with me, Lord. So that when time has past, I will be with thee, Lord".

4701736/4697422/4714792.title: A Prayer - My Crucifix
4701736/4697422/4714792.text:
A Little Metal CrucifixAs plain as it can be.And only God in Heaven knowsHow dear it is to me. I have it always with meIn every step I take,At evening when I slumberAnd at Morning when I wake. In bright or cloudy weather,In sunshine or in rain, In happiness or in sorrow, In pleasure or in pain.In days of pain and anguishThe greatest thing I knewWas to look at that dear CrucifixUntil I calmer grew. And looking on that figureWhich hung in patience there, I saw the dreadful tortureWhich he in Love did bear.
(continues on next page)

4701736/4697424/4714793.title: Paidir
4701736/4697424/4714793.text:
Sé lúan an tsléibhe lainne, léan sgrios.Luan é is iomadh faoi gruamTuitheann t-aer anuas ar féar glasLasann spéar - spear úr ghá dhóghadhAr an darna buille an sciuth ba áidhbheilBeidh gach éin dhá bhfuil marbh beóBeidh gach anam glé-geal ins gach colann bréagachO Sliabh na Gloisigh go Sliabh na mBanIsligh anuas, a pheachadh, truaigh do'n ár gcruaidh no tá ar tallIs minic a luadhamar Mac Dé go h-uaibhreach is gan do chuid sin.Tiocfaidh fiú de seo dul i n-úireIs an bhrisigh rúinn as reibh ar chillBeidh gach anam glé-geal ins gach colann bréagachO Sliabh na Gloisigh go Sliabh na mbanTré rádh na n-aoinneach a dtiofaidh mé treanasachNach raibh dom beann mo cumacht go fuacht na sleibhteNa cathair maoilreach, acht amhainSíl ceil ciall asail ruaidh.Siubhalfaidh mé sléibhte ar brighidh go léír leacDo sa bhfuil ar Herod is mé luigh an t-siubhalO Mathair glé-geal tá do cian déantabeir leat i m'eadan cuartú an domhain.
(continues on next page)

4701750/4699011/4723783.title: A Collection of Prayers
4701750/4699011/4723783.text: "God bless Good Friday and Friday too.It was on Good Friday Our Saviour was crucified.The wicked Jews were standing byPierced Our Saviour to the heart and hand,His blessed blood began to flow.His blessed mother was standing by with a mournful look and a dismal sigh."Anyone who says this prayer three times a day, three times a night shall never enter into the Gates of Hell. This prayer should be said going to bed at night and getting up in the morning.

4701750/4699012/4723785.title: A Collection of Prayers
4701750/4699012/4723785.text:
This is a prayer which never came from a book. This prayer has to be said going to bed."In the name of Our Lord Jesus Christ crucifiedI lay me down to rest, bless me O Lord, defend and govern me that after this short and miserable pilgrimage, bring me to the everlasting life Amen."That prayer was never learned in school or never came from a book. It was an old woman about 80 years that used say this every night. I do not know her name.



An old woman that was living in an old barn in my
(continues on next page)

4701750/4699012/4723787.text:

It was an old woman about 80 years that used say this every night. I do not know her name.



An old woman that was living in an old barn in my

4701750/4699013/4723789.text:
(continued from previous page)
district used to say this prayer at night."O Dear Jesus I love youKeep me safe under lock or keyAnd if anything comes near me that I'll either hear or seeO! God bless me."Some children that were passing stood listening and they heard her shouting out the prayer.



Lord Jesus dying in the gallas tree for my sins.Holy cross see me in thoughtward off from me all weapons of danger,Lord Jesus Christ through your suffering in the cross give me grave to carry my cross patiently
(continues on next page)

4701750/4699014/4723792.title: A Collection of Prayers
4701750/4699014/4723792.text:
(continued from previous page)
when I suffer without complainingThrough my sufferings I may escape all danger now and forever. This prayer is said in the time of danger.



As I went into the chapel doorI laid my sins outside the door.I met the Blessed Virgin with seven blessed book's in her hand.Seven priests singing, seven bells  ringing close the gates of (Heaven) Hell and open the gates of Heaven, and let all the poor souls in Jesus by the branch and Mary by flower. Amen
(continues on next page)

4725004/4699222/4724066.title: A Collection of Prayers
4725004/4699222/4724066.text:
"There are four corners on my bedThere are four angels on them spreadMatthew, Mark, Luke, and JohnGod bless the bed that I lay onIf I die before I wakeI leave my sould to God to takeIf I die before I sleep,I leave my soul to God to keep"Another Prayer"O merciful Jesus have mercy on mefive bleeding wounds nailed to a tree.O merciful Jesus have mercy on me,my soul and my body resigned to thee"Another Prayer"May I meet the Blessed VirginIn the Blessed Land
(continues on next page)

4701745/4698553/4724531.title: A Collection of Prayers
4701745/4698553/4724531.text:
There is a prayer said when going to bed at night, which I learned at home with my mother.Night Prayer.Night is falling,dear mother,and this long day is oer,And before Thy loved image, I am kneeling once more;To thank Thee for keeping me safe till this day,To ask you this night to keep evil away.Many times have I fallen to-day Mother dear,Many graces neglected since,last I knelt here,Be Thou not in pity, O Mother, dear,mild;Oh, Jesus, pardon the sins of thy childFor I am going to rest for this days work is done,Its hours and its moments have passed one by one And the God who will judge me,has counted them all,He has numbered each grace and
(continues on next page)

4701745/4698573/4724556.title: Riddles
4701745/4698573/4724556.text:
(continued from previous page)
It has no doors or windowsTo let me in to eat (An egg)



God bless Friday and Hood Friday tooAnd Friday our Saviour was crucified on. He was nailed to a cross and the Jews came in with sharp swords and they spread thorns on his head and pressed them down till His temples bled.He was pieced from the head to the hand and from the hand to the side and His precious blood came in flows. His Blessed Mother was standing by with a mournful sigh and a dismal cry.Anyone who says this prayer three times by day and three times by night shall never die in mortal sin, nor danger nor deadly sin, nor the dates of Hell you shall never enter in. And when you die Jesus, Mary and Joseph standing by at your bedside.

4701749/4698707/4725017.title: Prayer
4701749/4698707/4725017.text: O holy and glorious Virgin Mary. I commit my soul and body to thy Blessed care this night and for ever, but especially at the hour of my death. I commend to thy merciful charity, all my hopes and consolation, all my distress and misery, my life and my death, that by thy most holy intercession, all my works may be directed according to the will and to the glory of thy Blessed Son.

4706331/4703389/4725028.title: A Collection of Prayers
4706331/4703389/4725028.text:
Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, God bless the bed that I lay on. In this bed I lay to sleep, to God I give my soul to keep. If I die before I wake I pray to God my soul to take. There are four corners on my bed, there are four angels at my head. One to guard me, one to guide and two to carry my soul away. In the name of Our Lord, Jesus Christ, crucified. I lay myself down to rest, and grant me that after this short and miserable pilgrimage bring me to life everlasting happiness.



1. Frog in Middle = One girl stands in the middle, and all the others stand round her, and they all say "Frog in the middle don't bite us" and so on. If the girl in the middle catches one she will be frog in the middle then. 2. Tig = One girl says "tig" to the other, tips her and runs after
(continues on next page)

4706331/4703403/4725044.title: A Collection of Prayers
4706331/4703403/4725044.text: When awaking in the morning say, Oh my God I offer you my heart, and my soul, and my body. Oh teach me to love you in time and in eternity.When arising.Oh my God I rise from this bed of sleep to adore you and to labour for the salvation of my soul. Oh! may I rise on the Last Day to Life Everlasting Amen.When Dressing.Oh my lord clothe my soul with the nuptial robe of charity grant that I may wear it pure, and undefiled till I go to the judgment seat of Christ Amen.Then the morning prayers.

4701749/4698742/4725111.title: A Collection of Prayers
4701749/4698742/4725111.text:
A Collection of Prayers.[-]on Awakening.O my Lord Jesus, I give Thee my heart Praise, honour and glory be to Thee for every and ever Amen.Getting out of bed.I raise myself from this bed to adore Thee O God and to labour for the salvation of my soul. O Sweet Jesus, I hope to rise again on the Last Day into life everlasting.
(continues on next page)

4701749/4698746/4725122.title: Prayers
4701749/4698746/4725122.text:
Prayers[-]When RisingOh my God! I will rise from this bed of sleep to adore my God, and to labour for the salvation of my soul. May I arise on the Last Day to Life EverlastingWhen DressingOh my God clothe my soul with the nuptial robe of charity and grant that I may wear it pure and undefiled before the Judgement Seat of Christ
(continues on next page)

4706331/4703433/4725197.title: Food in Olden Times
4706331/4703433/4725197.text:
(continued from previous page)
eating.the windows they had were made from the Skin of sheep tacked on to the frame. Out of flax they made all their or house hold linen and wearables and out of the goat's tallow they own candles.

Críost liom,Críost romham,Críost im'dhiaidh,Críost ionnam,Críost fúm,Críost ós mo chionn,Críost do m'láimh dheis,Críost do m'láimh chlé,Críost í leithead,Críost í bfaid,Críost in aoirde,Críost i gcroidhe gach éinne smaoineas orm.



Beannuighim romham sa tigh seo isteach,Agus duitse féin, a Chrann aoibhinn deas,Na peacaí a thugas sa tigh seo isteach,Go dtógaibh Dia díom iad sul a gheobhaidh mé amach,Ó, a Thigearna, is ' dtí Tú a tháinig mé,Chun deoch a d'fhagháilt as tobar na daonnachta.Brarn det' Fhuil as Do tharbh dheasDéanfadh sí sinn a ghealadh is a glanadh, is a shaoradh,Is do thabharfadh ar n-anam gan ainimh in t'fhéachaint.

4701766/4700991/4725287.title: Religious Stories
4701766/4700991/4725287.text:
(continued from previous page)
cattle and piles of money. Their cattle were dying one by one. Money and cattle were going, so in an year the crows were in and out the window.



In the Name of the Father for successAnd of the Son who suffered painMay Mary and her Son be with me on my wayOh Mary meet me at the shoreLet not my soul go by theeGreat is my fear of thy sonIn the Communion of Saints may we beListening to the voices of the Angels and praising the Son of God world without end.Amen

4725689/4687662/4725378.title: Paidreacha
4725689/4687662/4725378.text:
Do réir Dé do deinim éBeatha na naomh do duile méCéolar na n-Aingeal do chloisim éAgus soille na bhFlathas do feicim éSolas na soille agus radharc na TríneóideAgus grásta na foidhne in ionad na éagcóire.Seo paidir a deireadh na sean-daoine nuair a bhídh tromlaidhe ortha :-Anna mhátair Mhuire agus Muire Mháthair CríostCuirim an triúr san agus an crann ar crocadh Críost.Idir mé agus tromlaidhe agus gach olc eile atá ar mo shuidhe.Bríd Ní Shúileabháin,Cromán Uachtar.



Ofráilim duit arís, a Thíghearna an íodbairt naomhtha so, íodhbairt fola agus t-éin Mhic ar son na h-anam atá imthighte ar an tsiorraidheacht agus go hairithe ar son mo mhuinntire fein an méid atá tar eis bháis ar mo son mo chomhfhoguir ghaoil mo comaointeóirí agus mo cómharsan.Siobhán Ní Teacháin,Cromán Iochtar,Cill-Orglan.

4725689/4687663/4725398.title: Paidreacha
4725689/4687663/4725398.text:
Micheal Naomhtha go neamh fiar t-ainm agus o naomh baiste grainte. Nuair a beadh a shiul a dhunadh agus a beul a leatha agus a mheabhair ag imtheacht chun fain uain an liost da glaodaidh agus an treimse caitthe agus Dia leis an aman an la san.



Is e seo paidir a deireadh na sean daoine nuair a biodh siad amuich sa pairc ag obair agus nuair a bhi an la criochnuighthe.Go fagadh Dia ar saoghal ata slainte againnIrid do meid sin do hocain bliain orainnAgus do cuirig Dia rath ar ar saothar



Nuair a théighimid go dtí an t-Aifreann. Nuair a theighimid có fada go dtí dorus an t-séipeal diarmíd ar ar Slánathoir Íosa Críost gan a bpeacaí leigint linn i dtig Dia. Nuair a téigimíd isteach cois i dirimíd sin féin agus annsan téighimid in ár glúna agus deirimíd ár bpaidreacha agus bimíd ag éisteacht leis an Aifreann agus an sagart a léigheamh agus agus bimid go léir ag feuchaint
(continues on next page)

4725689/4687666/4725463.title: Paidreacha
4725689/4687666/4725463.text: PaidreacaGo mbeannuighthe duit a Peadar gealGo mbeannuighthe duit féin cá codailís aréir mar a codal mac Dé.Cá codluigheadh anocht mar a codal na bocht.Cá coduigheadh oidhche ambárach mar a codal Naomh Pádruig.Cá codluigheadh is oidhche mainitir i bairithis.Céadta rómhat atá na n-Aingeal.Céadta na dhiadh atá na n-Aispaig.Tug Máire dhosa chun a gailt a dith amach agus annsan go dorus fairiteas.Táir a Bhrigde is trom do láimh.Tháinig na brat le gé láim bhinn boga Dia.Dith sí sceac ó anocht go bliain anocht agus anocht amháin le Dia.Máire Ní Réaghla.Cromán Iochtar.

4701768/4701064/4725772.title: A Collection of Prayers
4701768/4701064/4725772.text:
1. Oh! my God, you are a thousand times welcome into my house to - day. Hide me in a corner of yours and never let me be put out by commiting sin. 2. As I lay on this bed to sleep it is to God Iwill give my soul to take and if any bad thing comes this way God and his Blessed mother come and waken me.3. There are four corners on my bed, four angels on it spread, Matthew, Mark Luke and John, God bless this bed that I lay on.4. As I lay on my right - hand
(continues on next page)

4706330/4703167/4725978.title: Prayers
4706330/4703167/4725978.text:
Now I lay down to sleepTo God I give my soul to keepIf I should die before I wake To God I give my soul to takeThere are four corners in my bedOne to guard me one to guide me And two to carry my soul to heaven safe. Amen. St. Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John. God bless the bed that I lay on, It was on Good Friday the Jews came They sharpened a lance, and piercedour Saviour through the heartIt's through the heart, and through the side Our Blessed Mother standing by, With a sorrowful heart and mournful
(continues on next page)

4706330/4703169/4725981.title: Old Prayers
4706330/4703169/4725981.text: I N R I These letters stand for Jesus of Nazareth King of the jews. Keep me from sudden and unprepared death. In olden times when people got a pain in their side, this is the prayer they recited, and immediately making the sign of the cross over the part that pained.

4701659/4690333/4726018.title: A Collection of Prayers
4701659/4690333/4726018.text:
A Collection of Prayers.18-7-'38.There are for corners on my bed, there are four Angels over hear. Mathew, Mark, Luke and John God bless the bed that I ly on.Live Jesus live and let it be my life to die for love of Thee.Jesus be the stalk Mary be the flower, Jesus Mary and Joseph be with me at my dying hour.Infant Jesus meek and mild, pity me a little child. Pity me and pity mine suffer me to come to thee. heart of Mary I implore Thee. Heart of Jesus I adore Thee. Heart of Joseph pure and just. In these three hearts I place my trust.Jesus assist me. Mary give me power. Jesus, and Mary protect me every hour.O, my Jesus give me patience, My Mother Mary restrain my tongue.
(continues on next page)

4701676/4691992/4726138.title: (no title)
4701676/4691992/4726138.text: A Prayer said by Grand-mother during the '80s. She was then over 80 yrs. As I lie down on my right sideI pray to God to be my guide,There are four corners on my bed.There are four angels on it spread. Matthew, Mark, Luke and John, God bless this bed that I lie on. If any hurt or harm should come across meThat the B.V. Mary may come and waken me. If I am dead or asleepI leave my soul to God to keep

4706361/4706241/4726736.title: An Old Prayer and Song
4706361/4706241/4726736.text:
An old prayer and songThe very first joy our Lady had it was the joy of one, it was the joy of her own dear Son when He was born man.The very next joy our Lady had,it was the joy of twoIt was the joy of her own dear Son when He taught us what to do.The very next joy our Lady hadit was the joy of threeIt was the joy of her own dear Sonwhen He made the blind to see.The very next joy our Lady hadit was the joy of four,It was the joy of her own dear Son, when he begged from door to door.The very next joy our Lady had it was the joy of five, It was the joy of her own dear Son when He raised the dead to life.The very next joy our Lady had it was the joy of six, It was the joy of her own dear Son when he cured the sore and sick.
(continues on next page)

4701757/4699974/4726804.title: A Collection of Prayers
4701757/4699974/4726804.text: These are some old prayers. This is one which is said in the morning. "O Jesus in the blessed sacrament of the holy alter we offer thee the prayers, works and sufferings of this day. We offer them to thee for the intentions of thy divine heart and especially for greater devotion to our guardian angel and to those that are dying without the last sacrament and for the Pope's intentions. This is another prayer which is said after the rosary. "Heart of Jesus we adore thee, Heart of Mary we implore thee, Heart of Joseph pure and trust in those three heart we place our trust. There is another prayer which is said when going to bed. "I lay my body down to sleep, I give to God my soul to keep and if I die before I wake, I pray to God my soul to take. There are four corners on my bed. There are four angels on this spread. Mathew, Mark, Luke and John. God bless this bed that I lie on.Collected by: Bridie Cawley, HarristownHeard from her father M. Cawley

4701757/4699975/4726807.title: A Collection of Prayers
4701757/4699975/4726807.text:
Long ago the old people had beautiful prayers. None of these prayers were ever seen in books or in Prayer books. The old people learned these prayers and they taught them to the younger ones. These are some of the old prayers. This prayer is to be said when late for Mass. "O My God I wish to be present at the adorable sacrifice of the Mass, If I cannot assits spiritualy at all the Masses that are said throught the whole world. I unite my intentions with Thy holy ministers in offering up the adorable sacrifice for the same intentions that Our Lord offered himself on Mt. Calvery, And with it too I offer all the works I am going to perform this day. Sanctify them O Lord and make them redowned to Thy Glory, Sweet Jesus, Amen." This is a prayer which is to be said in the morning. "O Almighty and most Gracious Lord regard our prayers and deliver our hearts from the
(continues on next page)

4701758/4699999/4726899.title: Prayers
4701758/4699999/4726899.text:
1(To be said night and morning)Welcome Friday, Good Friday, tooThe day our Lord was crucified,His blessed Mother standing byWith a broken heart and mournful  cryWhosoever says this prayer, three times by night,And three times by dayAnd they shall never die in the state of sinThe gates of hell shall never open for them.



II To be said every morning.O most holy and Immaculate Mother of God glorious Saint Joseph guardians and patrons of our house and Union intercede for us our devoted children  now and at the hour of our death Amen.

A nun in the Mercy Convent , Sligo , learned the following prayers from her grandmother a native of the Galway Gaedhealtacht.Ag coigilt na teine  Coiglim an teine seo Mar choigil Críost cách Brighid fé n-a bun, Is Mac Mhuire ‘ n-a lár ,Na trí Aingle is mí cumhachtaI gCuirt na nGrástAg cumhdach ‘s ag coimeád an tigh seo‘Sa mhuinntir go lá .( Ag luighe )Go luighim le Dia      Is go luighidh Dia liomNár luigheadh leis an  olcIs nár luigheadh an t-olc liom .Crios Bhrigide fé mo lár Brat Mhuire fé mo cheann Tar, a Mhichil oigh is glac mo lámh Is dean mo shíochthan le Mac na nGrást.Má tá droch-nidh ar bith in mo dhiaidh-séCuirim Mac Dé idir mé féin Agus é féin

4701682/4692407/4727377.title: Prayers in English
4701682/4692407/4727377.text:
Prayers in English1. Prayer to be said in time of pain or sicknessThis prayer was taught by a poor old woman, a patient in the Mater Hospital,Belfast, in 1906Name and address of woman unknown"Merciful Jesus! have mercy on me,My soul and my body I resign to Thee;By those Five Bleeding Wounds nailed to a tree,Merciful Jesus! have mercy on me."2. Prayer to be said before going to sleep."As I lay down my head to rest,I place it on sweet Mary's Breast,As Jesus did when he was young,The Blessed Virgin's only Son."3. Prayer to be said before going to sleep."As I lie down upon my side,I pray to God to be my guide;If any evil comes to meThat I may have my eyes to see,And my right hand to bless me -Saying, "In the name of the Father , and of the Son,

Ámen.Ag Dul ar TurasAr choimrighe Dé is Mhic Duach is Mhic Dara thú , is go dtugaidh siad slán abaile thú.Aisling MhuireCodladh seo ort , a Mháthair?Ní h-eadh, a Mhic na Páiste , acht aislingCé'n aisling í féin , a Mháthair?Go bhfuil tusa ' do sciúrsáil.Bo chúinnéail, ' do cheangail do postaibh cloiche glaise,Go bhfuil do chuid fola céasta in a sruthán leat síos."Is fíor sin , a Mháthair. Ar té a dearfadh  t'aisling trí  h-uaire ar luighe dhó , ní baoghlach dó pianta

4701759/4700138/4727398.title: Collection of Prayers
4701759/4700138/4727398.text:
God bless this Friday and good Friday too.And the Friday Our Saviour wascrucified on the Cross.With a crown of thorns on hishead.They pressed them down till histemples bled.The Jews came in with theirsharp swords.And pierced Him through fromthe heart to the hand.His precious Blood began to flowHis Blessed mother standing byWith a heavy sign and a mournful cry.Anyone says this prayer.three times by night three times.by day.Never shall die in mortal sin.Or the gates of hell theynever shall enter in.Jesus, Mary and Joseph be withme at my dying hour.
(continues on next page)

Bhí sé istig sa bhaile ar fead leath úair an chluig núair a tháinig an tréan isteach. Do cheannuig sé an crúisgín ar dhá phinghin agus as bráth leis abaile arís. Deritear go bhféidir leis siubhal níos tapamhla na aoine eile i gCíarraidhe.



Nuair a bhíodh muinntir an tighe ag coighilt na teine badh gnáth leó an páidir seo do radh. Coigilimís an teine mar do choigil  Críost cách. Muire, i gceann an tighe agus Brighid in a lár, agus an dá naomh is mó cómhachta ins na Flaithis dár saoradh is dár sábhail go maidin*   *   *Núair a bhíthear ag ól deoch uisge taireis comaoine do ghlacadh is gnáthach an paidir seo do rádh:-Seo é sláinnte ár Slánuightheóra a cheannuig go daor sin,Is sláinte na mná mánla go raibh aici an t-aon mhac gan chéilleIs sláinte naoimh Pádrauig do bheannuig Éire(an seóladh ceadhna)

4706361/4706287/4728258.title: (no title)
4706361/4706287/4728258.text:
Long ago the children were about 10 years old before they wore shoes. They were not like those we have now. The soles of them were made of pork. They had to be very careful not to go near the fire as the soles of them would melt.The boy's used to wear dresses and bibs until they were about 12 years of age and at that time they started to go to Mass.The old men and women of the better class used to be beautifully dressed on Sunday. They used to wear pressed flannel petticoats and brown tamin gowns trimmed with velvet.



Good night dearest mother,The day's work is done,Its hours and its momentsHave passed one by oneMany time's have I fallenTo day Mother dearMany graces neglectedSince I last knelt here
(continues on next page)

4713241/4710709/4728285.title: Collection of Prayers
4713241/4710709/4728285.text:
Old people had very many beautiful prayers which never appeared in print.On awaking in the morning they sayJesus I offer you all I shall do, think or say today.Before work they sayMy God I do this because it pleases YouBefore lessons:-May God the Holy Ghost give me light to learn this.Before play:-Dear angel be with me that I may be safe from harm and sin
(continues on next page)

4706355/4705506/4728527.title: Collection of Prayers

4701688/4692714/4728620.title: Prayers for Rounds
4701688/4692714/4728620.text: 309Prayers for "Rounds"Take off your shoes and stockings and walk to the altar.* Say 5 Paters, 5 Aves, 5 Glorias at the altar, the same over at the well and the same at the Mass Rock (one round) cross the stream*Repeat *   * twice.Over well say 7 Paters, 7 Aves, 7 Glorias.Return to the altar and recite the Rosary - 15 mysteries.

4759290/4694144/4742258.text:
1) When you would rise in the morning:In ainm an Athair, agus an Mhic, agus an Spioraid Naomh. Coinnéal libh saor ar gach díombáidh an lae2) Ag dul ar aistear:Coinnéal ar an gcasán ceart a Dhia.3) Ag dul go obair:Bailigh ó Dhia, Pádhraic agus Muire orrainn.4) When the first  " braird "   comes:Go mbéidmíd beo ar an am seo arís, faoi shaoghail agus sláinte, agus trócaire na ngrásta5) When you would hear the Cuckoo; In ainm an Athair, agus an Mhic agus an Spioraid Naomh, go mbéidmíd chomh fearr an bhlian seo chugainn is atámíd anois.6) When the Clock strikes;   In ainm an Athair agus an Mhic, agus Spioraid Naomh, go mbéidhmíd sláinteamhail an uair seo ambáireach.7) When going into the Church, you shake the Holy Water on yourself, and say:" Ó Uisce na grásta, slán ar  ár anama in aghaidh na heanchoin, agus na heirchoide,  le Dhia agus Mhaidin ar sábhál ar sceithe, ar scannradh, agus ar námhaid ainm agus cuirp.8) When anything valuable would die: They
(continues on next page)

4713252/4711574/4743118.title: Paidreacha
4713252/4711574/4743118.text:
Paidreacha1.Luighim ar an leabaidh seo mar luighim insan uaigh.Faoisdin go cruaidh le Dia.‘Nois atáim ag iarraidh na h-asblóide ort.A Mhuire Mheidhreach agus Mhaighdin GhlórmharTabhair dom radhairc ar do theighleach agus ar do mhór-cómhachta.Solas na soillse agus radharc na tríonóide Agus grásta na foidhne in aghaidh na h-éagcóra.2.Tháinig triúr ban chúilfionn caomh a’ fiosrú uagha mo mhór-chorp CríostIs iad ag moladh glóire Dé go h-árdNa Iúdaigh.   Fág annsan é.  Níl aon nídh ar a chumas go dtí go n-eirighidh an t-éinín atá ar íochtar a chuirid go bhfuilid ann agus na fiacha le deich mblíana fichid.11.D’éirigh an t-éinín go bríoghamhail uasal ar uachtar a chuirid.  Agus do scread a dhá sciathán agus do ghéill Mhach Mhuire.111.
(continues on next page)

4701714/4695334/4743175.title: Collection of Prayers
4701714/4695334/4743175.text:
My God I offer thee this day. All I shall do or think or say. Uniting it with what was done. On earth by Jesus Christ the son. I make this offering for the souls. That Gods own Mother would release.That she may place them near her son.In everlasting rest and peace.If Mary bless thy child to-day and guide me on my heavenward way.Heart of Jesus I adore theeHeart of Mary I implore thee.Heart of Joseph pure and just.In those three hearts I put my trust.When Our Lord and Saviour came to the cross.
(continues on next page)

4713252/4711663/4743409.title: Paidreacha
4713252/4711663/4743409.text: PaidreachaEactraig dom agus ná eactraig bréag.  Cé h-iad san na daoine atá le daoradh?  Luct bréannta agsu luct peachaigAgus lucht na mionna móraAtá ar slabhra ceangailteAgus nách daor é an dtoisc?Ainm an duine ó’n a bhfuaras an paidir.Tomás Ó Donncada, Cúlbáin, Lios-a-phúcaAinm an chailín a fuair an sgéalLuighseach Ní ClaochlaidheSáoirse, Faithche, Lios-a-phúca.

4713252/4711675/4743454.title: Paidir
4713252/4711675/4743454.text: Paidir“A Thighearna caith síar ar an locht mé is ná tabhair aníar arís go Nodhlag mé.”  Deireann duine é sin nuair a bhíonn sé spíannta caithte amach.  An bhochtaineacht ní molann is ní cáinim í ach an té a mholfadh liom – sa bochtaineacht aige a b’fhearr liom í.”  Trí buadha an chuit:-  Ciúineas coisidheachta; radharc san oidhche; dearmhad bean an tíghe.Trí droch-nósa:-  Ag ól an ghloinne, ag caitheamh an phíopa, agus ag leagadh na drúchta, go mall san oidhche.Ceithre gnóthaí gan tairbhe:-  Ag ardúghadh teine ar loch; ag cruinniú cloch an chuain; comhairle do mhnaoi bhuirb nó buile duirn ar íarann fhuar. Ainm an duine ó’n a bhfuaras íad:-Seán Ó Cathasaig (nách maireann)Sráid Árd, Cíll – Áirne
4713252/4711675/4743454.school_info: School: Clochar na Trócaire, Cill Áirne

4713252/4711689/4743524.title: Paidreacha
4713252/4711689/4743524.text:
Paidreacha1.	Grásta Dé chúgham is pinginí airgid!2.	Go gcuiridh Dia ‘na leabhar thú agus nar bainfidh an domhan as tú!3.	Grásta Dé chúghainn is adbhar léine anairhte.4.	Dé bheatha féin agus do t-ualach!5.	Nár agraidh Día orm é!6.	Beannacht Dé le h-anaman  na marbh agus le h-anam na marbaibh caitlicí an domhain mar a n-órduigheann Dia agus an Eaglais dúinn guidhe ortha! 7.	Coigilim an teine seo mar choigileann Día cách.  Muire dá gceann an tighe againn agus Bríd na lár. A bhfuil d’aingealaibh is d’aspalaibh i gcathair Íosa.  Ag cóinleacht an tighe seo, agus an  líon-tighe go lá! 8.	Cabhair, agus grásta, agus cáirde ó Dhia cúghainn.  Cabhair gach lá atáim ‘dá íarraidh.  Sacraimínt na h-aithridhe ‘gus neartuighídh Dia linn.  Cómraide m’anamha ort, A Mhuire Maighdean Thíghearna!
(continues on next page)

4713252/4711694/4743562.title: Paidreacha
4713252/4711694/4743562.text: PaidreachaMíle moladh leat a Thíghearna Dhia an té a thug an beatha sin d’ár gcolann.  Go dtugaidh sé glóire na bhflathas dá’r n-anam.A Íosa mhilis éist mo chasaoid.Solas na bhflaithis go bhfaighaidh m’anam.Imtheóchaidh an fuiseóg is áinle ar sliabh.Imtheóchaidh an duine óg agus a cáil na dhiaidh.Imtheóchaidh a bhfuil agus a tháinig riamhAc ní Imtheóchaidh na grásta ó Dia.Grásta Dé chughainn agus pinginí airgid.Dia na Grásta agus go mba cumaoin le Dia sinnGo gcuirid Dia ‘na leabhar tú agus nár bainidh an domhain as tú.Ainm an duine ó’n a bhfuaras é seo:-Bean Uí Shúilleabháin, Túr Nóna, Gníomh-go-leith.
4713252/4711694/4743562.school_info: School: Clochar na Trócaire, Cill Áirne

4723819/4716125/4743734.title: A Fairy Tale
4723819/4716125/4743734.text:
(continued from previous page)
and from the day he did this to the day he died he was disabled.



When people would come into the house they used to say "God save all here". When people would get milk in any house they would say "God bless your cows". When people would get tea in any house they would say, "That your giving hand may never fail". When people went out for the first time in the morning they would say "God bless the crops".

4723819/4716135/4743743.title: Old Prayers
4723819/4716135/4743743.text:
When people were kindling the fire they would say "O God give me all in the house, the grace to be able to stand against all temptations, and so save us from the flames of hell". When people were sick or in pain they would say "O God who died and suffered so much for me on Calvary, Grant me ease. When sweeping the floor they would say "O Mary who swept at Nazareth, keep me from all harm and on the right road to Heaven. When scrubbing the table they would say "O Holy Virgin, keep
(continues on next page)

4701726/4696452/4743834.title: Prayer
4701726/4696452/4743834.text:
God bless good Friday and Friday too the day our blessed Saviour was crucified by the wicket Jews. They pressed a crown of throns on his head. The Jews came with the bloody spears and prierced out Saviour through the heart from the heart to the hands. His precious blood began to flow, his blessed mother stands under him below, with heavy sighs and mournfull tears. Anyone says this little prayerthree times by night and by day thegates of hell shall never enter in. Lord be the branch and lady be the flower sweet Jesus be with me at my dying hour. I'd forgive the whole world in hopes the Lord would forgive me this day and night.Peter sat on a marble stone. Jesus came to him alone. "Peter what is on thee"? "Jesus the toothache". Peter get up and come along with me. Whoever shall repate this prayer three times by night and by day shall never have the toothache nor never may.
(continues on next page)

4701726/4696479/4743908.title: A Prayer
4701726/4696479/4743908.text:
As I went out this blessed morningTo view this hold landI met a blessed ladyWith seven Mass books in her handSeven bells a ringingSeven hymns a singingOpen the gates of heaven and close the gates of hell.Those who say this prayer three times by the night and three times by the day they will never die in sin.There are four corners on my bed and four angels overhead. Mathew, Mark, Luke and John. God bless the bed that I lay on.As I lay down to sleep I give my soul to God to keep God within God without. Christ Almighty round about
(continues on next page)

4701726/4696500/4743983.title: Prayers
4701726/4696500/4743983.text: I lie in my bed as I lie in my graveBegging of Jesus my soul to receiveJesus my branch and May my flowerMay ye have mercy on me nowAnd at my dying hourThe chapel door I enter inOutside the door I leave my sinsI bless my face with holy waterIn the name of God, the Son and FatherI pray to God in the holy altarTo give me the benefit of this day's Mass and holy water.In the name of Our Lord Jesus Christ crucified, I lie down to rest. Bless me, O Lord, defend and govern me in this short and miserable pilgrimage and bring me to life everlasting. Amen.

4701726/4696501/4743987.title: Prayers
4701726/4696501/4743987.text: Here I lay my body down to sleepTo God I pray my soul to keepThere are four corners on my bedThere are four angels there spreadMatthew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless me on this bed I lie on.If any evil thing came to trouble me,O Blessed Virgin Mary, waken me.Lord be the flower, Mary the branch,Lord have mercy on me nowAnd at my dying hour.I lay my body down to sleepI pray to God my soul to keepAnd if I die before I wakeI pray to God my soul to take.

4713236/4710152/4744353.title: Old Irish Prayers and when they Were Said

4706361/4706296/4744613.title: Old Prayer
4706361/4706296/4744613.text: Old PrayerVouchsafe that we may praise the sacred Virgin. O Lord give us strength against thine enemies. May God be praised and blessed now and forever.Amen.

4723853/4719238/4744843.title: Collection of Prayers
4723853/4719238/4744843.text: Prayer before lying down ; [?] ask God to protect you during the night; " Here I lay me down to sleepI give my soul to God to keep Christ my Father at my headMother Mary at my feetIf anything should happen meMerciful Jesus have mercy on me.""There are four posters to my [?] bedFour angels early spreadSt Mathew, St Mark, St Luke, St John,God bless the bed I lie on."I learned these two old prayers from a man named Dick Clerkin Carson. He was a very kind holy old man. He died at an advanced age in 1938.

4723853/4719239/4744846.title: Collection of Prayers
4723853/4719239/4744846.text: "Here I lie down to sleep I pray to God my soul to keep And if I die before I wake I pray to God my soul to take""God bless Friday and Good Friday too For that was the day Our Saviour was crucified. His Blessed Mother was standing by With a sorrowful heart and a mournful cry."Those who say this second prayer three times a day the gates of hell they shall never enter.

4723853/4719240/4744849.title: Collection of Prayers
4723853/4719240/4744849.text: Prayer said on going to sleep: "On my right side down lies me, As Jesus did on Mary's knee. With his right hand across her bread [?] That God may sent my soul to rest.""Jesus meek and Jesus mildPity me a little child, Take my heart and bless it, That nothing evil may possess it"

4723815/4715942/4758637.title: Prayers
4723815/4715942/4758637.text:
Prayers to be said when going to bed.This night I lay down to sleep.I give my soul to God to keep. If I die before I wake.I give my soul to God to take.As I go to my bed, I go to my to my grave. Begging of Jesus, my soul to receive. Bright Queen of heaven, Christ be my flower.Jesus be with me at my dying hour.O Lady, O Queen, O Mother.In the name of Jesus, and the love of Jesus. We implore you to take our cause in hand. And grant it good success.O Mary my Dearest Mother. I beg of you to help me at all times.And especially, at the terrible moment of death.Never leave me until you see me safe in heaven.Blessing you and sing in you. Mercy for ever. AmenAs I lie down on my right side,God Almighty be my guide.God almighty, mighty most.Father, Son, and Holy Ghost.
(continues on next page)

4723854/4719351/4759488.title: Old Prayers
4723854/4719351/4759488.text: As I go to my bed, as I go to the grave,I pray to the Lord my soul to receive,Lord of the branch, Lady of the flowerSweet Jesus, be with me at my dying hour.As I lie down to sleepI give my soul to God to keep for ever,Waken now or waken neverI give my soul to God to keep for ever.There are four corners on my bedThere are four angels over my head,Matther, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless the bed that I lie onFor them that sleep they cannot seeHoly Jesus save me.See Our Lady sitting under Our Saviour's kneeThen keep us from the temptation of the devil

4723854/4719355/4759510.title: Local Prayers
4723854/4719355/4759510.text:
I will rise from this bed of sleep to adore my God and to labour for the salvation of my soul Oh may I rise on the last day to life everlasting. Amen.Oh my God clothe my soul with the nuptial robe of charity, and grant that I may wear it pure and undefiled before the judgement seat.Jesus the branches and Mary the flowerProtect me now and in my last hour. As I lie down to take a sleepGod, to Thee I give my soul to keepAny danger in the wayGod Almighty waken me.



For a burn a person licked a mankeepers' stomach and his tongue rubbed on a burn will cure it. The cure for a stye is to point a gooseberry thorn at it 9 times and throw the tenth thorn away saying "In the name of the Father & of the Son and of the Holy Ghost. Amen.Bilberry tea is a cure for the measles.
(continues on next page)

4701704/4694286/4759661.title: Paidreacha
4701704/4694286/4759661.text:
Bás beannuighthe go bhfághaimíd, beatha na glórmhar go gcruinnighimíd, ar bhaintreabhach Muire go rabhaimíd a coidhche agus ar uair ár mbás, AmenÓ a Dhia táim ag iarraidh Ort mar dhéirce mé a leigint isteach i dtigh na féile áit nach n-iarrfaidh mé biadh ná éadach acht beatha na glórmhar is dá h-éisteacht.Absalóide, creideamh cruaidh seo a thuigeanns againn ar uair ár mbás mar thuigeanns an t-aingeal Dé i gcluasa na mná, trí ráithe abhí sí ag A iomchur gur thúirling sí mantal ar a h-asal, dhá ríogh, trí ríogh, siolt, deór, braon níor bhlas A bhéal gur thainic Mac Dé, gur thug Sé an t-uisge trid a mhéar. Is maith
(continues on next page)

4701704/4694288/4759664.title: Paidir
4701704/4694288/4759664.text:
Lughim ar an leabaidh seoMar síntear mé san uaighM’fhaoisdín cruaidh a gním leat a Mhic DéAbsalóid atá mé ag iarraidh OrtIn aghaidh gach ráidhte mo bhéilIn aghaidh gach gníomhartha mo chorp-saÓ a Ḋia nach mé atá lochrach!In aghaidh gach nidh ráiteas agus nár chualasIn aghaidh gach dubhras agus nach bhfuil fíorBhroinnim-se m’anam duit a Athair is a Árd RioghA bhainríoghan na bflaitheas agus a bhanaltra mhic DéA bhfuil de naomh agus na h-aspal i gcathair na trionóideGo dtiocfaidh tú chugam le friothalamhO! a Mhuire mheidhreach is a Mhaighdean ró-chómhactachGo dtugaidh tú radharc dom
(continues on next page)

4701704/4694290/4759666.title: Paidir
4701704/4694290/4759666.text:
(continued from previous page)
Paidir a rinne ÍosaÓs cionn na físeAr shlighe a bhachallI gcionn gach caisilGo mbá rún diamhairA bhéamuid ann.Ná dún na dallAtá a bhraith orainnÓ a Íosa ins an tocharA bhfuil muide annGo dtugaidh Tú sinnAr Do dheas láimhAn t-Athair, An Mac agus an Spiorad Naoimh



Codhladh sin ort a Mháthair? Ní h-eadh a Mhic, a chuisle chreachach. Go d’fhaisling a Mháthair is do beidh do fuinéal is do stuiréal amáireach do cheangal do chosai do chroiche, le claidheamh a chur i Do thaoibh dheis, corón spíonta a chur i Do cheann, tairingní le nár crochadh do chosaí
(continues on next page)

4701704/4694292/4759668.title: An Phaidir Gheal
4701704/4694292/4759668.text:
Luighim-se le Dia, go luighidh dia liomScath de os mo chinn, cros na n-aingeal fa mo chomCa luighfidh in anocht idir Muire agus a Mac, eadar Bríghid is a brat, eadar Colm Cille is a sciath, eadar Dia is A lámh deasCá neireochaidh tú i mbárach?Éireóchad le Pádhraig. Cia iad seo inár ndiaidh an oiread seo eile do mhuinntir de. Druid nó dún Ifreann, agus foscail geata Flaitheas Dé, leig an t-soillse mór amach ó Ḋia. Déan trócaire orainn is mac na hoighe go bhfuighidh ár n-anam.



In ainm an Athar a chuaidh ar neamh,agus A Mhac a d’fhulaing a phian,An Sprioradh Naom ar neartú Maighdin Beannuighthe ar dtriall.
(continues on next page)

4701704/4694295/4759680.title: Prayer
4701704/4694295/4759680.text: T'was on Good Friday our Saviour, he was crucified.A crown of thorns was put on his head.The Jews flowed with the long spear.And hit him from the heart to the hand.Thy blessed blood began to flowThy blessed mother standing by,Anyone, who says this prayerThree times a night, three times a dayWill never enter the gates of hellOr die in mortal sin.Lord be the branchMary be the flower,Jesus and Mary, help me at my dying hourWritten by Vera Jennings, Cullea, Curry, Co Sligo

4723874/4721296/4759990.title: Prayers
4723874/4721296/4759990.text:
PrayersHail Thou! lay me down to sleep.I give my Soul to God to keepIf I die before I wakeI pray to God my soul to take.There are four corners on my bed.These are for Angels overspreadMatthew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod Bless this bed which I lie on.On Good Friday at Easter noonThe Jews came down with their sharp spears and pierced the Heart of Our Saviour dear. The blood did flow from heart and hand. His blessed mother standing by, with a sighful mourn and pitiful cry. Those who say this little Prayer of mine, three by day, or three by night, will never suffer the flames of Hell or Eternal damnation.As St Peter sat on a marble stone weeping all alone. Our Lord and Saviour was passing by and said Peter what ails you or what makes you weep. My Lord and Saviour it is the toothache Rise up Peter and be hail, not you alone but all those who say these
(continues on next page)

4723857/4719532/4760157.title: A Collection of Prayers
4723857/4719532/4760157.text: A Collection of PrayersPrayer said going to bedAs I go to my bed, as I go to my graveI hope in the Lord my soul may be savedLord of the branch, Lady of the flowerI hope the Sweet Jesus be with me at my last hourAs I lie down to sleep I give my soul to God to keepAnd if I die before I wake Lord Jesus Christ my soul may takeThere are four corners on my bedThere are four angels over headMatthew, Mark, Luke and JohnGod bless the bed I lay me inWaken now, waken everI give my soul to God foreverAs I was going through the happy land I met the Blessed Virgin and mass books in her hand.Bells ringing Priests singing the true lamb of God - open the gates of heaven, close the gates of hellLet the sinners in, they that say their prayers three times a day shall never suffer the pains of hell

4758474/4747101/4760273.title: A Collection of Prayers
4758474/4747101/4760273.text: 120 A Collection of PrayersWhen going into the ChurchBefore this church door as I enter inOutside the church door I leave all my sinBegging of the Redeemer of all menNever to let me be guilty of any more sinAs I kneel down before this blessed altarmaking my moans to the Son and FatherAnd the blessed lamb that's pressed with the crown of thornsMay give me the benefit of this day's Mass and holy water.Mrs Holmes, (49 years)Caldra,ElphinIta Gannon,Caldra.Elphin.

4758474/4747102/4760451.title: A Collection of Prayers
4758474/4747102/4760451.text: 121ContinuedTo be said on Good FridayGod bless Good Friday, Good Fridaythe day our Savior was crucifiedThe Jews came with their sharp spearsAnd peirced the heart of our Savior dearHis poor mother being standing byWith a heavy sigh and a dismal cryAll who say this prayer three times by day, three times by nightShall never enter the gates of Hell or burn eternally.John Holmes, (aged 80)Caldera, Elphin.Ita Gannon.Caldra.Elphin

4758474/4747103/4760457.title: A Collection of Prayers
4758474/4747103/4760457.text: When going to bed.There are four corners on my bedAnd on there are four angels spreadMat and Mark Luke and JohnGod bless this bed that I be onIf I die before I wakeI will give my soul to God to takeIf any evil comes to meOh Blessed Virgin Mary you save me.Lord be my branch! Lady be my flowerOur sweet Saviour Jesus Christ be at my dying hour.

4758474/4747104/4760460.title: A Collection of Prayers
4758474/4747104/4760460.text: 123ContinuedWhen lighting a candle the old people used to say:- Lord Jesus: grant us the light of Heaven, when we lave this world.John Rushe (55)Shankil,Elphin.A Rushe.Shankil.Elphin

4758474/4747119/4760495.title: A Collection of Prayers
4758474/4747119/4760495.text: When awakening in the morningO Lord I arise from this bed of sleep to adore my God and to labour for the salvation of my own soul. O Lord Jesus clothe my soul with the robes of charity, that I may wear them pure and undefiled before the judgement seat of Jesus Christ.When going to bedUnder thy protection O Holy Mother of God, we seek refuge, preserve me this night form sin and danger. Grant me thy Holy blessing.When you lie downIn the name of our Lord Jesus Christ crucified, I lay myself down to rest, Bless me O Lord defend and govern me and by this short and miserable pilgrimage bring me to everlasting happiness. Amen

4758474/4747121/4760502.title: Story of the Holy Family
4758474/4747121/4760502.text:
(continued from previous page)
140right road to go to get out of Egypt quicker.Miss Nora Connor (86)Raheen,Mantua P.O.Castlerea.A.  Rushe.Shankil.Elphin



A Collection of PrayersOn gong to bedBlessed Virgin: pity meFrom the shades of darkness set me free.On gong to bedDear St. Joseph! spouse of Mary.Blessed of all the Saints on high.When the death shaded round me fallingTeach, O teach me how to die.Going on a journeyThrough by gone years He's helped me,To-day I'll praise his Name,And trust Him for the future,To help me just the same.Mrs Holmes (79)Caldra.ElphinIta Gannon.Caldra.Elphin

4758474/4747122/4760508.title: A Collection of Prayers - Prayer on Covering the Fire At Night
4758474/4747122/4760508.text:
141A Collection of PrayersPrayer on covering the fire at nightGod save this house as Christ save all,Mary and Brigid guard each wall.May the hosts of angels bright.Guard ourselves and our home to-night.Mrs Travers.Kilmaryal.ElphinA. Rushe.Shankil.Elphin.



Another Prayer (when going to bed)O'Lord: my God, by suffering rent,Nailed to the cross, my love to gainGrant through thy cross when left is spentIn death, thy mercy I obtain.



Another Prayer (on awakening)Oh Sacred Heart of Jesus, I adore thee, wounded by my sins, and I consecrate to Thee, all the joys, sorrows and off-ections of my heart, that united to Thy infinite Love, I may be made one with Thee for all eternity Amen.Mrs Dorr.Kilmaryal.Elphin.A. Rushe.Shankil.Elphin

4742074/4732998/4760539.title: Paidreacha
4742074/4732998/4760539.text:
(1)Anna, Máthair Mhuire,Muire mháthair Chríost,Eibhlís, Gábhréil, máthair Eóin Baiste,Cuirim an triúir san idir mé is galar na leabthan:Téighim fé coimirce crois na mbeann,'Am chosaint ar gach an spiorad fhaid atáim im' luighe,Cuirim an crann gur céasadh Críost,Idir mé agus an Trom-luighe.
(continues on next page)

4742074/4733021/4760594.title: Paidreacha
4742074/4733021/4760594.text:
PAIDIR  SAN  OIDHCHE  ROIMH  DUL  A  CODLADHGo luighidh mé le Mhuire, agus luighidh Muire liomGo gcodlóchaidh mé le h-Íosa agus go gcodlóchaidh h-Íosa liom.Go n-éirighid mé le Mhuire agus go n-éirighidh Mhuire liomGo mairid mé le ÍosaAgus go mhairidh h-Íosa liom.
(continues on next page)

4742076/4733101/4761421.title: Paidir dos na hAnamanaibh Imithe
4742076/4733101/4761421.text: Paidir.Paidir dos na hanmannaibh imighthe: -"Má tá fuigheall faoisdine, dearmad aifrinn, baois óige, ná aon trioblóid eile ón tsaoghal ag déanamh díobhála dá n-anam. Dia is Muire is Mícheál naomhtha go dtugaidh fuascailt fuarthan agus saoghal breitheamhnachais ar a n-anam agus nár agraidh Dia cionntach an saoghal so ar a n-anam ná ar ár n-anam bocht féin nuair f[h]agamaoid an saoghal so.Ó P[h]ádraig Ó Súilleabháin, Milíní, Bunán.

4758474/4747179/4761730.title: Old  Prayers - When Going To Bed
4758474/4747179/4761730.text: 198Old PrayersWhen going to bedO merciful Jesus have mercy on me.My should and my body I resign to Thee.Thy five bleeding wounds and Thou nailed to a tree.O merciful Jesus have mercy on me.2 Holy St. Anne, grandmother of our Lord, pray for us3O God! grant us the light and the glory of Heaven.(This is said when lighting a fire, or a candle)When the lamp was lighted, the old people used to put the sign of the cross on their foreheads and say:- The Cross Christ about us.James Mullaney (86)The Palace,Elphin.Alphonsus Rushe.Shankil,Elphin

4758451/4745130/4770107.title: Old Evening Prayer Which Was Said by the Local People Long Long Ago
4758451/4745130/4770107.text:
241Old evening prayer which was said by the local people long long agoThe following prayer was generally recited in the evening at the setting of the sun, and it was regarded as being the best prayer for the ending of each day.Night is falling, dear Mother, the long day is o'er,And before thy loved image, I'm kneeling once more,To thank thee for keeping me
(continues on next page)

4742076/4733219/4770163.title: Paidreacha
4742076/4733219/4770163.text:
PaidreachaUimh. 1. Beirimíd buidheachas an bheatha-so lenár Slánuightheoir, Íosa Críost, an Té a thug an bheatha so dúinn go dtugaidh Sé beatha shíoraighe agus leabaidh Chríostaidhe dár n-anmanna, go dtugaidh Sé réidhteach ar ár gceasnachaibh agus díol ár seana-fhiacha agus biadh gan aitheas gan náire. Go dtugaidh Dia mór na glóire dúinn i gcómhnaidhe é. Beannacht Dé le hanmanna na marbh go léir, Caitilicigh i bpurgadóireacht agus na seacht sinnsear d'fhág sinn; agus má tá aon smut nú dorchadas ón saoghal so - dearmad Aifrinn, nú briseadh lá shaoire nú Domhnaigh go dtógaidh (dtógfaidh sa lámhscríbhinn) Dia dena hanmanna bochta é.Uimh. 2. Paidir eileTá ceithre cúinne sa leabaidhTá ceithre aingeal timcheall ormMá gheibhim bás sara ndúiseóchadhDo Dhia tugaim mo anam le tógaint.Amen.Ó Phádraig Ó Súilleabháin, Milíní, [An] Bunán.
(continues on next page)

4742076/4733222/4770187.title: Paidreacha Eile
4742076/4733222/4770187.text: Paidreacha eileUimh. 8. Ó a Thighearna, Íosa Críosyt, a dubhairt, "Iarraidh agus tá le fághail agaibh, loirgidh agus gheobhaidh sibh, bualaidh agus osclóchar díbh. Athchuinghimíd ort go humhal, go dtabharfá dúinn tabhartas do ghrádha ró-naomhtha, ionnus go ngrádhochaimís Tú feasda le lán-chroidhe, le gach briathar agus le gach gníomh, agus ná sgarfaimís choidhche de Do mholadh-sa atá beo id'Righ ar shaoghal gan foirceann. - Amen.Uimh. 9.Ó a Dhia caithfidh mé bás d'fhagháilNíl fios agam cad é an t-am,Cé an nós, cé an áit, acht má fhaghaim bás i bpeaca marbhthach táim caillte go deo. A Ísoa dein trócaire orm - Amen.Máire Ní hÉigceartaigh (56 bliana d'aois), Milíní, [An] Bunán.

4742076/4733223/4770190.title: Paidreacha Eile
4742076/4733223/4770190.text: Uimh. 10.A Mhuire, is Tú mo mháthair, is mo dhóchas, cuirim mé féin fé do bhrat annsan; is mian liom mo shaoghal do chaitheamh go maith agus bás d'fhagháil i ngrásta Dé. Saor mé ón bpeacadh agus tabhair dom Do bheannacht - Amen.Uimh. 11.Ó a Dhia, tá dólás mór orm, fearg do chur ort de bhrígh go bhfuil tú chomh maith, agus tá rún daingean agam gan peacadh a dhéanamh arís go bráth - Amen.Uimh. 11. A Dhia, tá grádh agat dúinn, beidh grádh againn duit.Uimh. 12.-Mar a deirid ag ól dí:-Bhur sláinte agus sláinte na gcomharsanSláinte na sean-mhuinntir mar is iad do thóg sinnIs dá mbeadh a gcuid acaIs sinn do gheobhadh í

4713259/4712368/4770528.title: An Sceimhealaireach Beannaithe
4713259/4712368/4770528.text:
An Sgeimhealuireach BeannuightheSin í an Sgeimhluireach beannuigte an Mhaighdean glórmhar ar lic an Tuama.    An t-am a tháinig a’ fhiosrú a Mhic agus a Mór-grádh féin nuair a fuair sí an Tuama folamh roimpi do sgriobh sí go fogharluidhthe dúil ‘á innsint don té thógfadh é as do onórfadh é as do choimeadfadh é nár baoghal do codhladh amuigh.  bás obann, breoidhteacht mór, badhadh fairrge, pianta siorruidhe Ifreann, arm teine, na an tig go mbeadh sé ag doghadh, ná mná óga a bheadh i dtrioblóid cluigne agus é rádh in-a dtimcheall, d’fhoirfeadh sé iad gan amhras de mb’áil leo é rádh no é bheith n-a dtimceall.



An PaidirA bhainriogan ró-ghlórmhair na mílseacht agus na neart ar choimirt dó lá beannuighthe.  Cuirm spiorad m’anama agus mo chorp cughat go h-umhal ‘s mo smaointe is mo gniomhartha ag éileamh do faratheist
(continues on next page)

4742076/4733234/4778182.title: Paidir
4742076/4733234/4778182.text: Paidir a fuaireas ó Mháire Ní Éigceartaigh - thá sí i Lundain fé láthair acht chomhnuigheadh sí sna Milíní, an Bunán.1. Mo bheannacht agaibhbeannacht Dé in bhúr gcuid,in bhúr sliocht agus bhúr sláinte.Nár leogaidh Dia droch-sgéal in bhúr measg,nú measg ár ndaoine náár gcomharsain is gach aoinnego bhfuil amuigh is sa mbaile.2. Íosa Críost ag cainnt lena mháthair"Id chodla[dh] ataoi a mháthair.""Ní headh, a ghrádh geal ach ag marbhna atáimseI dtaobh Rígh na nIúdachAtá [ag] teacht annso i mbárach.Fear caol, ciardhubh a chaol donn fé (?)Beidh an [t]sleagh dhearg ina láimh aigeChun í [a] sháth[adh] tré thaobh ár Slánuightheora, Íosa Críost.""Is maith a[n] m[h]arbhna í, a mháthair."Agus níl aoinne a déarfaidh í trí [h]uaire ar leabaidh chun suain ná faghaidh na flaitheas mar dualgas ar mo ghualain[n] go bráth.(Bhí a thuilleadh leo acht ní raibh sé aici.)

4742127/4738329/4778281.title: Paidreacha
4742127/4738329/4778281.text: PaidreachaFadó bíodh mórán paidreacha ag na daoine agus deirtí íad i gcómhair rudaí áirighthe.  Cuir i gcás da mbeadh sé i na  beus (béas) ag duine tromlaí do teacht air dearfadh sé an paidir seo ag dul a codhla.  “Anam máthair Muire, Muire Máthair Críost, Elizabeth Máthair Eoin Baiste, an triúr san ar clúdh mo leabadh agus an crann gur crocadh Críost idir mé agus an tromlaí.”  Seo paidir a deirtí ar an Coróin Muire i dtig toramh, “Cuirimíd cúig paidreacha cun Dé agus cúig Abhé Máire leis an anam a bhí so corp so láithreach.  Má bhí fuighil faoistine, dearmhad Aifrinn, baois óige ná aon smáilc eile ó’n t-saoghal so, Dia agus Muire agus Mícheál Naomhtha agus an dá easpol déag ag tabhairt fuasgailt fuarthan agus saor breitheamhnas a tabhairt dó.”    Seo paidir a deirtí nuair a bhídís ag dul tar roilg, “Beannuighim Dia a fíor-aoinne Criost atá annso ag feitheamh le aiseirghe glórmhar.  Go dtabharfadh an Té a fuiling bás ar bhúr son suaimhneas sioraighe dhíobh.Áine Ní SheághdhaCillín-liathMaistir-gaoithe.

4742127/4738342/4778295.title: Paidreacha
4742127/4738342/4778295.text: Paidreacha  Do bhí mórán paidreacha ag na sean-daoine agus deiridís na paidreacha sin nuair a bhídís ag obair.  Seo paidir a deireadh na sean-daoine nuair a bhídís ag coigilt na teine ist oidhche.  “Coigilim an teine seo fé mar a coigileann Críost cách Muire i gceann an tíghe is Bríghid na seasamh ar lár an t-ochtar is aoirde i gCathair na Grást.  Siad a chuirim-se fé dhíon am tíghe seo is a dhaoine go lá.”    Nuair a bhidís ag dul a codhladh ist oidhche annsan deiridís an paidir seo, “Luighim le Dia agus luighann Dia liomn ó’m bathas go dtí an bonn.  Gabhaim Dia mar cómhairle, Muire mar Mháthair, Flaitheas Dé mar dhúthchas agus diúltuighim d’on Áirseór.   Na seacht n-aingeal is síne, na seacht n-aingeal is óige, siad a chuirim im’ dhíonughadh im’ ghárdáil agus ag breith m’anam go carraig na Glóire.  Nuair a lasaidís an lampa deiridís an paidir seo, “Solas Dé cun ar m-anam.”Síghle Ní Shíothcháin,Inse na Tuinne,Maistir-Gaoithe,Cill-Áirne.,Fuaireas an é seo ó,Seán Ó Shíothcháin,Inse na Tuinne.,

Agus ag cuir mo pheacaí síos duit a ríoghan na naomh geal



Paidear Roimh BháisIs gearr go raghad im dhúthaig i fios na h-uara í thánghadhGo dtíghidh mo Aingeal Caoinleacht im bhfocair um cosaint ar mo namhaidibh.Go tíghidh Muire agus a banntrac cé gur tsaigeac iad sa Glóire agus an naoi míle déag ban-óga i n-anóradh an o Glórmhar.Go tíghidh Críost agus a ceathrar cé gur calma dhom iad d'iarraidhGo tighidh Íosa agus an ochtara um cosaint ar na píantaGo tíghidh Micheál agus a n-aonúir. Go tíghidh na h-Asbail go tréan cúgam.Go tíghidh na h-Aingeal i caoinleacht mo anama go cathair Íosa mar a bhris leat-sa a Mhic MhuireÍosa Críost a shín do géaga ar crois. D'fhulaing na mílte pianta is na ceadta id loc.Luighim-se síos fé dhéin - tais géag anocht is go raibh an timpeall fíon do chroise, do chré is do chuir

4713259/4712372/4778478.title: Aisling na Maighdine Muire
4713259/4712372/4778478.text:
Aisling  An Maighdhin MuireC. Dia dhuit a Mháthair.F. Dia Dhuit is Pádruig.C. Cad - na - thaobh  ná codhlan tú a Mbáthair.F. Aisling do dheineadh aréir domC. Cad é sin a MháthairF. Go raibh marcach caol dubh ar each caol donn agus sleagh dearg ar a dheas lámh chun é sach trí croidhe an Rí Glórmhar amáireach. Is maith an aisling é sin a Mháthair. An té d'iarfadh an aisling sin trí h-uaire na luíghe ad leabaidh suan dó. Do gheobhadh sé flaithis Dé gan turamaisg, gan dúais ar uair a bháis. Amen



Dé bheathasa Domhnaigh tar-éis na seachtmhaine chorruig ár gcos go moch chun Aifreann, cuir as ar gcroidhe droich smaointinn maluighthe agus tóg ceo na peacaí da'r n-anama. Íosa a cheannuig sinn do shaoradh agus bheannuig sinn. Tóg ceó na peacaí dá'r n-anama

4713259/4712373/4778485.title: Paidir - Nuair a Bheadh na Daoine ag Tógaint Comaoine
4713259/4712373/4778485.text:
7         Nuair a bheadh na daoine ag tógaint comaoine.Ó mo Thighearna Íosa Críost go bhfuil do sheilb dha thógaint is do carthanact dá más leoganac leat cion Criostaidhe, beatha na naomh a thabhairt dom anam.



a.8    Ag fágaint an tSeipéal Mo impídhe cughat  a Mhuire is mo comairce cughat a Íosa is ná dein aon peaca go bhfillfeadh airís ort.



a.9   Nuair a thógainn duine pínse snaoisín Saol úr cughat, bás gan peaca is beannacht na ngrás le h-anamaca na marbh.



a.10   Nuair a bheadh duine ag crúd bó an cead uair tar-éis breith.Rath Dé agus bráon beannuighthe

4713259/4712374/4778511.title: Paidir - Nuair a Mhúchfaí an Solas Istoíche
4713259/4712374/4778511.text:
a.11   Nuair a mucfaí an solus is d’oidhche Go dtugad Dia solus gan dorchadacht dár n-anam



a.12   Ag dul a codhladLuigim sa leabaidh so mar a luighim-se im’uaig.  Deinim m’fhaoisdin go cruaid leat a Dia.  Iaram an asblóid ort a Mhuire gréineacht agus a Maighdean mór glórmhar tabhair radhardh dom  ar do h-adharcanna  mór comhachtach solus na soillse agus radharc na Tríonóide agus grásta na bhfoidhne le h-aghaidh na g-éagcóra.



a.13  Ag  iarraidh athcuinge ar Naomh GobnaitGo mbeannuighe Dia dhuit a Gobnait NaomhthaGo mbeannuighe Muire dhuit agus beanuighim féin dhuitFé comhairc a thánghad ag gearán mo sgeib dhuitAs iarraidh mo leighis ar son Dé ort

4713259/4712375/4778519.title: Paidir i gcomhair an Tromluí
4713259/4712375/4778519.text:
a.14   Paidir i gcoir an TromluidheAnna Máthair Muire, Muire Mháthair Críost, Eiblín sgéabrach máthair Eóin bhaiste.  Cuirfhid me (sé) an triúr ban naomhtha seo ‘dir mé agus galar na leabhtan gan mé mucad, bádhad ná bascad, ná bás dorcad na h-oidhche.  Teighim fé do comaraoise Crios na Meann ar gach namhad atá ar mo thighe agus cuirfid mé an crann go céasadh Críost ‘dir mé is an trom-luidhe.



a.15  Sé do bheatha a Máthair óigSé do bheatha a Máthair óigA realtann lonnrach beanuightheA bhainrioghan comhtac ríamh gan smúidLe grás an Tighearna tuillightheA realt na mara soillsigh dúinnAn ród don cuan ta talamh ciúin

4713259/4712383/4778561.title: Paidir do Naomh Bríd
4713259/4712383/4778561.text:
(continued from previous page)
Aodh Ó h-Amhra an Treimh Boch Críochnuighthe, bhoc Cais, bhoc Cormac, bhoc Eaoinn.  Mise Brighíd Ní Doicadaodh a bheirfeadh an long go réid ó port go port ar do cumairc-sé duinn féin.  Os leat féin bl. an oidhche anocht go bliain ó anocht agus anocht leis amháin le Dia.  Is maith an ráithte  a fagamar.  Is fearr an ráithe go dtanghamar.  Rath an ráithe a fágamar i líona an ráithe go dtángamar.



a (28)Do Naomh PádruigA Phádruig ró naomhthaA cara ár gcroidheÉ a threóruidhe do shaor sinnÓ scamal ár draoidheachtA shagairt do stiúr sinnChum fíor Creidheamh Críost.Tá páistí na h-Éireann ag glaodhach ort airísA Pádruuig ró naomhthaTá mioscas an tsaoghail.   (a críoch so ar L 29)

4713259/4712389/4778567.title: Paidir le Rá ag Crú na mBó
4713259/4712389/4778567.text: a.29Paidir le rádh ag crúadh na mBóRaith Dé ar mo bhó.  Raith Peadar ort is Pól.  A bhanaltra an lúigín óg.  An luíg atá sa chró.  Is an luíg ná’r tháinig fós.  Dia do leughaint leó i bhreith gamhna baineanna is beó.  Sa teacht abhaile ó ló agus ag tabhairt an bainne mhór,11.Raith Dé is Peadar ort is raith na n-aspol ort  Is mór braon beannuighthe ag tuitim na ceataibh ort Is go fachtar do thairbhe is nár a bagal duit fé nár madra ná céim aon chairrge a baineadhaon barasnut ar teacht abhaile chúgham i mbéal a neadarra mo chroidhe, mo caithiseach.111.Éireód ar maidin leat ar mo cóirín bhainne leat agus raghadh agus rathadh leat is ní raghadh cun aistir leat.  Ach ó bun an baile seo go dtí ár barra amach.  Mar a geobhadh féir fada dhuit, fír míon garraid duit, seamróg barra glas, nóiníní deargha a cuireadh i cneadaig tú agus ag tál ar bainne thú.      Croidhe mo caithiseach

4713259/4712392/4778869.title: Paidir

a.30     PaidirÍosa dhibh dílis agus Athair Mhic Suain. 4713259/4712393/4778871.text:
a.32   Céad glóire leis an t-AthairAtá go comhachtac ins na FlathaisCé gur síorruidhe buan é a ainm.Cun a rádh aige ‘s gach n-aon Mar do rughadh é go deallamhAr mainséir fuair an aisil.Ar lár an Geimhreadh gaireamhGan aoibhneas ná aer.Núair éirig suas a bpearsan.Níor glach léas ar thalamhNíor gheidheadh a’ feuc ná marcuidhIs níor gráidh ríamh an géim.Níor shuidh ar cúirt ná ar h-allaNíor geidheadh go tigh-tábhairne ar reachtmaisNíor glach míon i gcóir a leanna.Ach ar fíor uisge caol.Do dhein sé gach nídh do ceapadhDár cúgham a t-ear ‘s a talamh‘S na réiltíní úd ag taistealGac oidhche ar an spéir.Da luigheadh le rádh na beaca.
(continues on next page)

4758455/4745496/4779361.title: Prayers
4758455/4745496/4779361.text:
1 As I lie down on my right side,I pray to God to be my guide,If any evil comes near me,Christ Jesus come and waken me.2 There are four corners on my bed,There are four angels at its stead.Mathew Mark Luke and John,God bless the bed that I lie on.This prayer is to be said each night on lying down to sleep_____________________2 As Christ was walking one day aloneHe met Saint Peter sitting on a marble stoneWhat ailest thou Peter and why dost thou quake,O my Lord and master it is the toothache.Whosoever shall say this prayer for my sake,Shall never again be troubled by the toothache,This prayer is a sure cure for tooth
(continues on next page)

4758455/4745497/4779364.title: Prayers
4758455/4745497/4779364.text:
(continued from previous page)
3 God bless Friday and Good FridayThe day our Saviour was crucifiedHis happy Jews being passing byWith a fierce look unto His heartFrom his heart unto His hand, down His precious blood did flow. His blessed Mother being standing by with a heavy heart and a dismal cry. They who say this prayer three times by night three times by day danger of death they shall never fear or any mortal sin or into the gates of Hell their souls shall never enter



4 O Jesus, sweet Jesus who died on the tree The five bleeding wounds were given for me. My heart and my soul I give unto thee O Jesus, sweet Jesus have mercy on me.Mary is the BranchJesus is the flowerMay the almighty God be with meat my dying hour
(continues on next page)

4758455/4745498/4779369.title: Prayers
4758455/4745498/4779369.text:
(continued from previous page)
Heart of Jesus every day may my love for Thee increase,May it never die and may its ardor never cease,



I adore thee O Most Precious cross which has been adorned and venerated with the tender delicate hands and feet of our Lord Jesus Christ and imbued and dyed with this Precious Blood I adore thee. My God nailed to the cross for the love of me. I again adore thee O holy cross for the love of my Lord Jesus Christ. Amen.

4758488/4748099/4780607.title: Old Prayers
4758488/4748099/4780607.text:
This prayer was said by an old Irish woman in preparation for Communion. The name of it is "My loving Lord a Thousand Welcomes".O Son of Mary I love you, indeed I do. who am I at all, that you shold come next or near me. O. God of Heaven make a little corner in your heart for me, and never while there is life in me let me lose my place there, and after death may I still hide there.Amen.Have pity on me O Blessed Mother talk to my God for me. Tell Him I am poor ignorant creature full of nothing but sin and misery, but that I love you. His own dear Mother, that I am a poor servant and for your sweet sake to help and pity me. Amen.
(continues on next page)

4723830/4717100/4780694.title: Herbs
4723830/4717100/4780694.text:
(continued from previous page)
Boxwood bark is used for headaches. First the bark is boiled and then the juice is drunk.Cherry bark is used as a cure for coughs and sore throats. The bark is cut into small parts and boiled and when it is cool it is drunk.Chestnut bark is boiled for a sore throat. The bark is boiled in boiling water and while still hot it is rubbed on the throat with a very fine soft cloth.



Here I lay down my head to sleep,I pray the lord my soul to keep,If I should die before I wake,I pray the Lord my soul to take.There are four corners on my bed,There are four angels on it spread,Mathew, Mark, Luke and John,God bless this bed that I lay on.O Jesus, the very thought of theeWith sweetness fills my breastBut sweeter far thy face to see,

Is a diarradh na hathchuinge ar so é ort.Bridget's girdle round meMary's mantle beneath meBlessed Michael hold my hand and make my peace with the Son of God. 4758484/4747755/4781295.title: A Prayer Said when Pulling Herbs
4758484/4747755/4781295.text:
Blessed is the vervain that grows through the groundIt was on Mount Calvary first it was foundIt's a cure for all diseases and a heal for all woundsAnd in the name of Jesus I'll pull you from the ground.



It is on Spy Wednesday my sickness I takeOn Good Friday I'll die for your sakeAnd on Easter Sunday great wonders you'll seeBoth the sun and moon dancing in honour of Me

4742151/4740522/4782097.title: Prayers
4742151/4740522/4782097.text:
Prayers.These prayers were given to me by the old people:-Prayer said on getting up in the morning:-I will rise myself up from this bed of sleep to adore my God and to labour for the salvation of my soul, oh, may I rise on the last day to life everlasting. Amen.Another Prayer said on getting up in the morning:-O God, thou kept me safe through the night.Watch me this day and keep me from harm, oh, most loving God.Another Morning Prayer:-Most pure and holy, kind and true and tender Jesus, be our help, our support, our comfort, our glory, or living and our health.Most loving, true and gentle Jesus, guard and guide us from sin, sickness and poverty.
(continues on next page)

4758461/4746307/4782751.title: Prayers
4758461/4746307/4782751.text:
My own sweet Immaculate Mother when death's dreary shadow draws nigh Wilt thou come from thy throne in the Heaven's and teach me thyself how to die. Oh come by St Joseph attended Let me hear the sweet tones of thy voice saying "Now that the exile is ended the time is at hand to rejoice" Bring me  home to the Heart of my master to the land overflowing with bliss where my joys shall be deep and undying to repay all my sorrows in this As I lie down on my right side I pray to God to be my guide and if any dangers happen to me O Blessed Mother
(continues on next page)

Luke and John.God Bless this bed that I lie on.If I be dead before I wake,I give my soul to God to keep.



A halfpenny is called a fluke.A penny is called a wing.A three piece is called a kid's eye.A sixpence is called a tanner.A shilling is called a bob.A half crown is called a half a dollar.A crown is called a dollar.A ten shilling note is called a half a skiff.A pound is called a quid of skiff.
